business.start.para: Mi. Speaker (Hon. Archie Cameron) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - Can the Vice-President of r.he Executive Council, who is acting for the Minister for Defence, inform the House whether it is a fact that Army ducks have been made available in the Windsor district of New South Wales for flood rescue work? Is it a fact that the local State Liberal member, as part of his election campaign, has been visiting various parts of his constituency in one of the Army ducks, and that this has hindered and retarded the work of rescue and relief? Is it also a fact that residents requiring transport to Windsor from their flooded properties have had to wait for the council flood boat while the State Liberal member and candidate for that electorate at next Saturday's State election has continued to use the Army duck on his campaign tour? Will the Minister have inquiries made and inform the House upon whose authority the Army duck was diverted from flood relief work for the abovementioned purpose?

- This matter really comes under the jurisdiction of the Minister for the Army. I shall make some inquiries from the Minister to ascertain whether he can supply the information to the honorable member. I know nothing about the use of Army ducks. The only duck about which I know anything is the way in which the Leader of the Opposition is ducking away from the New South Wales election campaign.

- My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration. Is it a fact that, since the commencement of operations under the InterGovernmental Committee for European Migration. Australia has taken nearly onethird of the emigrants sent overseas under that scheme? Has Australia been more successful than Canada and other countries in attracting European migrants? Is the proportion of British immigrants being maintained and, if so, are we still able to attract more British immigrants than other countries?

- The Australian Government has been closely linked with the work of the Inter-Governmental Committee for European Migration, and it has received from the committee valuable co-operation in the movement of suitable selected immigrants from Europe, all of whom have come within the range of selection of our own Australian selection officers. From memory, I think that approximately 30 per cent, of the total number of migrants who have been moved by this organization have come to Australia. I am glad to be able to say that we have been able to secure a high proportion of the number of people who have left Great Britain. According to Board of Trade figures published by the United Kingdom, the figure has been in the vicinity of 28 per cent. Canada has taken about 20 per cent, over the same period. Australia is currently receiving more immigrants from the United Kingdom than are Canada, New Zealand and South Africa combined - a highly satisfactory result.

- In directing a question to the Minister for Trade I remind him of a statement he made in the House a few days ago in connexion with the sale of the Australian Whaling Commission's station at Carnarvon, in Western Australia, that a selected group of persons had been approached in regard to the sale. I now ask the Minister to be good enough to advise the House just who constitute that selected group of persons.

- I did not say any such thing. What I said was that everyone who was engaged in whaling in Australia had been written to and told that the Government was prepared to sell the whaling station, and asked if they were interested in the sale, and were offered all possible information on the matter. At the same time, by public statements, it was so clearly known that this was the Government's policy that without any prompting from the Government, certain groups of businessmen in

speech.para: Perth, Sydney and various other places have approached the Government. They have been given every possible facility to know and understand everything about the station. It seems that the only organization in Australia which was in blissful ignorance of all this was the Labour Government of Western Australia, and that does not seem to be very much of :i testimonial to it.

talk.start.para: - I direct to the Prime Minister a question which I put with some diffidence because of its subject matter. It has been the custom of the House, in the event of the death of a sitting member, to meet and place on (cord its sympathy, to be conveyed to his relatives, and then to adjourn for 24 hairs as a mark of respect. I invite the Prime Minister to consider an alteration to that procedure, whereby the House will meet, record its sympathy, and then adjourn to S o'clock on the evening of the same day. I do not offer this suggestion in any attempt to lessen the proprieties to which we should adhere on such occasions or to lessen our respect for honorable members concerned, but for reasons which I think every honorable member will understand.

- The problem to which the honorable member refers has, I think, been in the minds of a number nf honorable members. Certainly it has !>pen in my mind. It is quite plainly a matter on which some sensible agreement ought to be arrived at. As the honorable member will agree, it is not, and should not be. a matter of dispute, but a matter for agreement and I propose, at an early d fi te. to take an opportunity to have a word with the Leader of the Opposition about it.

- I direct a question to t.lie Vice-President of the Executive Council. As the right honorable gentleman has been making unsubstantiated charges of corruption against public men in this country, and has been posing as the champion of what he calls " fundamental morality ", will he use his undoubted influence in the Government to have the incomes, and the sources of income, of all public representatives published periodically? This practice is followed in other countries of the world and has been a method, on the one hand, of protecting the reputations of honorable members from unscrupulous accusations and, on the other hand, of protecting the people from malpractices.
- On . the one hand, I have made no charges of corruption against any government or any member of any government.
- I did not say "government ". I said " public representatives ".

- Or public representatives. I have made no charge of corruption, and if I did, and if a royal commission were appointed to inquire into the charges, I should not run away, as the honorable member for East Sydney ran away from such a commission, on the excuse of parliamentary privilege. With regard to the principles of fundamental morality in government I hoped that the honorable member would be in accord with me in that regard. I would think it rather strange if he were not. However, although I would dissociate the honorable member for East Sydney from the principles of fundamental morality, I think that the honorable member for Scullin is in accord with me in that regard. With regard to his suggestions that certain matters should be published, 1 shall have a look into that, and if it is within my power to do something in that regard we shall see what can be done, although it might reveal some rather strange circumstances.

subdebateinfo.title: VISIT OF PRIME MINISTER OF INDIA

talk.start.para: - I ask the Prime Minister whether any definite date has been fixed for the visit to Australia by the Prime Minister of India. Further, will the Government consider, in the preparation of Mr. Nehru's itinerary, visits by him to every State in the Commonwealth ?

- No date has been arrived at. The matter remains completely in general. I have not anticipated that Mr. Nehru will visit Australia before the Prime Minister's conference in June. I had thought that perhaps, at that time, I would be able to discuss with him what he wanted to do. Whether he will desire to visit every State is entirely a matter for him to determine. These journeys of an official kind are not always without their strain for the visitor.

- ls the Postmaster-General aware that the result of the decision of the Full Bench of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court to reject the Public Service Arbitrator's determination in inspect of telegraphists and postal clerks and to substitute in its place other rates of pay has resulted in a reduction of £5 a year in the case of the one group and an increase of only 4½d. a week in the case of the other group on the rates fixed by the Public Service Board itself in December, 1954? Is he aware also that the board has refused to negotiate with the union concerned, in spite of its promise to do so in the event of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission deciding to approve of marginal increases to telegraphists employed by that organization? In view of this information, will the Postmaster-General consult the Prime Minister, if that is necessary, with a view to having an instruction issued to the Public Service Board to meet the union concerned for the purpose of carrying on the negotiations which it promised, but so far has refused, to carry out? If the Prime Minister is not prepared to issue that instruction to the board, will the Postmaster-General do what the Overseas Telecommunications Commission did, and negotiate directly with the union concerned on the subject of these marginal rates?

speech.para: Air. DAVIDSON. - The honorable member for Hindmarsh has directed to me a lengthy and a detailed question. I suggest to him that if he wants detailed replies to all the parts of this question lie should put it on the notice-paper. However, as an immediate reply, I want to say to him that I am quite satisfied that the Public Service Board, in carrying out its functions, is guided, under the policy of this Government, by the decision of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. Of course, the board is, itself, a wagefixing authority for the Public Service and for allied governmental instrumentalities. The honorable member has suggested that I should take some action in the Postmaster-General's Department which would be outside the scope of the Public Service Board. I say to him that the board, in its consideration of wages and conditions, always confers with the allied governmental instrumentalities, and I certainly would not consider any suggestion that the department should act on its own initiative, outside that policy.

talk.start.para: - I desire to ask the Prime Minister, as the president of the Olympic Games Committee, whether it is a fact that ticket holders for the Olympic Games will not be permitted to take cameras to, or photos of, the games. If so. will the Prime Minister request the Olympic Games Committee to "remove this ban so as to enable amateur photographers to add to the pleasure of the games, not only for themselves, but also, for their friends who are unable to attend the games and who, if cameras are allowed, will have the opportunity of seeing slides or prints of the games after their conclusion?

- The plain truth, in reply to this question, is that I do not know. I do hope that my friend will not presume that the Olympic Games are within my administration as Prime Minister. I thank Heaven that they are not.

- I preface my question by reminding the Prime Minister that just before the recent election an announcement was made in Canberra that plans for a new Bass Strait ferry were well under way. In view of the fact that recent events have proved Taroona to be most unpredictable, will the Prime Minister have these plans finalized so that the vessel may be replaced at the earliest possible da.t«2

- I will take _ the matter up with my colleague, the Minister for Shipping and Transport, who has, I know, been directing a great deal of attention to it of late. I am happy to hear from the honorable member that Taroona is unpredictable. One aspect of its operation that can always be predicted with complete certainty is that it will cost us, by way of subsidy, £200,000 a year.

- Order ! I must call the attention of honorable members to the fact that two questions have just been addressed to the Prime Minister on matters that are outside his control. I must ask honorable members to confine their questions to matters for which Ministers are responsible or I shall have to ask them to sit down.

- I rise to order. I understand that the Government has made a substantial contribution to the finances of the Olympic Games Committee. As this money comes from revenue, are not honorable members entitled to ask of the Prime Minister questions concerning the work of the committee?
- I should not think so. The money has been voted to the committee and I do not think that the Government, as a government, is taking an active interest in the running of the Olympic Games.

- I ask the PostmasterGeneral whether his department has now decided to issue a special postage stamp to commemorate the work done in Australia by the Royal Australian Flying Doctor Service. If so, will the department give special consideration to the design that has been submitted by the officers of the Royal Australian Flying Doctor Service? Finally, if it is true that the stamp is to be issued, could the Postmaster-General arrange for the Royal Australian Flying Doctor Service to be notified of the date of issue long before public notice of it is given, so that the service may be able to capitalize on the first-day covers, and obtain the profits therefrom which otherwise would go to private stamp dealers?

- The honorable member has been in touch with me for quite some time about the issuing of this stamp. A design was submitted by him and it has been forwarded to the stamps committee for consideration. I believe that his very laudable desire will be given effect, and I shall certainly take into consideration the proposal that he has now made.

- I refer to the recent statement by the Minister for Trade that gifts from the United States of America had had the effect, in certain areas, of cutting off the sale of similar Australian goods. I wish to know whether that was a private statement of opinion, or whether commercial or diplomatic representations have been made to the United States in the matter.

- It is a matter that has been discussed very publicly at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade conferences, and since. Broadly, the attitude of the Australian Government is that if the United States of America or other countries wish to give, or sell cheaply, surplus or other goods to needy people in circumstances which would not interfere with the normal trade of other countries, we shall offer nothing but encouragement. The criticism is of countries who are possessed of surpluses and decide to give those surplus goods, or sell them cheaply, to the customers of other normal trading countries, and to that extent distort the ordinary pattern of trade and subtract from the ordinary export income earning capacity of the trading countries.
- The criticism is directed to the United States of America itself?
- Quite clearly, yes.

- I ask the Minister for Social Services whether a decision has been made to establish a regional office of his department in Newcastle, and, if so, whether a regional director will be appointed. If these decisions have been made, could the honorable gentleman inform me as to the area that will be controlled by the regional director, and whether it will include those parts of New South Wales north of the Hawkesbury River?
- I have no knowledge of the opening of any regional office anywhere, but it shall be my pleasure to make the necessary investigations and inform the honorable member foi' Robertson direct.

- I ask the Prime Minister whether the Government has under consideration a proposal to amend the Seat of Government (Administration) Act so as to incorporate in that enactment the provisions of section 92 of the Constitution, as has been done in a comparable act relating to the Northern Territory. As this matter bears so directly on the transport of goods by road from the State of New South Wales to the Australian Capital Territory, and thus is reflected in the cost of materials and the prices of commodities here, will the Prime Minister take the earliest opportunity to make some announcement on the matter?

- I confess that I have never thought of the point, but it is an extremely interesting one. I shall be very happy to have a discussion with the Attorney-General and try to arrive at some mind about the matter.
- Does the Prime Minister recall that he made an election policy speech in 1949? Does he recall that he j>;;ive certain guarantees regarding government enterprises, and that he said -

quote.para: I state quite categorically what we shall do about them. We shall, among other things, be encouraging the improvement of existing mercantile fleets. and be requiring the new Government shipping line to justify its existen re nationally and competitively.

speech.para: Tn view of this guarantee, has the Prime Minister changed his mind in respect of the Commonwealth shipping line? What has the Commonwealth shipping fleet or the Australian Shipping Board done to warrant any change in the present arrangement, whereby these 43 ships are operated as a Government enterprise?

talk.start.para: - To the extent that the honorable member's question reminds both him and the House of the excellence and quality of my 1949 policy speech, I am indebted to him. It is a piece of absolute unselfishness on his part to remind us of it.
- And extravagance on yours.
- No, I stand by every word of it. It is an admirable document. As to the rest of the honorable member's question, it obviously relates to a matter of policy, and therefore cannot be answered.

- I preface my question to the Minister for the Interior by saying that at the federal election held on the 10th December, 1955, instructions were given, consistent with section 130 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, that each candidate was to be represented at each polling booth by only one scrutineer. When the provisions of section 131 of the act were pointed out, particularly the provision that " all the proceedings at the scrutiny shall be open to the inspection of the scrutineers ", candidates were allowed more than one scutineer, so as to obviate the delay which would have resulted from counting in the presence of only one scrutineer. Will the Minister take action to see that the confusion which resulted from the conflict between sections 130 and 131 will be avoided, and the practical requirements of the scrutiny met?
- I assure the honorable member for Yarra that I shall look into the subject-matter of his complaint and make every endeavour to see that there is no possibility of confusion in the future.

- I ask the Prime Minister whether it is a fact that surplus finance from this year's revenue cannot be allocated to ex-servicemen for the purchase of existing dwellings because it is required for the loan programme. Does the Prime Minister consider investments for loan programmes more lucrative and more pressing than the return received from war service homes investment and the satisfactory housing of ex-servicemen or does the right honorable gentleman believe in encouraging the present black market that is now being operated by certain financiers when finding temporary finance for ex-servicemen who are waiting for the War Services Homes Division to find and grant permanent finance ?

- I cannot profess that I clearly follow the point that has been made by the questioner because, in point of fact, the Commonwealth has no loan moneys to use for this purpose. Therefore, I should have thought the question hardly arose. I will have a look at the details of the question he has put, and if something can be said further, I will be glad to do so.

- I address my question to the Minister for Labour and National Service. In view of the fact that those working under State awards are receiving 19s. a week more than workers operating under federal awards, does the Government intend to make any attempt to bring the federal awards into line with the State awards in order that this anomaly may be rectified?

- As I think the honorable member will he aware, there is a case partly heard before the full bench of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court at the moment. That case covers, in some degree, the particular matter referred to by the honorable gentleman. Counsel for the Commonwealth has already indicated that at a later stage of the proceedings a statement will be made on behalf of this Government, and I do not propose to add to that at this juncture.

- My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the term for which the former Minister for the Army has been apponted Consul-General in New York, and what salary and expense allowance is he receiving in that office?
- I will refer this matter to the Department of External Affairs, and I will have that information obtained and circulated to the honorable member.

debate.para: Debate resumed from the 29th February (vide page 384), on motion by Sir Eric Harrison -

item.para: That Mr. Downer, Mr. Drummond, Mr. Joske, Mr. Kent Hughes, Mr. Lucock, Mr. Mackinnon, Mr. Timson and Mr. Wentworth he members of the joint committee appointed to consider foreign affairs generally and, in particular, to inquire into matters referred to it by the Minister for External Affairs.
That the foregoing resolution he communicated to the Senate by message.

debate.para: Mr. CALWELL(Melbourne) [10.59 J. - Last evening the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison), who was in charge of the House, tried to rush this motion through the chamber. We had no notice of it, and we secured the adjournment of the debate in order that honorable members might have the opportunity to express their views about the fitness or otherwise of the various honorable members who, in the terms of the motion, are to constitute this foreign affairs study circle. I should like to say, in passing, that when we received the names of the senators who will constitute part of the joint committee, we were amazed, but not surprised in another way, to find that the sole member of the AntiCommunist Labour party has joined this committee.

The names submitted to the House for approval commence with that of the honorable member for Angas (Mr. Downer). I think the honorable member for Angas might very well be a member of this committee, because he is a very able and very likeable man. As a matter of fact, he should have been in the Ministry. Why he was excluded and some of thu duds were allowed in, I do not know. I hope what I have to say about his qualities will not damage his prospects in the future, and I sincerely trust that he is at least in the third eleven. Speaking seriously, of all the Government supporters included in the list, I know no honorable member who works harder or discharges his duties with a higher sense of responsibility than does the honorable member for Angas, and I wish him well in whatever he undertakes. He has served on the Foreign Affairs Committee for a considerable time, and it is probably right and proper that, if there is to be continuity in that body, he should be a member of it still.

The honorable member for New England (Mr. Drummond) is a very learned man, and was for a time Minister for Education in New South Wales. He has taken a long and active interest in political life and in the cultural affairs of his own State and, indeed, of Australia. We offer no objection to his appointment to the committee. But I am intrigued by the fact that a former New South Wales Minister for Education has to join a study circle to learn something about foreign affairs. This seems to be all wrong, and I have no doubt that we shall be given some explanation of why the study circle should not be constituted into a proper foreign affairs committee. But that is by the way. The Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton) is looking at me intently while I am discussing the honorable member for New England.

talk.start.para: - I am looking at the honorable member with a sort of affection.

- I thought it may have been because the Minister has a guilty conscience since he has forestalled the honorable member for New England as a representative of the Australian Country party in the Ministry. The name of the honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Joske) has been included in the list of nominees for the Foreign Affairs Committee. I suppose the honorable member had to be included. He has just returned from the United Nations head-quarters in New York. Having had the United Nations mayonnaise liberally showered over him, he is regarded as an expert. The honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes) is to be a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee. His appointment will be scarcely a solatium, though it is intended as such, for his wounded feelings after his undeserved exclusion from the Ministry. It shows what would have happened in the party room had the Ministers been selected by the same means «s the proposed members of the Foreign Affairs Committee were chosen. The honorable member for Chisholm won nomination for appointment to this committee on the votes of his fellow members, but he was not able to win approval for a place in the Ministry from the "top brass " of the Liberal party as exemplified "by the Vice-President of the Executive

speech.para: Council. The honorable member for Lyne (Mr. Lucock) is a very thoughtful young man, and he naturally wants to learn something about our foreign relations and to discover whether we have a foreign policy - it is very doubtful whether we have. The honorable member for Corangamite (Mr. Mackinnon) is a very quiet and reserved gentleman who probably will break forth in this study circle, although he has not done much up to date. He comes from a very distinguished family, and I am sure he knows a great deal about the government of nations. Perhaps he knows more than do a lot of his colleagues. Then there the honorable member for Higinbotham (Mr. Timson). I thought he was in line for the Speakership. Certainly, at one time, he was tipped for that position. His appointment to the Foreign Affairs Committee, too, is intended as a solatium for his wounded feelings.

Now I come to the piece de resistance. the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth). If there is one committee of which he should not be a member, it is the foreign affairs study circle, or any other committee concerned with foreign affairs. The honorable member was the grand inquisitor on the original Foreign Affairs Committee. He thought that this was not to be a study circle. He thought it was to be a place where he could pursue his heresy hunts. He wanted to arraign people for treason before this committee. He wanted to be allowed to run loose through the Department of External Affairs, seeking out those whom he regarded as Communists, fellowtravellers, and the like. His years of study in the study circle do not seem to have improved his technique at all. We do not like him on this committee, because he just will not grow up on questions of foreign affairs.

talk.start.para: - He hates the "Corns." too much. That is what the honorable member means.

- He may hate Communists, but there are other people whom he hates more, and they are members of the Australian Country party, because he thinks that they are far more dangerous to the peace of Australia and the good government of this country, and he is right. He has made a success of professional anti-communism. He can always get a press when he wants to inveigh against some honorable member on this side of the House. He is the perfect smear-master when it comes to labelling his opponents Communists. He does not believe half of it, of course, but it suits in the present frame of mind of the electorate. These are the people who a re to constitute this committee. We will not have any reports from them, of course. They will not tell us when the Indonesian ambassador comes to address them and gives his opinion of Senator Rankin for his recent utterances. We will not hear from them why the Minister for External Affairs found it necessary to prostrate himself before Dr. Soekarno and apologize because one member of this Parliament exercised the right of free speech and said what he thought was right concerning the Indonesian President some time ago. If I may say so parenthetically, I thought that the display of cringing servility towards the Indonesian President by the Minister for External Affairs was equalled only by the late El Glouai when he prostrated himself before the restored Sultan of Morocco, Ben Yussef, and begged for mercy. The Government has had it in its power to make this committee a real committee over the years. It has refused to do so. We shall allow the motion to proceed, but we do not expect any better results from this committee than we got from the previous one.

speech.para: Mr.WENTWORTH (Mackellar) fi 1.8]. - There is one verse in the Bible which I think I need never read so long as I am in this House. That is, "Woe to you when all men speak well of you ". I am sorry that I have not received even a solatium from the honorable member for Melbourne (Mr. Calwell), who is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He says that he does not like me on this committee. He may not like me in other political places either. I make no apology for seeing in foreign affairs to-day a conflict between the two systems of communism and freedom. I make no apology whatsoever for that, because that is the essence of foreign affairs to-day, and if that essence is embodying itself, as it is, in the atomic situation, when this material situation embodies that non-physical conflict, at least I can say that I have shown some interest in this matter. I make no apology whatsoever for anything that I have said or any line that I may have followed. I do not think it right that when the world is locked in this ideological conflict, which will determine by its issue the whole future of mankind, honorable members of the Opposition should seize the opportunity to try to make a few cheap political points. It is no laughing matter that humanity lies in imminent danger of extinction. It is no laughing matter that the freedoms that we have won over some thousands of years of struggle upwards from slavery all lie in jeopardy. It is no laughing matter, as the honorable member for Melbourne seems to think, that those who believe that these things are of the essence of foreign affairs should endeavour to join even a study circle in relation to them. I make no apology whatever for what I. not by myself but in common with other members of the committee, said in a report in relation to a certain Dr. Burton, intimately connected with both the Communist party and the Labour party and forming one of the links between them, when he went overseas and, knowing what he was doing - because he could not plead ignorance - signed a report which came very near to treason, even if, by reason of the technical deficiencies of our law, it did not actually constitute treason. I make no apology for what I. in common with, other members of the committee, did or reported to the House on that occasion.

If the phrase " cringing servility " is to be used, as it was used a few minutes ago by the honorable member for Melbourne, then I must apply it to him. He is not a Communist. I do not believe even that he likes the Communists. But he is cringing servilely to his leader, who is taking the party in the direction of communism. The honorable member for Melbourne is paying off for the fact that he has made a deal which has retained for him the deputy leadership of his party in this House. He is now, as so many other Labour people are, saying things which are helpful to communism and which follow the Communist line, for his own personal advantage. If that is not cringing servility, I do not know what is.

Mr.WARD (East Sydney) [11.12 J. - 1 want to add to the criticisms that have been made of this committee, and deal with the remarks of the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth). The honorable member for Mackellar ought to examine his own conscience and then decide whether he could be a useful member of this committee. He never misses an opportunity to attack the Labour party and its leader because of what he states to be the party's cringing attitude towards, and its domination by, the Communist party.

The honorable member cannot deny that on one occasion, when he was doing a little cringing and crawling himself, he called on Mr. Roach, a prominent member of the Communist party on the south coast of New South Wales, to talk to him about certain difficulties which he was having in running a newspaper there. At that time, the honorable member made a donation to Mr. Roach to support the waterside workers in a dispute in which they were then engaged. He decided also to present them with a cup, to be competed for at the annual six-hour day celebrations in Wollongong. It was known as the Illawarra cup and was to be presented for the Lest marching display in the procession. In the first year of the competition, the cup was won by the south coast section of the Waterside Workers Federation and the honorable member had the pleasure of presenting the Illawarra cup to Mr. Healy, the general secretary of the federation. So we can imagine what hypocrisy the honorable member engages in when he attacks the Labour party and its leader.

Let us look at his firm opinions. I believe that the honorable member is fanatical. He sees the hand of communism everywhere. How could he be a useful member of this committee? Some time ago, he issued a pamphlet in which he referred to a preventive war. He wanted the Western powers to take advantage of the time that still remained, according to him, to drop their atomic and hydrogen bombs immediately on the

Soviet. That was his solution of world problems. What contribution could a man who holds such views make to the Foreign Affairs Committee? As a matter of fact, I have heard him referred to in the corridors as "Bomb happy Bill ". He has it on his brain. I can understand that a lot of people in the. world are worried about the present situation and the development of these great weapons of destruction, but the honorable member for Mackellar has become a complete fanatic. He thinks of nothing else, and sees the menace of communism in every direction.

I suggest, as has also the honorable member for Melbourne (Mr.Calwell), that the Foreign Affairs Committee is purely a study circle, and that it will make no reasonable contribution towards the solution of Australia's difficulties or the formulation of foreign policy. The Government originally wanted Opposition members to join a committee which was to consider only matters referred to it by the Minister for External Affairs. No provision was made for the making of a minority report to the Parliament. As a. matter of fact, the Opposition members could not report to anybody. They could not report even to their own party or convey in conversation to any member of the Parliament what they had learned. How utterly ridiculous that would be! Therefore, in my opinion, the Australian Labour party has adopted the correct attitude. In relation to the personnel of the committee, I am perfectly satisfied, whatever I might say about other individual members of it, that the honorable member for Mackellar is a fanatic, and that he has fixed opinions about certain aspects of Australia's foreign policy. That has proved to the satisfaction of Opposition members that they did the correct thing in not associating with the committee and certainly in not associating with the honorable member for Mackellar.

talk.start.para: - I wish to make a personal explanation. I refer to two matters, one of which is trivial and the other important. The version given by the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) of what happened on the south coast is, to say the least, highly fanciful and almost completely untrue. It has been mentioned before in this House by the honorable member for East Sydney and 1 have previously exposed its falsity. The important matter is what he said in relation to a pamphlet that I issued. His statement on that matter also happens to be untrue. What I said in that pamphlet was not as it has been stated by the honorable member. I said that, while the democracies had the monopoly of atomic weapons, they should use them to enforce world control and to ensure permanent peace. If that had been done at that time there need have been no war, and Ave would not now stand, as the whole world stands, in danger of obliteration. That is a serious matter. I feel that I must direct the attention of the House to that misrepresentation - I shall not call it a deliberately misleading statement - by the honorable member for East Sydney. I am. indeed very sorry that he does not appear to like it.

. - One of the penalties that I have had to pay for w hat has happened to me in the past few weeks - and I assure the House that it was entirely unsought and unexpected - has been the necessity to surrender my place on the Foreign Affairs Committee. It was my privilege to be a member of that committee from its inception, and I think I attended every meeting of it. Iii my opinion, perhaps the finest thing ni its kind that the Government has ever d.,ne has been to establish a committee of this description for the distribution of information to members of this House anr! members of another chamber so that they may, in turn, inform their colleagues, whoever they may be, of the changing circumstances of modern society so far as external affairs are concerned. As I Iia ve stated, I very much regret that I arn no longer a member of the committee. I enjoyed every hour that I spent with it. I enjoyed meeting representatives of other peoples of the world, and I consider that the work that was done by the committee was of inestimable value to inn and to the country as a whole. Having ?aid that, let me say that, for the life of me. I cannot understand the attitude of the. Opposition. So far as I am in a position to judge that attitude, it can be described only as a miserable confession of cowardice. At one stage therewas in existence no foreign affairs CoIn.mitteee, but only the Department of External Affairs, whose titular head - now the Leader of the Opposition - had the prerogative, apparently, of determining the foreign policy of the then Government. I remind honorable membersand, indeed, the people also, that that being so, Australia became, for thefirst time in our history, a dubious international risk. We were not trusted by any other reputable country on the faceof God's earth. It was not until the people in their wrath rejected the LabourGovernment and elected the MenziesFadden Administration, as we know it to-day, which in turn established theForeign Affairs Committee, that we as a nation were able to recover the position. The Foreign Affairs Committee has played a very important part in that recovery.

speech.para: I am on intimate terms with some of the ablest members of the Opposition, for whom I have the greatest regard. To my certain knowledge, they are very eager to play their part as an Opposition and to nominate some of their number for appointment to this committee; but honorable members opposite are forbidden to take any part in the deliberations of this body. What a lamentable state of affairs! That sort of thing could not possibly happen in the Australian Country party, nor could it happen, I believe, in the Liberal party. There is, as I have stated, a group of Labour men in this House and in another place who are anxious, to my certain knowledge, to inform themselves about important events in other parts of the world, but they are expressly forbidden to have anything to do with the committee. My friend, the honorable member for Melbourne (Mr. Calwell) has been placed in the invidious position this morning of having to stand up and try to defend that indefensible attitude.

One of the complaints that have been voiced by the Opposition against the committee is that its members might not be able to obtain information they want. I can assure honorable members on both sides of the House that, if and when they are appointed to the committee, they will be fully loaded with, all the information they are likely to absorb. The reading that is necessary to keep oneself informed can be described only as being prodigious. No matter how limited a man's capacity may be, he cannot fail to improve himself by being associated with the committee. Proof of what I have to say is to be found in our own experience. No sooner was there a cleavage in the ranks of the Opposition, no sooner was the Anti-Communist Labour party established in this House and in another place, than the very first thing that party did was to indicate that it wished to participate in the Foreign Affairs Committee's discussions, and play its full part in that committee. And it did. I was privileged, together with other members of the committee, to sit with members of the Anti-Communist Labour party from day to day, and if any one cares to ask those who were at that time members of that party their opinion of the value of the work of the committee, I am quite certain the answer would be that the committee's functions were of inestimable value to the country as a whole. The proof of that was emphasized last night, I believe, in another place, when again the Anti-Communist Labour party, given the opportunity to do so, immediately indicated that its members in the Senate would be represented on the Foreign Affairs Committee. It is simply impossible for any private individual to keep himself informed of all that is happening throughout the world unless there is a committee of this description, with the latest information available to it from day to day, and with representative people appointed to it, competent to absorb that information.

I did not know the names of the honorable members selected to represent this House on the committee until I heard them announced by the honorable member for Melbourne, who is Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The honorable member for Angas (Mr. Downer) was previously a member of that committee. I sat with him continuously since its inception.

talk.start.para: - He is a very able man.

- I agree, and if the honorable member for Melbourne would pay a little more attention to what the honorable member for Angas has to say from time to time I am quite certain that it would be of great value to him. The honorable member for New England (Mr. Drummond) is another old member who has been renominated, and, it is to be presumed, will be re-appointed to the committee. The honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Joske) is a newly nominated member, and I know, from the character of the man and the quality of the work that the committee does, that he will find it of absorbing interest. So, too, with the honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes). His experience in other parts of the world should make him a very valuable member of the committee. The honorable member for Lyne (Mr. Lucock) - and I think the House should know this - has been very anxious to be, like a great many other members on both sides of the House, a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee. The fact that I have been placed in the position that I now occupy gave the honorable member for Lyne this opportunity, and I have no doubt that he will discharge his duty with all the ability that he has. The honorable member for Corangamite (Mr. Mackinnon) cannot be otherwise than a valuable member of the committee, and can only discover, as we all have discovered, the absorbing interest to be derived from the work of the committee. The honorable member for Higinbotham (Mr. Timson), with whom I composed my differences yesterday, for which both he and I are glad, has been appointed as a member of the committee, and I am sure he will enjoy his work on the committee. The honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) is only the third retiring member of the committee to be reappointed. He, of course, is a most colourful character, and, though I must confess that it is my invariable practice, as soon as he begins to speak, to retire from the scene, that is probably my fault. But he has been a very valuable man in the Foreign Affairs Committee, whatever his disabilities may be in other directions. I do not know the identities of those nominated by the Senate to be members of the committee, but I close by saying that I, as a perfervid democrat, deplore the attitude of Her Majesty's Opposition on this question, as I do its attitude on a great many other questions. Here is an opportunity for members of the Opposition, by their own decisions and their own acts, to be represented on a committee that is of transcendental importance to our country as a whole. Yet here is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition placed in a position this morning of having to inform the House that the Opposition is expressly forbidden to participate in the work of a committee.

. - I think the House must feel indebted to the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton) for having, like the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward), put the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) in proper perspective. The Minister has made it clear, as has the honorable member for East Sydney, that the House regards the honorable member for Mackellar as being somewhat of an oddity. We agree with the Minister for Social Services in that regard, and I leave the honorable member for Mackellar to think over the views of not only the honorable member for East Sydney, but also those expressed by one of the Ministers in the Government that he supports. I should like to say at once that I fully support the appointment of the honorable member for Angas (Mr. Downer). It seems to me, as the honorable member for Melbourne (Mr. Calwell) has stated, that this is the Government's way - a rather shabby way too, I might say, incidentally - of giving some small consolation to this man who, it knows in its own mind, should have been appointed to the Cabinet; because, if ever a man were entitled to be added to the Cabinet as a result of the contributions he has made to this Parliament in debate, and because of his general understanding and demeanour in the Parliament, that man is the honorable member for Angas. It is a tragedy that a man such as he should have been left out of the Cabinet and given this job in the " study circle " while a man such as the Minister for Social Services should be appointed to the Cabinet. One would have no difficulty in going through the list of Cabinet members and finding the names of at least five or six men who could never have survived a ballot of their fellows in a joint party meeting of the Liberal and

speech.para: Australian Country parties had they been compelled to face one. What I have said of the honorable member for Angas also applies to the honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. Joske), because he, again, is one who was surely entitled to expect promotion to the Cabinet as a result of the work that he has done in this Parliament. It must have come to him as something of a shock when he looked at the calibre of some of the Ministers who now constitue the Government, especially some of those in the " second eleven ", and had to ask himself whether the Prime Minister at heart considered them to be of greater intellect than he is.

I refer now to the remarks made by the Minister for Social Services about the honorable member for Chisholm (Mr. Kent Hughes). He spoke of that honorable member's great suitability for membership of the Foreign Affairs Committee, saying that he is a man who has travelled widely. Unfortunately for the honorable member for Chisholm, he is indeed a mau who has travelled widely. Had it not been for his recent visit abroad to the island of Formosa where he kowtowed to Chiang Kai-shek, and for the statements that he made about his visit to Taiwan, which is the Formosan name of Formosa. I think the honorable member for Chisholm might still be a member of the Cabinet. It is well known that, privately, he has expressed the view that the reason for his omission from the Ministry was that the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) and the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey) did not agree, with statements that he made publicly in relation to Formosa. However, this gentleman will now join the Foreign Affairs Committee, and the Prime Minister will have the consolation that the views of the honorable gentleman, when he is a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, will be taken very little notice of. They will be taken far less notice of than if he were a Minister. The Prime Minister thus made sure that the honorable gentleman, as a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, would be prohibited, according to the terms of his appointment, from giving any information or making statements that bear on any of the information given to him as a member of that particular body.

I come now to the most interesting aspect of the whole matter, and that is the regret that has been repeatedly expressed by members of the Government about the refusal of the Opposition to become identified with this Foreign, Affairs Committee. On the one hand, members such as the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) and other irresponsible types such as the honorable member for Mackellar have told this Parliament repeatedly that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) is nothing more nor less than a Communist stooge: and that the honorable member for East Sydney, likewise, is nothing more nor less than an under.cover agent of Russia in Australia. Having said this and given the impression that they really meant it, they then express regret that the Opposition has not identified itself with this Foreign Affairs Committee to which, if it is half as important as we are led to believe it is, the Opposition would undoubtedly elect the very two people that Government supporters so roundly condemn whenever the opportunity presents itself. The Opposition would, of course, elect its own leader, and the honorable member for East Sydney would always be assured of election to any committees such as this, that the Opposition might find itself prepared to identify itself with.

I would like to ask whether the Government, in these circumstances, wants to give to itself the right to tell the Opposition whom its representatives should be and whom its representatives should not be. If the Government is not going to take unto itself that right, we can only assume that the Government, in extending its invitation to the Opposition to be associated with this committee, did so in the knowledge that the men whom it has condemned here as being unworthy of the Parliament would be the men who would sit on this committee. It either proves that the committee is what we say it is - an ineffectual body that is nothing more nor less than a study circle - or else it shows, as is more probable, that the Government members themselves do not really believe the attacks that they have made and the things that they have said about the Leader of the Opposition and members of the Opposition, such as the honorable member for East Sydney.

The reason that the Opposition has repeatedly rejected the invitation of the Government is mainly that we believe that the committee is not given the full right that it should be given. We do not believe that the Minister, for example, should be the only one who should have the right to say what matters shall be considered by the committee. We believe that the committee, if appointed, should have the power to call upon any of the departmental officers to inform its mind on any matter of foreign affairs that the committee considers ought to be dealt with. The committee should have the right, moreover, to advise the Minister for External Affairs on matters of foreign affairs when it believes that the Minister is astray, or about to make a decision one way or the other. The Opposition, moreover, believes that a committee which is compelled, in the circumstances, to consider only those matters that are referred to it by the Minister, and which is compelled to consider only that information which is weeded out by the Minister as being suitable for its ears, cannot serve its purpose in the way that the Opposition would like to see it serve this country.

I direct attention to the fact that, the honorable member for Angas expressed his complete opposition to the Government's decision and the Minister's decision, to enter into the peace treaty with Japan which allowed for the rearmament of Japan. There are other members of the committee who supported the views of the honorable member for Angas in opposing the decision of the Government to rearm Japan so shortly after Australia had been fighting Japan in a theatre so near to our own shores. If one is able to use the standards of debate in foreign affairs as the criteria by which to judge whether or not this study circle has had any important results, one is compelled to say at once, and without hesitation, that the study circle has been a dismal failure. Apart from the expressed views by the honorable member for Angas, the views expressed by the honorable member for Mackellar and some former members of the committee, particularly the Minister for

Social Services, who has just left the chamber, are a classical example of poorly-informed minds, or of the minds of people who are so prejudiced as to be incapable of being informed, no matter what information is available to them. The Opposition is very suspicious that the original purpose of the Government in inviting the Opposition to become identified with the committee was to try to commit the Opposition to the Government's plan at that time to become involved in an aggressive war against the people of Asia. We have to consider that the Foreign Affairs Committee was first appointed at a time at which the Prime Minister had come back to this country and promised the people of Australia that he would be able to provide them with a war against Asia within three years. The Foreign Affairs Committee was formed in the hope that the Opposition would be foolish enough to become identified with it, so that the Government r-ould then say, when it declared war on the people of Asia, in accordance with the plans that were undoubtedly so carefully laid by the Government and its advisers in America, that the Opposition was behind it, and that Australia, as a nation, was united behind the Government's aggressive designs in Asia. The Opposition was not prepared, therefore, to allow its name to be used as the excuse for declaring this aggressive war on people in Asia, whose only wish was to govern themselves. We made it clear, therefore, that if this committee was to have any power, it would require the right to examine any particular aspect of foreign affairs, and the right to call for information on foreign affairs. It would also have to be able to give an intelligent view on all matters relating thereto. The Opposition, as I say, repeats that it is not prepared to become linked with the Government's designs in Asia one way or i ho other.

Sir ERICHARRISON (WentworthVicePresident of the Executive Council and Minister for Defence Production) f 11.44]. - in reply - I just want to straighten the record on this matter. It seems to me that things have gone completely off the rails. They went off the rails originally with the statement of the honorable member for Melbourne (Mr. Calwell) when he said that the Government was making another attempt to rush business through this House without notice. The honorable member has had long enough experience of parliamentary practice to know that when a message comes from the Senate, the Government has to do something about it. The Government submitted the motion, and the honorable member for Melbourne then asked me, across the table, whether I intended to proceed with it that night, or grant him the adjournment of thedebate. I told him that I would grant the adjournment of the debate, and hetook the opportunity so presented. Now he says that the Government is attempting to rush this motion through the House without giving him notice of its intention. Of course, it is characteristic of the way in which he has handled the debate.

Honorable members opposite have not observed the ordinary . ethics of debate. The debate upon the resolution to bring the committee into existence was fitting and proper, but honorable members opposite have used this debate as an opportunity to smear, and damn with faint praise, Government nominees. They have sought, for instance, to create disaffection by describing an honorable member as a great man who should have been in Cabinet. They have sought to smear other honorable members by raking up, as did the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) when speaking of thehonorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) anything harmful that they could find. Other members of the committee have been damned with faint praise. That has been the intention of honorable members opposite in thisdebate.

From the business paper one sees that three other statutory committees with nine, ten and nine members respectively have been appointed without resort topersonalities. Honorable members opposite are not prepared, when their supporters are on committees, to display the elephantine humour of the honorable member for Melbourne, or the smears of the honorable member for East Sydney and the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron). The Government's nominees are the chosen of the parties. They were chosen by ballot. There was no arranging of forces, nor were promises given in return for votes within the party. There was nothing like the grouping of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition to ensure their reelection. No one was dumped in the way that the honorable member for East Sydney was dumped so conclusively by his leader. Our nominees were balloted for in a legitimate manner and no doublecrossing took place. One Labour supporter put it rather well when he said (hat voters in the Labour party ballot should have marked their cards with a double-cross.
Mi-. Duthie. - I rise to order. What lias this to do with the motion before the House?

talk.start.para: - It is as near to it as anything that I have heard this morning.

- No one could accuse the honorable member for East Sydney of being wistful, but there was a wistful note in the voice of the honorable member for Melbourne when he realized that in our party a straight vote could be taken and that but for the adoption of less ethical methods, he might not have retained his position as Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Importing those less ethical methods into this debate he has sought to destroy a committee which has rendered valuable service to the people of this country, and which has interested itself in matters of which we, in our insularity of a few years ago, took little notice. Now the House is internationally minded. This is attributable entirely to the work of such committees. In offering the Opposition membership of the committee we are saying to them, " Please come in and instruct your minds on these matters. Even if you have some taint of red we are perfectly certain that acquaintance with the wider sphere of international politics will brain wash you, and that you will come into the fold without any leaning towards the left". Honorable members opposite should consider that, because one section of their party did so. It became very active and played a good part in the conduct of the Foreign

speech.para: Affairs Committee. We know that there are still, on the other side of the House, members who, while rendering lip service to their leader, would not, in their heart of hearts, have a bar of him. Some of them during the last election in Victoria even put themselves forward, not as Evatt candidates, but as Cain candidates in order to show their contempt for their leader. This is the party that now seeks to discredit a committee of this calibre.

I merely wished to put the record straight in regard to the procedure necessary to bring the matter before thi? House, and to draw attention to the unethical approach of honorable member* opposite. There was no need whatever to challenge the membership of the committee because honorable members opposite had already, on another occasion, challenged the principle of its establishment. Having done what I rose to do, and made one or two additional remark? that I think are quite pertinent, I shall resume my seat.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
