talk.start.para: .- I take this opportunity to add my congratulations to those that have been offered to honorable members who have made their maiden speeches. However, one gentleman who supports this Government marred a very fine speech by showing that he intends to adopt the usual reactionary attitude of some Government members, and will try to smear this party as being associates of the Australian Communist party. If the honorable member for Moreton (Mr. Hallen), who made a veiled assertion to that effect, cares to examine the position without bias he will discover that although, admittedly, one Labour supporter was elected to this Parliament on Communist preferences, the same is true of a Liberal member of this chamber and a Liberal member of another place. However, I am not so foolish, bigoted or biased as to state that any of those three gentlemen are associated with the Communist party, or are pro-Communist. Government supporters seem to take advantage of anything of this nature to cast a slur upon members of the Opposition. I am proud to be able to say that I have never been associated with the Communist party and that I have probably fought its members much harder than have Government supporters.

speech.para: It is also interesting to note that of 112,000 votes polled by Mr. Healy, the No. 1 Communist candidate for the Senate in New South Wales, the Liberal senator received 82,000 as against 30,000 for the Labour candidate. I can just imagine the hue and cry that there would have been among Government supporters if the position had been reversed. Our anti- Australian press would have published the news in big headlines. But nothing was said about it in the newspapers, or by Government members, except so far as was necessary to cast veiled aspersions upon respectable members of the Opposition.

During the adjournment debate last night something came up about a certain resolution, which was defeated, concerning the Communist party in Queensland. Does it mean that because a resolution of that kind is defeated, those who vote against it are Communists? Do Government supporters say that more than 50 per cent, of the people - the proportion that voted against the dissolution of the Communist party in the 1951 referendum - are Communists? The aspersions that are cast on honorable members of the party to which I belong are too ridiculous for words. The Labour party is always bitterly opposed to the Communist party, because it is the desire of the Communist party to wreck us. The Communists know that while. Labour has an opportunity to govern, with its policy of full employment and a fair and just deal for the workers, communism is dead. The Communists try to injure the Labour party and to put Liberal and Australian Country party governments in power, because they know that an opportunity might then come their way to gain followers, for it i3 likely that the actions of such governments will result in a depression, poverty and unemployment. That is why the Communist party on various occasions has arranged its preferences at election time, certainly in a veiled manner, so that they will go to supporters of the present Government.

At various times, honorable members opposite have spoken about disunity in the Labour party. Let us examine the position of the Government parties. In New South W'ales last year, a gentleman named Mr. Murray Robson was elected to the leadership of the Liberal party. That, gentleman wanted a coalition with the Country party. Mr. Lyle Moore would not agree with that proposal, and he resigned his position because he did not believe in a coalition with the Country party. Only a few weeks later Mr. Murray Robson was deposed from his position as leader because he had wanted to bring about the coalition. Mr. Lyle Moore finally had his way, and he returned to the position of president of the Liberal party. The result of that dissension is that in three country electorates in New South Wales that are at present represented by Labour members, the Liberal party is opposed to Country party candidates. I refer to the State electorates of Mudgee, Dubbo and Young. I can mention another instance in Victoria, where Mr. Bolte last year became Premier. When Mr. Bolte found that he had enough Liberal supporters, he immediately dumped the Country party and formed a government of his own. We have only to consider the course of events in this Parliament. The Prime Minister, when allotting positions in the

Cabinet, completely overlooked the Australian Country party for what I consider was the first portfolio that should have been given to that party. I refer to the Ministry .of Primary Industry. There is in that position a Liberal, a city-bred man, who has had no experience-

talk.start.para: - He comes from the country.
- He was born there, probably.
- And has lived there most of his life.
- He probably has, and so have most of the Australian Country party members.
- It is a pity that more Opposition members have not.

- At present in New South Wales there is a ministry of sixteen members, seven of whom come from the country. That is an answer to the honorable member's interjection. We on this side of the House believe that there is disunity within the Government parties. That was evidenced during the debate on the Ministers of State Bill, when an attack was made upon the Liberal party section of the Government by a gentleman who sits in the Government corner on this side. Then, one of the honorable gentlemen on the other side of the House - I do not know which electorate he represents - stated that the honorable member who had made the attack was annoyed because he had not been admitted to the Cabinet. Apparently, in this one-man band, if I may use the expression that was used by the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) in speaking about the Labour party's voting procedure, an honorable member must be on side with the Prime Minister before he can make headway in the Government parties. That is quite obvious to every one.
- Well, what follows?

- Something important follows, from my point of view. I take exception to the fact that in the GovernorGeneral's Speech very little was said about housing. It is my opinion that immigration should 1 be entirely curtailed until the Australian people, and the new Australian people within Australia, are housed. I say that for this reason: In the electorate in which I live, and which 1 am honoured to represent, there are many thousands of people without homes. There are many young married people, with two or three children. Recently, a lady approached me to see if I could get her a home. She and her husband are living in one room and they are trying to raise a family. There are scores of thousands of young married couples throughout Australia who are willing to raise families and accept the responsibilities of family life, if they can get homes. I fully appreciate the need to populate our country, but we also have other responsibilities. It is all very well for Ministers, and others, who have their homes, to advocate that we should increase our population, but what sacrifice are they making? The people who are making the sacrifices are the ones who are looking for homes, and I think that something should be done to help them.

speech.para: I asked a question on this matter of the Minister for Immigration yesterday, but, as usual, his answer was completely evasive. I asked him whether this Government can guarantee continuity of employment to the immigrants who are already here, to the Australian people, and to the immigrants who intend to come here. I say that the Government cannot offer such a guarantee, because when the proposed economic sanctions are brought into operation, after the various State elections are over, we will see want and misery even worse than we saw in 1952 and 1953. Honorable members will recall that at that time many hundreds of new Australians marched into the City of Sydney, demanding work, and they rioted in Rawson-place. That is a spectacle which could be seen again, and, in my opinion, we will see it in a worse form.

Honorable members opposite offer no constructive ideas on what should be done about the housing position. Their only suggestion is to divert money from some other source into housing projects. A statement that was made recently by the secretary of the New South Wales Housing Commission, Mr. Bourke, shows the trend in this matter. From last year's allocation of loan money to the New South Wales Government, 4,900 homes were built. but in this year only 3,700 homes can be built. The position will be worsened next year when the effects of increased interest rates for housing loans are felt.

I was appalled to find that in the Governor-General's Speech no reference was made to any intention to restore quarterly wage adjustments to employees working under federal awards. It is most unjust that wages were pegged in 1953 for those employees, and that they are still pegged. They are still pegged, yet we see prices rising week after week and no attempt is being made by this Government to curb that trend in any way. The Menzies-Fadden Administration was elected in 1949 on the false promise that it would put value back into the fi. It had no intention of honouring that promise, and the failure to do so has created the position in which we find ourselves to-day.

We all remember that the late Mr. Ben Chifley told us in 1948 that unless the prices referendum was carried we should have a position that could be likened to that of a dog chasing its tail. I think honorable members on both sides of the House will admit that that prophecy has come true, for to-day the position is just one in which wages are chasing prices all the time.

We also remember that when we had federal prices control in 1948, the living wage was £5 12s. a week. Now, without federal prices control, it is £12 15s. in New South Wales. The present Government stated, in 1948, through the antiAustralian newspapers, that the States could control prices. It is my firm belief that it knew then that the States could not control prices. The Government deceived the people in order to induce them to vote against the referendum, much to the detriment of Australia and the Australian working people.

Finally, I emphasize that honorable members on the Government side should think well before casting aspersions at the members of Her Majesty's Opposition. I advise them to look round the chamber, and to ask themselves whether they are honest, whether they are here as elected representatives of the people. If they do so, I am confident they will not brand decent honorable people as being pro-Communist. The policy of the AntiCommunist Labour party is to try to defeat communism by introducing fascist methods. We of the Australian Labour party believe that the correct way to defeat communism is to have a happy, contented and prosperous nation in which everybody is entitled to work and in which there is a job for every one. We do not believe in introducing one evil in order to get rid of another, but I think that some honorable members on the Government side would be only too willing to introduce fascist methods in order to defeat communism.

talk.start.para: .- I think I heard the honorable member for Watson (Mr. Cope), say that he would like to see our immigration programme slowed down. That is a very short-sighted view because, unless we maintain our inflow of migrants, this country cannot possibly develop or go ahead. I hope to refer to that matter later. Nor should we accept the counsel of despair that so many of our economists are putting forward. I believe those men are living in ivory castles, far removed from realities. They arc dealing with the economic man, the rational man. Some economists seek to tell us what the rational man should do and how he should behave in certain circumstances, but the so-called rational man breathes, eats, sleeps, drinks and gambles. He does not behave in the manner in which the economists believe he should behave. Every man in Australia has great faith in Australia. He believes in Australia, and he is prepared to push ahead and see that it is developed. Australia can, and must, go ahead. It cannot mark time. We cannot halt. We cannot say, " Let us wait for a better opportunity to do these things ". We must go ahead, and for that development, we need two things. We need a large population, and we need capital.

speech.para: Immigrants have played a very great and important part in the development of Australia, especially since the war. They have been largely responsible for maintaining our building programme and our transport services. They have done much for our public utilities. There are over 40 nationalities working on the great Snowy Mountains scheme. There are two further instances of the good that immigrants have done. The sugar industry would have come to a complete standstill within three years if it had not had the help of new Australian labour. Again, half the fruit-pickers of the Commonwealth are new Australians. In the steel industry, they have played a major part. It will be seen from this that the new Australian is helping our export industries greatly. In short, it can be claimed that the new Australian has put more into this country than he has taken out of it. I think we all are in agreement that Australia should maintain a vigorous immigration policy. Although the State Premiers agree on very few things, this is one matter upon which they do agree. Australia needs an increased working force. We have the native-born Australian and the immigrant from whom to draw. Even assuming there are difficulties, and there must be difficulties when we are trying to digest a large number of people coming into the country, it is our duty to provide homes for those people, because we have a duty to increase the population of the country. We are living in a fools' paradise if we shut our eyes to that fact. Most of us will remember the words of William Morris Hughes, which, although spoken over 30 years ago, are just as applicable to-day as they were then. We must all agree with his statement that, " We must populate or perish ".

But the migrants coming into the country to-day are no longer refugees or people without a country. They are people who have opportunities in their own homelands and it would be a great mistake if we slashed our immigration programme, as we did in 1952. We cannot just turn the flow of immigrants on and off as we do a tap. If we did so, it would be hard for us to recover ground. It took almost three years to get back to a normal immigration intake after 1952.

The other thing necessary to our development is the attraction of overseas capital. That cannot be forced into Australia. It must be attracted here. We must have a climate, and political and national opinion which are favorable to
R.-[IB]

the attraction of overseas capital. An excellent example to follow would be Canada, a country that has forged ahead rapidly. Canada has had stable government, perhaps the most stable government since the war. Incidentally, it is of interest to note that it is a Liberal government, and that probably explains a great deal. Secondly, the Canadians have an expansionist attitude of mind. Profitmaking there is popular. It is accepted by practically all sections of the community. It is not the despised and wicked thing the right honorable Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) would like to have us believe here. In Canada, dividends on Canadian securities are free of tax up to 20 per cent, on ordinary and preference shares. The effect of this, first of all, has been to make the Canadian capitalminded. He has been given faith in the future and in the development of his country, and the right climate of opinion for overseas investment has been produced. The result has been to give Canada a tremendous impetus, and a healthy economy that is plain for all to see. This has made Canada the envy of the world, and has caused a huge inflow of overseas capital, particularly from the United States of America. We all know that, in the United Kingdom and the United States, there are large funds that could be invested in Australia. Although a certain amount of overseas capital has been invested here, we need more to keep pace with the rate of development that we have undertaken. We cannot compel Britain and America to invest in Australia. It is our responsibility to create and maintain an attractive field of investment. We must have some form of special incentive to attract British and American money here. In short, Mr. Speaker, we must have in Australia a climate of opinion very encouraging to the investment of overseas capital. By this means we shall bc able to attract overseas money and harness it to its proper use of developing our great country.

I wish now to speak about the part being played by the Australian Government in the field of television. As you, sir, know, £305,000 of the taxpayers' money has already been spent on television in the current financial year out of die amount voted in- the Estimates. The ultimate expenditure this financial year might even he £2,017,000. According to announcements made recently in the press and elsewhere, the expenditure already made is quite inadequate, and honorable members may be sure that it will be exceeded. Let us just consider our precious import licences, which the Government is trying to curtail. Up to the present time, for television alone, the national broadcasting stations have obtained licences to import from dollar and sterling areas goods to a total value of £720,000. and commercial stations have obtained licences for goods worth a total of £1,580,000. The money to pay for these goods comes out of the pool of overseas funds that we are trying to conserve. In addition, television will involve constant spending abroad on technical matters, programmes, films and artists. This government expenditure on .television comes at a time when we should be restricting our imports, watching our expenditure, and carefully pruning government spending, as we have done in many departments.

As all honorable members know, at the present time, the prices of our primary exports are falling, our own costs of production are rising, and we are having real difficulty in selling many commodities such as wheat, dried and tinned fruits, wine, eggs and butter. Also, the imports that we are obtaining from abroad are becoming increasingly dear. In these circumstances, every non-essential import should be carefully considered, and a proper system of priorities should be introduced. The Government is not undertaking this. Although it urges us to produce more, farmers are allowed to

SO short of many items of essential equipment. I mention only a few such as wire netting, galvanized iron, machinery and rotary hoes for small farmers. These things cannot be imported in sufficient quantity because we have not enough sterling and dollar currency available, although, apparently, there are unlimited sterling and dollar funds available for television. "What will be the use of television to the man on the land for the next five or even ten years? He will be digging into his pocket to help pay for Commonwealth expenditure on television, but will not b* able to enjoy television himself. Hp will, receive no benefit from that expenditure. He will get only a reduced flow of imports of the goods he needs, and the extremely doubtful pleasure of paying higher taxes. We must ask ourselves whether television is really essential. The popular answer seems to be that it must be essential, because first-class nations have it. I do not think we can accept that as an argument for the immediate introduction of television in Australia. However wo look at it, television is a luxury for a few, because it will attract labour, capital and materials from essential industries. We are already able to see the effect of th? impending introduction of television on the work of the Postmaster-General's Department in country areas. The department is not replacing maintenance and mechanical workers as they leave its service. It says that this is not retrenchment, but the result is that the number of men working on the installation and maintenance of telephone services is shrinking. The department will not pay overtime for certain work and therefore employees leave and go where overtime is obtainable. Although telephone services in country areas generally are reasonable, they are by no means worthy of boasting or pride. Yet we tell the man in the country, "You will pay for television to be enjoyed in the city where you will not see it, but you cannot obtain a new telephone service or have your existing service improved " !

What will be the effect of television om the national economy? As I have said, it is a luxury and the effect of luxuries is always inflationary. Television will greatly increase the demand for hirepurchase finance. I understand that television receivers are selling in Britain for £100. We can only guess what they will cost in Australia. It may be anything up to £200. We cry that we want more people on the land, but we are encouraging a lop-sided, luxury, milk-bar economy. We are giving people more incentive to remain in the cities, and less encouragement to live in the country. Perhaps we are too heavily committed on television to turn back, but I ask the

Government to leave it to private enterprise to take the risk of introducing it. Private enterprise can judge the risks, and, if it is prepared to go ahead, well and good ; it will have the responsibility. If the Government allows the Australian Broadcasting Commission - a highly efficient organization - to go ahead at full steam and put a great deal of public money into television, it will force private enterprise to enter the field perhaps much earlier than it wishes. The Government should hasten slowly in this matter. Admittedly, it must control the quality and quantity of television programmes. However, it could well leave it to private enterprise to proceed with television, as it did with radio broadcasting. Private enterprise knows the economic risks and what the people want. As I have said, the Government must control both the quality and quantity of programmes, but it should withdraw from the field otherwise, and, if necessary, enter it very slowly at a much later time.
Mr.GRIFFITHS (Shortland) [12.24J. - The electoral commissioners badly mauled the Shortland electorate in the recent redistribution of electoral boundaries.

talk.start.para: - The boundaries were extended.

- The size of the electorate was more than trebled. No doubt, this was done to make secure the seats of Liberal members such as my friend the honorable member for Robertson (Mr. Dean) and others, at my expense. In the redistribution, 27,000 electors were removed from my electorate, and .some 25,000 were added to it from other divisions. I wish to convey my thanks to both the old and the new electors of Shortland for the confidence they have reposed in me by electing me again as the representative of Shortland in this House. I desire also to join with previous speakers in extending congratulations to the new members of the House on the excellence of their maiden speeches, which reflected credit on themselves ann augur well for their future. Other contributions which were worthy noting and commenting upon were made by the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth), the right honorable mem ber for Cowper (Sir Earle Page,,,ih, honorable member for Blaxland (Mr. E. James Harrison) and the honorable member for Robertson. The honorable member for Robertson referred to the recent waterfront dispute and he challenged honorable members to say where they stood in relation to it. I have been consistently opposed to strike action by members of industrial organizatons, except as a last resort. So far as 1 am aware, union members are the only ones who suffer grievously as a result of direct action. At all times there should be more conciliation and possibly les? arbitration on matters in dispute. Had there been more conciliation in the case of the waterside workers, whose case had been before the court on eight or nine occasions, and who had not had an increase in their marginal rates since ] 948, the trouble on the waterfront might have been avoided. For years the shipowners knew that trouble was brewing. Long before application was made for a 10 per cent, increase in rates, they knew that the men were dissatisfied with their margins. After the tally clerks and casual storemen and packers had received increases of 9d. and 8£d. an hour, respectively, in their marginal rates, and the watersiders' application had not been proceeded with, the shipowners knew that a strike was imminent.

speech.para: They have known for years that the working conditions on Australian wharf? are so bad and primitive that wharf labourers have only been awaiting an opportunity to voice their protests against lack of facilities and amenities. The strike was of some value, even though the greatest losers were the men themselves. The handling of the dispute by the executive of the Australian Council of Trades Unions and its somersault decision did grave harm to the organized industrial Labour movement. If, in the opinion of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, the strike was justified in the first place, it was still justified when the returntowork order was given. The leaders of the Australian Council of Trades Unions knew full well that the conditions governing the back-to-work order did not include any guarantee that the men would receive an increase greater than the 6d. an hour which had been promised by the owners, and that there was no undertaking that the rotten conditions of employment in many ports would he improved. The leaders of the Australian Council of Trades Unions knew that the shipowners' promise of an increase of 6d. an hour, with a guaranteed fortnightly payment of £20, was loaded, and the Australian Council of Trades Unions deserves the censure of the industrial movement for its handling of the dispute. Does any honorable member believe that the guarantee of £20 a fortnight was given out of the shipowners' goodness of heart? The catch was that, the guarantee was on a basis of a fortnight's employment. If no work was offering in the first week of a pay period, and in the second week there was full time and overtime, no guarantee applied in relation to the first week's work that was lost. That meant that the men had to be on call all the time. They had to be ready, turn out from their homes, and attend for four hours each day in order to be available if work was offering. At the present high rate of wages they would receive more than £20 in a fortnight if ample work was available, but in order to receive the guaranteed £20 they would sometimes have to work full time and overtime in the second week of the pay period. Their families would be expected to live on £20 or £22 a fortnight, knowing full well that had the men worked full time, or had the guarantee been given for the first week, they would have received more than £30.

I have said previously in this House that the facilities and conditions of employment at many wharfs are so bad that it is impossible for waterside workers to do a better job than they are doing. In 1952, following a dispute at Newcastle, the Government sent Mr. Kelly, an officer of the Prime Minister's Department, to inquire into conditions at that port. He found that conditions were the most primitive in the Commonwealth and he made a scathing report to his senior officers. To-day, those conditions remain unchanged. Iron-wheeled hand trucks are being pulled by men over roughly timbered wharfs at a cost of strained muscles and backs. These fourwheeled vehicles are 20 or 30 years old, and the wheels have flat sections which cause jolting every time the wheel turns. Only within the last couple of weeks I inspected conditions in the great storage sheds at Newcastle. The floors have sunk, the concrete has broken, there are no cranes to assist in the storage of wool and other merchandise over the height of S or 10 feet which men can reach with the aid of fork lifts. This means that these stores are repeatedly only half full of merchandise waiting to be loaded. The worst feature of ship loading is the loss of time caused by the shipowners' refusal to have cargo stored at the wharfs in order to take advantage of the available labour at all times. I understand that in some cases wool will not be removed from the wool stores to the wharf unless it is paid for on the spot after the sales, and, as a result, watersiders are kept waiting for work, and loading is delayed. Some owners do not like paying penalty rates. Others have no organizing ability and time and again they do not call for labour while ships lie idle at the wharf.

I should like to quote a couple of instances of delays that have taken place, but I assure honorable members that, throughout the year, there are hundreds of such occasions, and dozens of ships are delayed in port because of the inaction of owners and their failure to organize efficiently and so facilitate the turn-round of ships. I have particulars of cases in respect of dozens of ships where many hours have been lost through waiting for cargo, because of the inability of owners to organize proper working. First I refer to the case of the vessel Dong Hae. Work on this vessel commenced at 8 a.m. on the 14th May, 1955. Only twenty men were selected for the 8 a.m. shift, although the ship was capable of working 102 men at this stage. The agents selected another 58 men at 1 p.m. Their stated reason for not picking up the full complement of men was that they could not obtain sufficient fork lifts to keep two hatches working. As there was labour available on this day and all requirements could have been supplied, 504 man-hours were lost through the inability of employers to supply mechanical equipment. On the 5 p.m. shift, no labour was called for, but labour would have been available, if required. In that instance, 576 manhours were lost. On the 6th May, the vessel picked up 96 men for an 8 a.m. start. It did not requisition labour for the 5 p.m. shift, although plenty of labour was available. So 576 man-hours were lost to the vessel on that day. On Saturday, the 7th May, the vessel did not apply for labour, although plenty of labour was available. On that day 376 man-hours were lost to the vessel. On Sunday, the 8th May, the vessel again did not apply for labour. On the 9th May, 94 men were picked up for an S a.m. start. That was an overtime night, and the vessel could have worked labour until 9 p.m. There were slight showers during the day, and the agents dismissed the men at 2 p.m., although other ships in the port worked until 9 p.m On that day, 564 man-hours were lost to the vessel and the port. On the 10th May, 94 men were picked up for an 8 a.m. start. The weather was showery again, and the agents dismissed the men at 2.30 p.m., although the vessels Rhexenor and Tulane, in adjacent berths, worked until 9 p.m. As other vessels in adjacent berths worked during that afternoon, it was possible for the owners of this vessel also to use men to discharge its cargo during the afternoon.

This sort of thing went on during the fourteen days that the ship was in port. In that time, the owners caused a loss to the ship and the port of at least 3,083 man-hours. In addition, there was a further loss of 1,360 man-hours, caused by the failure of the owners to apply for night labour when it was available. The imposing total of 4,445 man-hours was lost on the working of this vessel. That means that the vessel was in port, taking up valuable berthing space and labour, for approximately 40 per cent, longer than was necessary. Perhaps I should mention that when SS. Sierra arrived in the port of Newcastle to unload cargo, it was unable to do so because SS. Dong Hae was still unloading cargo. So SS. Sierra had to by-pass Newcastle, go on to Brisbane and then come back to Newcastle to discharge its cargo.

item.label: MV.
item.para: Enfieldis another case in point. On the morning of the 18th May, 25 men were picked up for that vessel, but at that time it had not even left Sydney. It did not arrive in Newcastle until the 19th May. Due to faulty liaison between employers, the engagement of the men was not cancelled until after 9 a.m., when it was too late to use their labour again that day. A total of 200 man hours was lost to the port in that instance. I could cite dozens of cases of the faulty working of ships in the port of Newcastle. But what worries me most is that, in these days of mechanization, there are not to be found on the wharfs of the port of Newcastle cranes of a type - indeed, cranes of any type - that could lift cargo from the wharfs and from the holds of ships. It is true that Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited has such cranes on its wharfs, but on the wharfs operated by the Maritime Services Board facilities for the quick handling of cargo are not available.

talk.start.para: - What is the State Government doing about it?

- This is not a question of what the State Government is doing. It is a question of the cause of the slow turn-round of ships generally. I submit that these are matters requiring investigation, not only by the State, but also by the Commonwealth. The Kelly report, published in 1952, showed clearly what was happening then. It is still happening, because no improvements have been effected in the port of Newcastle since that inquiry was made. On the wharfs there are large sheds that possibly could hold all merchandise unloaded from ships and waiting to be loaded into them, but the sheds are only half-filled all the time, because there are no facilities in the sheds for stowing or storing the merchandise in such a way as to assist the quicker- turn-round of ships. There arc no amenities on the wharfs which would make for better working conditions and, therefore, a better understanding between the employers and the employees.

speech.para: The honorable member for Blaxland referred to the black market in finance, especially in New South Wales. Owing to the lack of finance provided by the War Service Homes Division, ex-servicemen are forced to resort to the black market in order !.:> obtain temporary finance for the purchase of homes. Recently, a gentleman wrote a letter to me in which he said -

quote.para: I have a loan of £2,000 approved by War Service Homes, but on advice it is doubtful whether finance will be available this year from them. I am a returned serviceman, married, with six children. I have already paid a deposit of £800 on a home and am living in it, paying rent, but now the vendor is pushing me for settlement and threatens to cancel the sale and make me forfeit my deposit.

War Service Homes advises me to obtain temporary finance. Well, I have approached the Bank of New South Wales, the Commonwealth Trading Bank, the Commercial Bank of Australia, Rural Bank building societies and some private persons, offering to pay high rental and big interest, but so far have not been able to get any offers at all, not even to the extent of £1,500.

speech.para: I submitted that letter to the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton). I have nothing to growl about in relation to the contents of the letter which the Minister wrote to me in reply. But it seems strange to me that a man who served his country in war, a man with six children who has paid £800 deposit on a home, is faced with the prospect of losing that deposit money and of being thrown out of his home by an unscrupulous owner because no finance is available to him from the War Service Homes Division. On the 27th February, the Minister wrote a letter to me in which he said that my correspondent had entered into a contract to purchase a home and that it would appear that, at that time, he expected to be in a position to obtain finance from some source other than the War Service Homes Division. My correspondent approached all the recognized financial institutions, but they refused to lend him even £1,500, although he was prepared to pay a rate of interest higher than the general rate. Therefore, it seems to me that those institutions and the War Service Homes Division are forcing men to raise loans on the black market, probably at rates of interest between 12 per cent, and 20 per cent. The Minister, in his letter, stated also - lt is noted from the correspondence that

Mr.- haspaid a deposit of £800 and that the vendor is pressing for settlement. Unfortunately, the contract of sale into which he has entered does not protect him against forfeiture of the deposit if the vendor presses his claim.
The Minister admitted that the man might forfeit his deposit; -

quote.para: This position has been brought about by the action of your correspondent himself in committing himself to the purchase of the home prior to submitting an application under the Act. Had he done this prior to paying the deposit of £800, the division would have been able to advise him of the action to take in order to protect hie interests in the matter.

speech.para: I regret to say that, in many instances, the division alters its policy quickly and often. On the 6th September, 1955, the War Service Homes Division warned an applicant for finance not to seek temporary finance elsewhere, although it had advised him that he would have to effect repairs to the house at a cost of £300 or £400 before money could be made available to him. Then, on the 28th September, 1955, the division told the applicant, to obtain' temporary finance in order to complete the transaction. In the first case that I mentioned, the Minister said that he regretted that it was not possible for the division to deal with the application in this financial year, but that all possible steps would be taken to complete it in 1956-57. Unfortunately, the Minister did not specify the date in 1956-57 when the money would be made available to the applicant for the completion of the transaction. I ask the Minister to consider this correspondence again with a view to fixing a firm date upon which the finance will be available so that my constituent will not forfeit his £800 deposit, and so that negotiations may be entered into with the vendor. Mr. Speaker, I suggest that this is a convenient time at which to suspend the sitting.

- Very well, I shall conclude my remarks at this stage, because to continue would be of no use.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to deal with the amendment moved by the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard). I think it is fairly obvious to all that this amendment stems from the philosophy of socialism and, as it has been moved by the honorable member for Lalor, whose adherence to the philosophies of socialism is well known, I would say that the amendment is not entirely surprising but, indeed, is understandable. But there are other aspects of the matter which are not quite so clear. One of them is the claim which has been made on a number of occasions by members of the Opposition during this debate that in some way the Western Australian Government was in ignorance of the proposed sale of the whaling station at Carnarvon, in Western Australia. I think it should be clearly stated to the House, and particularly to the people of Western Australia, that this proposal was previously raised publicly on many occasions over a number of years. It was raised in this House on many occasions. [ can recall occasions when it was raised by members of the Opposition. I can remember having raised the matter myself, since I have been a member of the Parliament. First, it is a matter that has been ventilated publicly through the normal processes of the Parliament; secondly, the files of the Premier's Department of Western Australia must contain considerable correspondence relating to the matter, and the Western Australian Government should have had no difficulty in referring to such correspondence. I am sure that the exact contents of that file would be within the knowledge of the present Western Australian Government. There should also be in the mind of the Western Australian Premier himself some definite understanding of the situation, arising from correspondence in that file, concerning offers which wore made in the past by the Commonwealth to the Western Australian Government in relation to the sale of the whaling station. The fact that this matter was open to the public view long ago is confirmed by a press statement which was issued by the then Minister for Commerce and Agriculture, who is the present Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) in this Government. The honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hamilton) has already referred to this press statement, as have several other honorable members, during this debate, but I think that, for the purposes of the records, I ought to quote some brief extracts from it, and also to ensure that the position is generally understood. I have here a copy of a press report of that statement made by the then Minister for Commerce and Agriculture on the 6th November, 1952. It reads -

quote.para: Questioned to-day, Mr. McEwen said the Commonwealth Government was considering selling its million pound Western Australian whaling enterprise.
He said the Commonwealth Government was close to a decision " in its discussions with the Western Australian Government on the future of the enterprise.
The Government believed it should fill no function as an operating producer or trader in the whaling or any other industry.

The Government believed that the Commonwealth Whaling Commission was established by the Chifley Labour Government to demonstrate the opportunities in Western Australia for modern, adequately capitalized, wellequipped whaling enterprise.

The Commission had operated through two full seasons and fulfilled this aim very satisfactorily. "For the future the Commission can only be regarded as a production activity which is not our concept of the normal function of Government", said Mr. McEwen. "In accordance with the general political philosophies of this Government, I have assumed that the Government will not want to go on indefinitely with whaling as a purely productive enterprise. " But this enterprise has been of such great importance, actual and potential, to Western Australia thatI have been in consultation with the Government of Western Australia to ascertain its views on the future of the Commonwealth whaling station. " There has been an exchange of views which is notyet complete. If the Government had to get out of whaling it would not wish its station in Western Australia to discontinue operations, which were of great benefit to Western Australia and to Australia's overseas earnings. " The Government would want the station to continue in efficient operation. It would not want the station to pass into the hands of overseas interests, if there were Australian interests adequately capitalized and sufficiently well -equipped to run the station

speech.para: The Minister concluded his statement by saying that he was unable to say when the Government would make a final decision to sell the enterprise, or to offer it for sale, but he added that no private concern at that time had yet made an offer for the enterprise. He added also that it was understood that the Western Australian government of the day wanted the whaling station to continue in operation, preferably in the hands of Western Australian private operators. For the sake of the records I think that those facts should be reiterated, because they definitely indicate that the Western Australian government of the day was clearly in possession of information about the Australian Government's desire to sell the whaling station and had, indeed, conducted negotiations regarding the matter. These facts, of course, would have been within the knowledge of the members of the Western Australian Parliament at the time, and the present Western Australian Government, being then in opposition, must also have had that knowledge at that time. Naturally, when it took over the reins of office, the present Western Australian Government would have immediate and free access to the files containing all the correspondence relating to the negotiations that occurred.

I think it has been proved conclusively that the members of the present Government of Western Australia were, either when they were in opposition, or later when they took office, in possession of the details connected with the Australian Government's desire to dispose of the whaling station, and one might gather, from the recent statements to the contrary, that the Western Australian Government has denied knowledge of the situation for purely political purposes. It is quite open, as the Minister for Trade has already said, for the Western Australian Government to submit an offer for the station within the next fourteen days. As the House has already been told, the financial year of the Australian Whaling Commission terminates at the end of this month, and it has been decided to give the Western Australian Government the opportunity to make an offer to buy the station up to the loth March, should it wish to do so. I think every one will agree, therefore, that 'the Western Australian Government has been given an opportunity to submit an offer, and that it is well within its capacity to do so if it has any real intention of taking over the station. I feel, and I believe a number of people in this House suspect, that there may not be any real intention on the part of the Western Australian Government at the present time to proceed with any such action. As honorable members know, there is to be a general election in Western Australia within a very short time, and I very much fear that the claim of lack of prior knowledge by the Western Australian Government about the sale of the whaling station is another case of a particular issue being used for purely political purposes.

Many other matters concerning thu Australian whaling industry have been raised during this debate. Some of the statements made have been entirely erroneous, and I feel it my duty, having been associated with the Department of Commerce and Agriculture as Parliamentary Under-secretary to the Minister, and now being associated in the same capacity with the Department of Trade and the Department of Primary Industry, thai 1 should say something in- regard to the background of the Australian whaling industry, in order to correct some of the statements that have been made, and to bring the true position to the knowledge of people who, in ignorance of it, may believe those misstatements.

The first important consideration that, one must consider in relation to the whaling industry anywhere is the conservation of whale stocks. In relation to this matter, Australia is represented on the International Whaling Commission, and the commission acts on the advice of the scientific sub-committee which has been established and regularly introduces special conservation measures that are recommended throughout the world for the conservation of whale stocks at all times.

Australia is also a member of the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling and, indeed, plays an important part in the meetings and functions of that convention. I might mention at this stage that the Director of Fisheries, Mr. Anderson, who is a member of the Department of Primary Industry at present and who is the Australian representative on the commission and at the convention, has played a particularly important and active part in representing the interests of the Australian whaling industry. He has established for Australia a good reputation among the other countries that are interested in negotiations < concerning the conservation of whale sto:ks throughout the world. Australian scientists have also played an important part, from the scientific point of view, in important aspects of biological work dealing with the humpback whale, and their contributions have been recognized by other countries. Australia has built up a high reputation in that regard as we'll as a reputation within the commission itself.

Quotas are imposed by the Australian Government on Australian shore-based stations for whaling and they are based on the following premises: - First, on data from the operations of similar stations in other countries; secondly, on rs ti ma tes which are worked out by Australian, advisers on the number of whales which can be safely taken from the main streams without seriously depleting the whale stocks; thirdly, on a study of the scientific data available on reproduction of whales; and fourthly, on the seasonal data that is available from whaling operators within the industry in Australia itself. Australian quotas are based on all that information and all those figures.

I was interested to hear a remark made by the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns) indicating that the International Whaling Commission was controlling the quotas in Australian waters. I should like to emphasize for the information of the House that that is not so. The quotas that are established for Australian waters are purely voluntary and are based on the information that I have just mentioned. The International Whaling Commission in no way has any voice in the estimation of those quotas or in the enforcement of the quotas.

However, I should like to follow up the reference to conservation by indicating to the House the quotas which have been fi 'located during the past season, because 1 think it is quite important and quite pertinent to the present debate. The information that I have indicates the principal whaling operators that are functioning in Australia and the quotas that have been allocated to them. On the east coast, there are two operators. One of them is Whale Industries Limited, of Tangalooma, Queensland. The quotas for the coming season have yet to be announced, but the quota for this firm in respect of last season was 600. The other operator on the east coast is the Byron Whaling Company, of Byron Bay, New South Wales, which has a quota of 120. So the total quota for the east coast of Australia is 720. Several undertakings operate in the West Stream, which is off the coast of Western Australia. The Cheynes Beach Whaling Company, of Albany, had a quota last season of 120. The Australian Whaling Commission's station, which is situated at Carnarvon and which is, of course, the subject of the present debate, had a quota of 500. The Nor-West Whaling Company, of Point Cloates, had a quota also of 500. So the total quota for the west, coast of Australia last season was 1,120. This figure refers, of course, to hump-back whales only. A provisional quota of 150 for the coming season has been worked out for the Norfolk Whaling Company, of Norfolk Island. So the total quota allocated to all operators in Australian waters is 1,990. That figure has been based on information obtained by the Department of Primary Industry through its Fisheries Division.

Prior to last season, the quotas allocated to the Australian Whaling Commission and the Nor- West Whaling Company had been 600, but during last season the quota was reduced from 600 to 500 for conservation purposes. I mention that in order to indicate the fact that conservation is being studied and is being practised in Australian waters. I think that is recognized by other countries which have quite a lot of faith in the methods that are adopted here and the way in which we practise our principles.

There is no restriction as to the number of whales of each sex which may bc caught, although it is illegal to take a female whale when accompanied by a calf. That question has arisen during this debate, so I think that I should clarify that point. Reference was also made to the size of whales and I think that, for the information of the House,

I should quote the minimum size of whales that can be taken in Australian waters. The minimum length of blue whales which may be taken is 70 feet; of fin whales, 55 feet; of humpback whales, 35 feet; of sei whales, 40 feet; and of sperm whales, 35 feet.

The control of the Australian whaling industry is exercised under the Australian Whaling Act 1935-1948. Certain conditions operate under this act under which whaling operators can obtain a licence to operate and, also, a licence to operate their catcher-vessel. There is a payment of £200 for the licence to operate, and of £50 for the licence for a catcher-vessel. The act also lays down that an inspector will be stationed at every whaling station that is operating around the Australian coast - that is, at each shore-based station. The inspectors who come under the Inspection Division and who are associated with the Fisheries Division carry out the task of seeing that the provisions of the act are adhered to by operators in Australian waters.

It might be said that these controls and restrictions on the industry appear to be rather irksome, but the conditions and results indicate that the restrictions on the industry' in Australia are warranted very much indeed. The lessons that we have before us of the depletion of blue whale stocks in Antarctic regions in the pre-war years, and in the immediate postwar years, indicate what can happen in the industry if we do not control it. At the present time, in the Antarctic regions, the heavy exploitation of the fin whale which is taking place should be a lesson to us. There are indications that unless there is a drop in the world price of whale oil there will be, during the nexttwelve months, a great depletion of the stocks of fin whales in the Antarctic. These are indeed lessons that we should learn in the conduct of our own industry around the shores of Australia. The Government intends to maintain control of the industry on this basis and to ensure that quotas are equitable and are observed. The preservation of our stocks of hump-back whales on the Australian coast will ensure the maintenance of a profitable industry for the future. There is no restriction on the number of sperm whales that may be taken, but restrictions are, in effect, applied by the fact that there is a much smaller market.

speech.para: I wish to recall the fight of the workers, in my day, to establish arbitration courts. Working conditions then are unbelievable to any one who did not experience them. In railway and other construction camps in the far north of Queensland, and ou the black soil plains, men received 6s. a day, had no amenities, and had to supply and carry their tents and blankets from job to job. Their conditions were comparable with those of coolies in many Eastern countries to-day. They had little or no opportunity to have a family, let alone a home. If they had families they could not bring them up in the civilized conditions to which they were entitled. Miners worked under the most primitive conditions thousands of feet below the ground. The winning of gold and other metals was then considered more important than the safety of the miners. Silicosis was so rampant that few men engaged in the mining industry lived beyond the age of 50 years. At one period the average age of the women at Charters Towers, one of the leading goldmining towns of Australia, exceeded that of the men by ten years. This was the result of the ravages of this dreaded industrial disease. It must be remembered that these conditions existed under tory governments.

The men decided to work for the creation of an arbitration court. They visualized that it would be a point of contact between the employers and employees, and that this would ensure that they got reasonable conditions and sufficient pay to maintain themselves and their families in comfort. The first arbitration act in Queensland was passed by a tory government. However, the act was soon seen to consist mainly of penalties for breaches of awards. It provided that only a man who worked in an industry could represent the employees; but the employers could send along any one whom they wished, and so could employ legal advocates. The owners selected one of their managers, and a legal adviser, to appear for them. I was selected by the miners to represent them and was successful in obtaining a small concession in wages and conditions. However, though penalties could be imposed on the employees for breaches of awards, none could be imposed on employers.

My main contention during this debate will be that under the present arbitration system penalties are imposed on workers and not on employers. We all live by the production, purchase, and sale of commodities. The worker has but one commodity to sell, his labour. The employers have never attempted conciliation but have used all the money and legal assistance at their disposal to fight improvements of working conditions. The worker is subject to penalties when he asks for a better price for his labour, but the business man who asks for a better price for his product is not penalized. The position is entirely unrealistic.

Recently agents handling razor blades were told that the price would go up by 4d. a packet. There was no question of resorting to arbitration and, consequently, no question of penalties, although the people will have to bear the price increase which in the aggregate will cost them thousands of pounds. If the workers seek even a small increase of pay they must go to an. arbitration court and become liable to penalties if they do not follow its rules and regulations. The Courier Mail in Brisbane has just sent word around to its agents that the price of that paper is now to be one penny more. Thus the management will collect thousands of pounds more from the readers without going to an arbitration court, and becoming liable to penalties if it does not follow a certain procedure. The two examples of price increases that I have given may seem minor, but in the aggregate they yield hundreds of thousands of pounds. We have the outstanding case of the ship ina companies imposing an additional 10 per cent, freight charge. That charge will cost the primary producers of Australia millions of pounds. But again there is no question of arbitration. They did not have to go to arbitration; they imposed that charge without reference to any one. All the charges I have mentioned have been imposed without reference to arbitration, and, consequently, without any question of penalties.

There is also the outstanding case of General Motors-Holden's Limited. Two years ago the profits of that company amounted to £7,000,000. Last year its profits were as high as £10,000,000. On the capital outlay of the company it was obvious that it had charged an entirely unfair and unjust price for its cars. But did it apply to an arbitration court? Have we any machinery to deal with these people? No! Neither, of course, can any penalties be imposed upon them. I have cited four cases illustrating the fact that private companies and business people can impose taxes on the people who use and consume their products. No one can deny that that is so. I maintain that we shall never have industrial peace and additional production unless these matters are dealt with.

Let us look at the other side of the picture. The employers applied to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration for a reduction of wages and an increase in hours. The judge who sat on the case in his wisdom pegged the wages, but he did not peg the prices of the commodities that a worker must buy to keep his wife and family. We have the astonishing position of a judge, who no doubt thinks he is very just and is doing the right thing, pegging the wages of workers, while at the same time the people who sell their products to the workers are allowed to charge what they like. I have given the House three or four instances, but, of course, I could mention many more. It must be obvious to all honorable members, irrespective of party affiliations, that these things cannot go on. We cannot allow one section of the community to be exploited, while allowing another section full freedom to do the exploiting.

Recently, the court viciously slashed the wages of shearers, and the shearers are refusing to shear for the new wage rates. The representative of the Graziers Association has threatened to take action - although I do not know whether he will do so - and he has stated that each man who refuses to shear is liable to a penalty of £100.

talk.start.para: - That is under Labour's arbitration legislation in Queensland.

- I do not care who introduced the legislation, it is wrong. But that is the position. Workers may be fined up to £100 each for refusing to accept an unsatisfactory award. What I want to stress is that penalties may be imposed upon workers, but that they cannot be imposed upon businessmen. The businessman can sell his commodity for whatever he likes, without fear of penalty, but the worker has no such freedom in selling, his labour, which is the only commodity he has to sell.

speech.para: Just before I came to this House this afternoon I heard a wireless report that the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association has been fined £700. I did not have time to ascertain what breach had been committed or what was the reason for the fine. I mention the report merely as an illustration of a very subtle method of taking the funds that a union has provided to defend its cases. Employers are subject to no penalties, and they can filch legally from the workers the funds that they have subscribed to defend themselves from attacks on their wages and conditions. This is a very subtle method, but, believe me, the people are beginning to wake up to these methods of robbing them that are being used now and have been used in the past.

I can mention to the House the case of a union the members of which had not been on strike for 25 years. It had had a case pending before the Arbitration Court for a couple of years. In all that time the case had not been dealt with, and the members of the union went on strike. The members of that particular union have to study for six years to acquire the necessary skill and knowledge to do their jobs. They have to devote as much time to study as does a lawyer or a doctor - excluding, of course, the specialists. When those employees went on strike, the employers themselves said that they were entitled to increases in wages. When the workers had previously applied for an increase in wages the employers went into the court and advanced such convincing arguments against an increase in wages that the Arbitration Court refused any increase. Therefore, we have the position of the employers admitting that they had wrongfully gone into the court to resist the application of this union. There is no question about these facts ; they were all published in the newspapers. The employers have their organization built up, and they said that, as a matter of principle, they go into the court to fight all applications for improvements in conditions or increases in wages.

The Waterside Workers Federation of Australia applied for increased wages for its members, and its representatives were told that the men would be granted a fraction of the amount for which they had applied, but that they must forfeit conditions of work that they had enjoyed for years. What do the employers think the workers are? What do they think the people of Australia are? They said, " We will grant a fraction of what you ask, but we must take from you conditions that you have enjoyed for years ". It is like some one who offers a child a lolly, providing that the child gives up the lolly he already has. Yet we have judges sitting in the courts and giving judgments such as that. It is quite childish. In the past, when the workers had not the benefits of education that they have to-day, these things could be put over and were put over them. It is a different world to-day. How anyone can believe that it is reasonable to offer people a fraction of what they have asked for, provided they give up something that they have enjoyed for many years, passes my understanding!

It is amazing to me that businessmen, politicians and the public generally do not realize that our arbitration system permits of the imposition of penalties upon one section of the community while at the same time allowing complete freedom to the other section. That position cannot continue. Unless we can set up courts with authority to check excess profit-making by' companies, the whole system of arbitration will collapse, because we cannot continue with a system which allows one person to charge what he likes for his commodity and which at the same time restricts the amount to be paid to another person for buying these commodities.

In the old days when we were fighting hard for the establishment of an arbitration court, we were striving for a system that would give us a point of contact as between employers and employees. We imagined in those days that the employers would be humane enough to appreciate the position of the workers. We visualized a System that would enable us to settle differences by conciliation so far- as that was possible and finally to take unsettled matters before an impartial court. We <lid not imagine that there should be any rule under which penalties could be inflicted upon workers while the employers concerned remained immune. Undoubtedly, we achieved a good deal under the arbitration system, but honorable members will realize that conditions in those days were so bad that it was quite easy to achieve some improvement for the workers. There was room then for a great deal of improvement, and there is still room for improvement.

I suppose the Labour party is at fault to some degree, in not having its own press these days. Time after time, we find that when there is an industrial dispute, the press publishes entirely false statements of the position as between employer and employee and often by so doing creates greater friction than if it published nothing at all. I know that many people look upon waterside workers, and in some instances coal-miners, as some strange beings who do not belong to the human race. I know both branches of workmen. They are all good citizens and all good characters. They take part in the social and sporting life of the town or area in which they live. After the recent floods at Goondiwindi, when primary producers were suffering desperate hardships, 300 waterside workers took their own canteens and food out there and worked free of charge to help those men clean up the mud and slush that had. been left by the turbulent waters. Are not such men entitled to a fair deal? Are they not men whom we can all respect? Of course, they are I

I am greatly concerned about this question, because Australia needs rehabilitating. We hear much talk about all the prosperity in the world, but things really are not the best. If we are to rehabilitate this country, we must have production. If we are to get that production, there must be satisfaction amongst the workers.
