speech.para: Mi.FALKINDER (Franklin) [3.1].- First of all, may I join with those who have congratulated the new members of this Parliament upon their maiden speeches? I think it is fair to say that the present standard of debate is at least as high as I have known it at 'any time during my period in this Parliament, and I believe it augers very well indeed foi- the future debate of this new Parliament.

The Address-in-Reply debate gives honorable members an opportunity - perhaps an all too infrequent one - to discuss almost any subject they may wish. In the opening paragraphs of the Governor-General's Speech, reference is made to the relationship between this House and the Senate. I want to devote my remarks to the relationship between the efficacy and workability of this Parliament, and the private member. I believe that the time has come, indeed that it is more than overdue, when we need to have another look at the tendency steadily but surely to decrease the privileges and rights of private members. In his last speech in this Parliament, the former honorable member for Henty, Mr. Gullett, made a very interesting and quite brilliant contribution on this very point. Last week, the honorable member for Farrer (Mr. Fairbairn) also made a very interesting contribution on the same subject. It is clear beyond any doubt whatsoever to every honorable member that the Executive is slowly but surely overriding and swamping the rights, privileges and responsibilities of the private members. It is time we called a halt to this drift.

After all, each and every member here represents something of the order of 40,000 electors. We are all here to represent them; we are not here merely to vote according to the decision of the Executive. We are here to represent our electors, to speak on their behalf and to do something effective for them. This whittling away of the powers, rights and privileges of private members is in evidence in many ways. First of all, there is the physical evidence of this dissipation of rights inasmuch as members of the Executive, and their staffs, are taking over offices in this building which, I believe, rightly belong to the members of the Parliament. This building was created for the use of the members. It was not to be used as a series of offices for Ministers with quite considerable staffs.

talk.start.para: - Some of them have very small staffs.

- That is so. lt is time that a halt was called. I can almost envisage the time when members will have no right of tenure in this building. I say this building was designed for members, but the design is disappearing. A former Clerk of this House has made some broadcasts and has written some most interesting articles on this subject. I commend them to all honorable members to read, as the case may be, or listen to, if they have the opportunity to do so.

speech.para: Now I turn to what is to me the most fundamentally important right of a private member. That is his right, as a representative of the electors, in relation to his vote in this Parliament. It always seemed to me, and I still believe it to be a cardinal principle of the Liberal party, that a member shall have a certain freedom in the exercise of his vote, and I would not tolerate, or remain a member of, any party that forbade its members to exercise that right. As we all know, members of the Labour party are bound to vote as that party directs. If they choose to vote contrary to the direction of the party, they run the very real risk of expulsion. In this matter, I fundamentally disagree with the Australian Labour party, because I believe we in the Liberal party have a basic right, which must be preserved. That is the right of the individual member of the party to vote as he desires.

talk.start.para: - Try it !
- I have tried it on many occasions.
- What happened?

- I am still in the Parliament. I wish to mention another matter in relation to the one to which I have just referred. It is the practice consistently adopted in this Parliament by all parties, when in office, of rejecting, out of hand, all Opposition amendments. The attitude, irrespective of the political colour of the government, seems to be that there can be no good in an Opposition amendment. That is a completely nonsensical attitude. I recall that, during the years from 1946 to 1949, when I was a member of this House, and when a Labour government held office, only one Opposition amendment was accepted. It was a very minor amendment, which involved merely the changing of a word. I regret to say that, since the present Government has been in office, little change of attitude has been effected. In all common sense, an Opposition is not always wrong, nor are suggestions advancd by it in relation to a bill always wrong. It is time we had a little more latitude, freedom and understanding in relation to suggestions advanced by honorable members who are in opposition for the time being. After all, if no notice is taken of Opposition suggestions, it is merely beating the air. In the Tasmanian Parliament and many of the other State parliaments, as well as in the House of Commons of the Mother Parliament, it is the practice to allow free votes. It is quite common for members of the Tasmanian Parliament to cross the chamber and vote as they see fit. Yet, in this Parliament, believe it or not, it appears that, in certain circumstances, if a member desires to vote according to his conscience, he commits a breach of his party's confidence, although that situation should never arise. In criticism of the present Government, which I support, I submit that there is no reason why a Liberal party and Australian Country party government should reject Opposition amendments out of hand or be touchy about the manner in which a Government supporter votes, solely because the Australian Labour party takes that view in the extreme. In short, it is no defence to say that, because another person does something, we should copy him. It is true, of course, that, on many occasions an opposition advances an amendment with the intention of embarrassing a government, and not with any genuine intention of having a bill amended, lt i3 equally true that, on many occasions, an opposition is able to make sensible suggestions which ought to be incorporated in bills.

speech.para: I wish now to refer to the rights, responsibilities and privileges of private members of this House in relation to " Grievance Day ". As we all know, Mr. ' Acting Deputy Speaker, " Grievance Lay " affords the private member the opportunity to speak in this Parliament on behalf of individual electors, or collective groups of them, in an endeavour to have rectified any troubles they may have. I wish to point out that, during the years since World W ar II., " Grievance Day " has been called on with the following frequency : - 1943-44, three times; 1944-45, once; 1945-46, five times; 1046-48, six times; 1948-49, six times; 1960-51, once; 1951-53, five times; 1953-54, once; and 1954-55, twice. It has long been recognized, in the House of Commons and other British assemblies, that the major part of the parliamentary time must be devoted to government business. In principle, the control of this time rests with the House itself, but, in practice, the House has, by standing order, delegated this control to the Government with a saving for private members' business, and other minor reservations. As a result, the Government is given very far-reaching control over the time of the House. Even the time allotted to private members' business can, when the Government considers the need arises and when it has party support, be transferred to the Government by a vote of the House suspending the relevant standing order.

In this House, the principal traditional formal opportunities for private members to raise matters are, first, by the moving of motions when general business is before the House and, secondly, by speaking to the question " That Mr. Speaker do now leave the chair " on " Grievance Day ". Until recently by sessional order, and now by Standing Order 105, precedence has been given to general business on a part of certain sitting days. Standing Order 291 provides that grievance shall be the first order of the day of government business on particular days. In the early years, one day in each sitting week was devoted to general business, and " Grievance Day " occurred every third Thursday. Later, general business was given precedence until 9 p.m. on each " Grievance Day ". In effect, the whole of each third Thursday could be given to the discussion of private members' matters, either on motion or under " grievance ". This position obtained until the 21st March, 1950, when the House adopted new Standing Orders, which provided that grievance should have precedence until 12.45 p.m. on alternate Thursdays, and that general business should -have precedence until 12.45 p.m. on other Thursdays. In other words, one morning in each week was set aside for private members' business. I have given the House the record of the facts. In recent years, it has been the consistent practice of governments to transfer some of these times to government business, on the one hand, by postponing the grievance order of the day and, on the other, by moving for the precedence of government business on general business days.

Other opportunities for private members to raise matters occur during the debate on the motion for the adjournment of the House to- conclude the sitting, during the general debate on the Estimates, in Committee of Supply, during the debate on the divisions of the Estimates, in Committee of Supply, during the debate on the motion for the adoption of the Address-in-Reply to the GovernorGeneral's Speech - the debate now in progress - and during the debate on matters of urgency in relation to a specific subject. The opportunities during the debate on the motion for the adjournment of the House to conclude the sitting, in theory, occur each sitting day, but, in practice, they are limited by the time the Government is prepared to devote to the debate. Opportunities during the general debate on the Estimates, in Committee of Supply and the debate on the divisions of the Estimates, in Committee of Supply, occur only once in each financial year. Opportunities during the debate on the motion for the adoption of the Addressin -Reply to the Governor-General'. Speech occur only once in each session. I do not wish to weary the House unduly with historical matters relative to this subject. I simply wish to say that it is more than time that greater opportunity was given to private members to ventilate the affairs, needs and wishes of their electors. Unless we get back to a situation in which the member comes to this House with an opportunity to speak on " Grievance Day ", and on the motion for the adjournment of the House, and to say something useful on behalf of his electors - we are drifting rapidly away from that situation - this Parliament will become nothing more nor less than a pale shadow of the Executive. That is no longer tolerable, and I make my protest against it and say that I will oppose it in every way I can.

talk.start.para: . - I find myself in accord with much that has been said by the honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Falkinder). I admire him for his courage in attacking the cause of the problems that are so evident to honorable members. It "becomes apparent from day to day that the privileges of the private members of the Parliament have been trespassed upon and have dwindled away. It is time that there was a general rebellion against this by private members, so that we may stand ! up for our right to do the work which the electors sent us here to do and uphold the prestige of this great National Parliament. I shall say no more about that now,

speech.para: I desire to address myself to the subject of the sale of the national whaling station at Carnarvon, which was established by a Labour government and which has proved to be most successful, with a capacity to save the taxpayers' money and show a return for the expenditure associated with its establishment. Over the years there has been much under-cover negotiation in connexion with this station. In the inter-

I e?ts of the nation, and -particularly in the interests of the people of Western Australia, it should not be sold, but irrespective of anything that the Opposition may say, irrespective of the merits of the case, the Government unfortunately has the numbers, and it will be sold. It will not be sold to the Western Australian Government but to private enterprise, namely, the Nor- West Whaling Company Limited, which is now controlling the Point Cloates whaling station, 70 miles north of Carnarvon.

This company has done very well since it was established at Point Cloates. It has paid big dividends to its shareholders, but in the Parliament yesterday the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) unintentionally spilled the beans, because in the course of his remarks he said that the very modern equipment at the Carnarvon national whaling station was sufficient to cope with the quota of whales allocated to both stations on the north-west coast. He did not mention both stations, but the information given this afternoon by the honorable member for Darling Downs (Mr. Swartz), who apparently had the latest figures, shows that the quota oi the two stations was 1,000 whales. The Minister for Trade said that the modern equipment of the national whaling station was able to cater for the total quota allocated to that coast, which means that the Nor-West Whaling Company Limited would walk in, acquire this national station, close its Point Cloates station, and, as a consequence, dispense with the services of at least 115 men. Nobody can convince me that this Government does not know that already. The Nor-West Whaling Company Limited employs 115 men at Point Cloates. Of these, ten are permanent and 105 are seasonal workers, so the town of Carnarvon, which is endeavouring to increase its population, will immediately lose the benefit of the 115 toilers on this station, because there is no other industry adjacent to Carnarvon which can absorb them. As a consequence,, in keeping with this Government's policy, they will migrate to the metropolitan area. Thus, a great disservice will be done to Carnarvon and district. Time after time the Government has preached its support of a policy of decentralization in order to encourage the growth of population in the north-west, where it is so badly needed. lt has been suggested that the Western

Australian Labour Government has known all about these negotiations, and that if it did not know, it ought to have known. These negotiations have never been brought from behind the scenes. They Iia ve been kept behind the iron curtain. Only because of continued questioning of the Minister did this Parliament obtain definite information within the last week that this national whaling station is to be disposed of. It is scandalous that the station should be sold to private enterprise and that the sale should result in the disposal of another undertaking on the coast which lias been such a great help to the people in that part of the country, but of course t,li at does not concern this Government. The Government has preached a policy of decentralization, but what are its actions towards that end? Where is the demonstration of faith? How can the people of this country accept those statements made from time to time by responsible Ministers of the Government? Nothing whatever has been done to justify their acceptance. As the honorable member for Franklin has said, \Ve have come to a point of frustration. Irrespective of the merits of the case which the Opposition is able to put and whether or not the interests of the country are adversely affected, the Government has the numbers to steamroller its proposals through the Parliament. The time has come when I ask whether it is worth while to stand here and discuss the affairs of the country as they have been presented to me. I know the north-west of Western Australia as well as does any other man in Australia. I present this case in all honesty and I appeal to the Government, even at this late hour, to reconsider the matter. I appeal to the Government back-benchers to come over to this side of the House and support the Opposition's amendment in order to prevent the sale of this great national asset.

I have been reading His Excellency's Speech, which deals with the proposals and policy of the Government. I did not find very much to encourage me. I am concerned with the development of this country. We talk about bringing more immigrants here. I want to see them come and to see the population of this great country increased to 30,000,000 or even more. I know that there is scope for these additional people, and that a properly organized long-range plan can provide the necessary development to assist them to carry on, become good citizens and producers, and help us to improve the position in which we are to-day. In addition, that would strengthen our defences to such an extent that we should be able to rest more easily than we can to-day.

But what do we find? This Government says that there is no money available for -development. The great potential wealth of the Kimberleys area in Western Australia is still unexploited. I have argued the case for the Kimberleys area since I entered this Parliament fourteen or fifteen years ago. I have put up cases to the Government time after time, but nothing has been done. I admit, of course, that the development of the area would require money. The Western Australian Government has sent deputations to Canberra which have been representative of all parties in that State. Those deputations have pleaded with the responsible Ministers here to assist Western Australia by providing the money necessary to put various developmental projects under way, so that, for example, water for irrigation purposes can be brought to fertile lands which to-day carry only a few cattle to each 100 acres. But nothing has been done. After those deputations have pleaded unsuccessfully with this Government for help, I feel that anything that I say will be of no use. There was a committee, consisting of private individuals who sacrificed their time and money to examine problems associated with the development of the north. They devoted their time to the problems and they paid their own fares to Canberra so that they could put their case to the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) and other Ministers. But they got nothing for their State. They suffered the same frustration that we in this Parliament have suffered. No move was made. They were given no encouragement, and there was no suggestion that any assistance would be forthcoming from the National Parliament.

I want to refer to another matter that has been hanging fire for a number of years. Time after time, T have put questions to the Minister for Territories (Mr. Hasluck) and the Prime Minister about the intentions of the Government in relation to the zone allowance that was instituted in 1945 by a Labour government, with a view to providing a small measure of income tax relief for people living in isolated areas under hard and wretched conditions. The Labour Government regarded the zone allowance as the forerunner of something that would be of great value to people in the north. It was instituted in 1945, and a small increase was made in 1947, as some compensation for the increased cost of living. But, since 1947, no further action has been taken. This Government has done nothing to increase the allowance. In their replies to questions that I have asked, both the Minister for Territories and the Prime Minister have said that the matter is under consideration. At one time, I was told that it would be dealt with in the 1955 budget. But, although the 1955 budget has come and gone, these people have not got even a mention. So, under arduous conditions, they are struggling to try to make ends meet in a country that is empty. It is empty because of the lack of policy of this Government.
I noticed that, in his Speech, His Excellency said -

quote.para: My Government's programme of work is designed as far as possible to overtake arrears and maintain post office services at a high level of efficiency.

speech.para: The town of Geraldton, in Western Australia, was promised a new post office in 1947. The promise was repeated in 1950, in 1953 and again last year, but, as far as I can ascertain, the people of Geraldton will have to wait for some time before they get a new post office. In the present building both the accommodation and the installations are inadequate. The people of the town are becoming disgusted with the delay. They have been told time after time by this Government that a new post office will be built, but the prospect to-day does not seem to be any more hopeful than it was ten years ago.

When, as representatives of the people, we present cases to the Government, we expect that those cases will receive at least consideration by the responsible Ministers; but, time after time, when an honorable member rises in his place to make a speech, the Ministers concerned are not in the chamber. They do not hear what is said and, what is mon:, they do not care what is said. It is of no use for them to say that they read the speeches, because we know that they do not. They do not know what cases have been presented to the Parliament and. therefore, they are not in a position to judge whether there is any merit in the proposals advanced.

I have been a member of this Parliament for many years, and during thai time I have fought to achieve something for the people who live in the vast constituency that I represent, but now I have reached the stage when I ask myself, " Is it worthwhile to rise in this House and make a genuine effort to do something for the people, if the Government is noi interested ? ".

talk.start.para: .- Mr. Acting Deputy Speaker,I believe that, in the history of this Parliament, an amendment has been moved to the motion for the adoption of an address-in-reply on sixteen occasions. Whatever were the subjects to which the previous amendments related, I am certain that honorable members from Western Australia will be pleased that the Opposition has seen fit to move this amendment, regardless of how much they agree or disagree with it. The time is long overdue for ordinary members of the Parliament to learn about a State which is often regarded as a place of sand and desert, rather than as a State of great potential value to the future prosperity of the Commonwealth. If the debate on the amendment serves only the purpose of bringing before the members of this House and the people of the country generally the importance and the potential of Western Australia, it will have served its purpose.

speech.para: It is somewhat surprising that the Opposition has taken the line that, if this whaling station is to be sold it should be purchased by the Western Australian Government. The honorable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. H. V. Johnson) has stated quite clearly that the sale has been arranged already and that he knows the buyer, but I venture to suggest that the honorable member is the only person in possession of that information. I have no idea how the honorable member could have got the information that he says -he has got. Last night, the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean) read an extract from an article published in the Daily News, the evening newspaper in Western Australia. The article asked what was to happen to the whaling station at Babbage Island, which is described as a £200,000 a year asset, and proceeded to suggest that first preference should be given to the Western Australian Government to purchase the station for the people of that State. It would have been wise for the honorable member for Melbourne Ports to make another quotation from the Daily News - from an article which stated that the Premier of Western Australia presented the Surf Life Saving Association with a cheque for a couple of hundred pounds. Like many honorable members of this House, the Premier believes that a contribution to a surf life saving association is a contribution to a worthy cause, but he said that however much he would like to give more, the government just could not afford to do so. If the Western Australian Government cannot afford to give more than a couple of hundred pounds to such a worthy cause, how, in the name of fortune, could it purchase a whaling station, the value of which, on anybody's guess, must be in the region of £500,000? I believe all honorable members are convinced that Hip undertaking will be sold. Anybody wlm is not so convinced, or who thinks that it was not obvious that it would be sold, seems to have forgotten the policy speech of the present Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) in 1949, because at that time he stated quite clearly the attitude of the present Government parties towards government-owned enterprises.

The sale of this undertaking to private enterprise will be appreciated by more people in Western Australia than the honorable member for Kalgoorlie believes. The Federal Government should not be a participant in industry, but should remain the watchdog of industries to ensure that they are conducted to the best advantage of the Commonwealth as h whole.

Speaking as a member of the Parliament who represents approximately 35,000 people in Western Australia, 1 should say that the first thing the Government should do, and which it probably will do, is to ensure that the undertaking is sold to a Western Australian company. The outlook of the State has changed completely in the post-war years. That would be obvious to honorable members who visited the State many years ago, or even during the war years. An awareness of the industrial potential of the State has suddenly become apparent. Whereas previously there was a tendency to look upon primary production as being our chief means of livelihood, and to regard the residents of the cities and towns as being parasites on primary production, we have now adopted a new philosophy. We recognize that the State can expand in the industrial field. Perhaps that is due largely to the many millions of pounds that have been invested in a refinery and the interest that has been displayed by the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited. Certain persons or organizations in Western Australia have recognized the potential of the State, and I think that they should be given the first opportunity to carry on the activities that have been carried out by the Australian Whaling Commission.

The Opposition has painted a glowing picture of the commission's undertaking. It has stated that the annual profit has been as much as £200,000 and £222,000 ; but it has not made any attempt to go back over the years in order to give a clear picture of the operations of the organization since its establishment. If honorable members were to examine the position in past years, they would note that at one stage the overall profit was in the vicinity of only £70,000 which, if the undertaking had been owned by a private company, would have barely returned any company tax to the Government. If the Government of Western Australia were able to find the money to purchase the project, no company tax would be paid and the Commonwealth would be the loser. Not only is the question of company tax involved, but also the question of taxes on shareholders' dividends, which also would bring money back into the Commonwealth purse. I believe that it is the duty of this Government, if it sees the possibility of establishing a particular industry, to establish that industry, but not to compete with private enterprise and not to continue a situation in which Caesar appeals to Caesar. While the Government remains unfettered by such undertakings as the one in question, it is in a position to legislate for the benefit of the majority and is not tempted to legislate for the benefit of its own undertakings. If the undertaking is not to be sold to a Western Australian company, it should be provided that any other company to which it may be sold should be financed entirely by Australian capital. It should be made clear that we have no desire to bring in foreign capital and that any profits should go into the pockets of the Australian people.

It is quite true that other whaling companies are operating around the coast of Australia. The honorable member for Kalgoorlie referred to the operations of Nor-West Whaling Company Limited. Many honorable members must be aware of the fact that that company makes a profit similar to that of the Australian Whaling Commission, that that profit is taxed, that it is derived from the same quota of 500 whales and that it is made on about one-quarter of the capital employed by the Australian Whaling Commission. I want to make it quite clear that I would not like to see the company which acquired the Australian Whaling Commission's undertaking take over the activities of the Nor-West Whaling Company Limited. I have in mind the statement of the honorable member for Kalgoorlie that the Minister for Trade had said in the House that the commission could handle the quotas of both organizations with its present staff. It seems to me that, if the Government does not sell the Australian Whaling Commission's undertaking, it is time to investigate the position of a staff that is probably being well paid to do only half of the amount of work that it is capable of doing.

Many persons have a misconception about the Australian whaling industry. From a total catch of 1,600 or 1,700 whales four Australian organizations - at Moreton Bay in Queensland, Cheyne Beach at Albany, the Nor-West Whaling Company and the Australian Whaling Commission - produce approximately 4 per cent, of the world's whale oil supply. The figures that I have quoted differ slightly from those cited by the honorable member for Darling Downs (Mr. Swartz). The point that I am leading up to is that this undertaking about which the Opposition has painted a glowing picture is engaged in a very hazardous occupation. There is no guarantee that the quota allotted under the international agreement will not suddenly be reduced. That is another reason why the Government should get right out of the whaling industry. It is in a position to ensure that the whale stock in our area is preserved, and that over-killing does not take place. It is quite obvious that, if other countries produce 96 per cent, of the world's whale oil, those countries could exert very strong pressure on the price of oil on the world's markets to the detriment of the Australian market. Great uncertainty exists about the price of whale oil. Since World War II., the price a ton has fluctuated between approximately £55 and £120 sterling. It will be noted that about four years ago, when the profits of the Australian Whaling Commission were enormous, the balance-sheet showed a price of £125 per ton. The present price, of course, is well down.

The commission has erected a £70,000 plant to treat whale meal. It is vitally important to the people of Western Australia in particular that one company should not have a monopoly of the whaling industry in that State, because, at the present time, there is very keen competition in the sale of such by-products as fertilizers. While there is competition, the price will be kept at a reasonable level. There is a danger here also, and I direct attention to it to show that the picture is not as rosy as the Opposition has tried to portray it. Whale meal costs approximately £57 a ton landed at Fremantle, but meat meal from Sydney can be landed for £30 a ton. The properties of meat meal are not very different from those of whale meal for the particular purpose for which they are used. It will be observed that any company which operates the undertaking that we are now considering will not have a clear-cut £200,000 a year profit on its investment. I suppose that, if we were to take the capital cost and do a little simple arithmetic, we would find that the percentage of profit is not very much greater, and is probably lower than that of the average Australian company.

One further point must be taken into consideration. As I have stated, whaling in this area is a hazardous occupation. The station is situated in a region of cyclonic storms. Any activity up there carries a double risk, because insurance premiums are almost prohibitive. Great structural damage by a cyclonic storm could be caused without warning. Some honorable members will remember that the Point Cloates whaling station, which was operated by the Norwegians, was closed down following damage caused by such a storm. The Government has made it clear to the Opposition and to the people generally its intentions in relation to this concern, and I believe that the people of Australia were fully aware of those intentions on the occasion of recent general elections. Therefore, if a government pledges itself to a policy, it is its duty to carry that policy out. It should set itself up as the assister of and not as an active competitor with industry. The money that is received from the sale of this whaling station could well be spent in the development of the fishing industry right round the Western Australian coast. There we have a terrific fishing potential, and I think that Government assistance is needed to carry on the research started by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in Western Australian waters, in an attempt to develop big fishing grounds. I consider that the Government has shown wisdom in deciding to sell the whaling station.

Most people in Western Australia have known for three years about the Government's proposal to sell the station. To claim that the Western Australian Government was unaware of what was intended is stupid in the extreme. Most Ministers of the Western Australian Labour Government have spent time during their holidays at the whaling station, have gone out on chasers to see whales caught, and have spent time at the factory, where everybody knew quite well of this Government's intention to dispose of the station. However, I suppose the Western Australian Government thinks that, as it is approaching the end of its period of office of three years, and has to face the country shortly, this is a good time for it to activate the Opposition in this Parliament into protesting vigorously at the proposed sale.

The present position in the Western Australian Parliament is that the House is divided almost equally between Government and Opposition, each having about 25 members. Political observers in Western Australia are forecasting that the position will remain the same after the election. One of the seats in which the Western Australian Government is vitally interested is the Gascoyne seat, the centre of which is Carnarvon, where the whaling station is situated. I cannot help feeling that all this turmoil about the proposed sale of the whaling station is closely connected with the coming general election in Western Australia, but I also feel that the people of Western Australia, knowing, as they do, the full facts of their State's potential under private enterprise, will realize that the Australian Government, by selling the station to private enterprise, would be acting in the best interests of the Western Australian people.

I sincerely hope that the spotlight thrown on the north-west of Western Australia during this debate will not be dimmed, but will shine brightly in future debates, and will illuminate for honorable members the needs of a vast part of this continent, which can be developed only with Commonwealth assistance. The development of this area would give an opportunity to Australians in Western Australia to add to that development with all the strength, enterprise, courage and initiative that they have. I think that the amendment moved by the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard), which I know will be defeated, will have served a very useful purpose if the result that I have mentioned springs from this debate.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to direct the attention of the House to the remarks made by the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) when he finally admitted that the Government proposed to dispose, by stealth, of the whaling station in Western Australia. I also wish to

item.para: . ;rect the attention of honorable members to the preamble to the act under which lie Australian Whaling Commission was established. It reads -

speech.para: An Act to provide for the establishment of an Australian Whaling Commission and for i lie carrying on by the commission of whaling activities in certain waters, and of activities incidental thereto.

I see no reference, in the Hansard reports of the debates on that bill, to any suggestion that this great industrial project, which is an enterprise in the true sense of the word, was to be established simply to show private enterprise that it could be carried out profitably. I suggest that it is rather novel for members on the Government side to say now that vaunted private enterprise, which, in all other respects, from what we hear from the Government side, can show us how things should be done, had to be shown how the nation's resources in the whaling industry could be employed, and had to have acts of Parliament passed, and the national wealth and the efforts of the Commonwealth Public Service used to show it how to do the job. Then, eventually, when it has been shown that there are no great risks involved in the industry, when the way has been paved, private enterprise is to be allowed to step in and take it over. I believe that this is a classical example of the extreme capitalist, materialist viewpoint and I rise to protest against this action, not only as a member of this Parliament and of the Labour party, who has a fraternal interest in enterprises controlled by the Government, but also as a citizen of this country. In other words, I am protesting, as a shareholder in this concern, against its imminent disposal by the Government.

The Minister for Trade saw fit to inform all sorts of people that the whaling station was for sale. He says that .the Government's intention to dispose of the station has been public knowledge for years. He said also - and other honorable members opposite have reiterated the statement - that every thinking citizen ought to have known that the Government proposed to dispose of these national undertakings. He selected some business groups in the community and informed them of his intentions, but why did he not tell all of them? Every one of us was just as interested in the matter as were these groups. I am not too happy, as a citizen, let alone as a member of this Parliament, about the Minister taking on himself the right to choose the lucky players who are going to receive this wonderful asset, because I am told that there are restricted resources on which the whaling industry can operate. I have that on the information of honorable members on both sides. 1 claim that the Minister has no power, no moral right, and that it is not his duty, to select any particular section of the corn.munity and surrender to it control of an industry which operates on limited resources and is, therefore, monopolistic in its nature. This sale is like a gigantic lottery, but the tickets in this one cost more than 5s. each. Only people who can produce £1,000,000 or so can buy a ticket in this lottery. The whole thing is just not good enough. I believe that it is an assault on the rights of this Parliament. I believe it prejudices the way in which the country should be run. The possession of this whaling station by the Government may be termed socialism by the honorable members opposite. It is the socialist attitude that wherever there are restricted resourcesavailable those resources should be controlled by the people's government for the people. That is one of the first tenets of the Labour party's socialism. A good deal has been said on the other side of the chamber about socialistic doctrine. The honorable member for Flinders (Mr. Lindsay) referred to the remarks made by my good friend and colleague the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns), as a "socialist diatribe". I think he did the honorable member for Yarra a little less than justice. I shall say of the Labour party's socialism that it is at least empirical and pragmatic. We believe that if an industry is successful, does no harm to anybody, and is for the benefit of the community, it is a good thing. This industry comes into that category. It is a successful enterprise, is doing nobody any harm, and is producing dividends for the community. That is the first test.

The second test, of course, is connected with the restricted nature of resources in which the industry operates. Are the resources operated on by the whaling industry available to everybody? It is quite clear, of course, that they are not. The industry, therefore, should be confoiled in the national interest. "When honorable members opposite speak of socialism they are inclined to use the term as though socialism were something doctrinaire and dogmatic. Our party, in the few years it has been in office in its history, has established successful enterprises. It has not set out, holusbolus, to nationalize anything, or to take things from other people.

talk.start.para: - What about the banks ?

- I point out to my friend, the honorable member for Mallee (Mr. Turnbull), that the banks are still controlled by this Parliament. Eventually, even the honorable member for Mallee has to accept the fact that the Parliament is the place from which the country should be run. He is becoming a socialist by implication in that regard. The point I should like to make to honorable members opposite is that they themselves display a remarkably doctrinaire and dogmatic attitude. The Minister for Trade himself showed such an attitude when he told us, reluctantly be it noted, that the Government was going to dispose of the industry. As the honorable member for Yarra has said, the disposal of the industry was to be effected, not because it was not a success, or because it had now been shown that it could not be run profitably, but simply because it was in the line with, his policy of antisocialism. I suggest that that is an extraordinary doctrinaire attitude to take. When have honorable members on this side of the House been heard to say that something must be carried out simply on the line of political dogma? I thought that the doctrinaire approach to these things was safely behind the iron curtain, but opinions are expressed in the House which I do not think bear examination.

speech.para: There is another point about which I would like to make an emphatic protest. For the second time in three weeks in this Parliament - for the second time in my brief stay here - the Government has only very reluctantly released a full statement on what it proposes to do. The first instance was the bill which was recently passed in relation to Ministers of State and their salaries. The details were brought to light only by the vigilance of the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean). i doubt whether we would have heard much of the proposal to get rid of the whaling station at Carnavon had it not been for the vigilance of honorable members on this side of the House. These things support the views that have been pronounced by some honorable members opposite on the growth of the powers of the Executive. The honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Falkinder) spoke of the cavalier way in which the Parliament was being treated by the Executive. The proposed sale of the whaling station is a classical instance of it. I should like to say to those people who are complaining about the way in which we are being treated, that if they complain of Parliament being treated in that fashion, then they are adopting a position of contradiction. From their own attitude to industry, it is apparent that they consider that the Parliament, as a representative body, and the machinery which it sets up, are not enough to run an industry. This decision to sell the whaling station is a vote of no confidence in themselves. So far as I am concerned, the doctrine of " socialization " as we on this side of the House call it, and that will do for this occasion, is a doctrine of self-confidence and selfrespect. The people opposite who are so keen to get rid of this asset are plainly saying that they are handicapped in operating it. We, on this side of the House, believe that the Parliament of the people should control the assets of the people; that the people who are elected here are quite as capable of running these things as anybody else.

One of the advantages that we have over the situation when an industry is controlled by Parliament is that it is answerable to the people. Those who control limited resources - and this is the case with the whaling industry and the products from it - also have control, in some way, over the people of the nation.

The products of the whaling industry are a part of the vital machinery of industry, and I believe that this industry should not fall into the hands of people who are not answerable to us. It is essential that the people who exercise power in the community, whether industrial power or any other sort of power, should be answerable to the people over whom they exercise it. That is another aspect of the doctrine of honorable members on this side of the House. The solution of these problems indicatedby the people opposite represents a vote of no confidence in this Parliament. Their solution is immoral, because it entails the use of the resources of the country to further the interests of private business.

Who are the lucky ones that will receive this great asset? We have not yet received any official statement on the value of the asset. The honorable member for Melbourne Ports "suggested that the minimum that should be demanded for it was close on £3,000,000, and this would be giving a fair return to the industry. It is not a matter of the £200,000 which is involved. It is a rnatter of the control of the people's asset. It is a matter of the attitude that we should adopt to the resources of the community. I believe that the Government, in proposing to dispose of an undertaking, even if a good sale is in prospect, is proceeding upon lines which are indefensible. I do not believe it is a question of whether £200,000 will produce this or that. The sum of £200,000 would finance the building of many things. There is a shortage of schools in the community. ' But I believe that honorable members opposite should take this opportunity to re-aline their policy of using the resources of the community only for business ends. They should re-aline this policy with the one that they espouse when they demand the observance of the sovereignty of this Parliament and the proper treatment of private members. The logical deduction from their attitude - that we areunfit to legislate for, control and develop these things - is that the honorable members are unfit to have rooms in the place, and unfit to be here at all.

Therefore, I hope that the Government will reconsider its pronounced policy. I hope that it will reconsider the facts as we have stated them. The Government, instead of getting rid of the country's assets to private concerns, should make every effort possible to bring the industrial wealth of the community back under the control of this Parliament. In the Governor-General's Speech, it was pointed out that we are unable, because of the influence of the Constitution, adequately to administer many fields of industry. It is important, therefore, to adopt one policy for this Parliament in these matters. That policy should be, " What power we have, that power we shall hold ". Therefore, I hope that those members opposite, who have so very freely, with a good deal of courage and with quite a lot of fluency, advocated greater respect for the private members, will think twice before they surrender the whaling industry of this country to private industry.

talk.start.para: . - I do not propose to continue this debate, which is developing into an argument between the merits ofsocialism and of private enterprise. The Government of this country has been elected as a protagonist of private enterprise, and I think that is the ultimate answer to all the discussion that we have had on the subject of the whaling industry.

speech.para: I wish to express some ideas on the defence of this country that have been going through my mind for some time. I should like to recall that, for some years now, we have been spending what for this country is an enormous sum of money on the defence programme. In fact, for the current year, the Estimates provide £190,000,000 for defence. A similar amount has been provided for the last few years. In that period, we have been providing each year approximately one-fifth of our national budget for our defence. This is a very significant proportion of the budget. I think thatit behoves us to ensure, within our ability, that this money is being spent wisely, and that we get the best result from the expenditure and the resources which are involved. I have some doubts about it.

In order to make my position clear, I think that I should review the situation in which we find ourselves in the world to-day. Australia, strategically, is developing very fast. Our population is growing. It is nearly 10,000,000 persons. Our industries are developing vigorously. Quite recently, we have discovered large deposits of uranium in this country which are being successfully processed.

All these things increase enormously the strategic value of Australia in the eyes of a potential enemy. The time has passed when we could say to ourselves that Australia's limited ability to mobilize Avar resources guaranteed that we would not be an attractive prize. During the previous Avars Ave could. with some confidence, regard ourselves as immune from air attack. Our concentrations of population and industry were, fortuitously, in the south-east portion of the continent, and in those days the range of aircraft was such that to launch air attacks on our important centres an enemy would have had to establish bases on the mainland, or obtain almost complete sea and air superiority and bring his aircraft carriers within range of our cities. That situation no longer exists. Every major country in the world - in both the democracies and in the Communist ohe - now has aircraft capable of bombing any point of the world from their home base. If that is so, Ave must ask ourselves what is the position with regard to the threat to Australia.

I think that, from every logical point of view, the most probable type of attack is air bombardment. It is the simplest, it is the most economical and it is the most effective, having regard to the development of modern air weapons. I would again draw attention to the fact that people do not seem to appreciate the enormous power of modern hydrogen bombs. T shall repeat an illustration that I have given before because I do not think that these points can be driven home too often. One hydrogen bomb, weighing 5 tons, has a greater destructive power than all the bombs that were dropped in Germany in the last war, had they been simultaneously concentrated on a single target. In addition, of course, the after-effects are enormously greater. In the light of these developments all logical reasoning seems to point to the fact thar

Ave should depend primarily upon air power for our defence. It is quite true that we must still retain some " orthodox " forces to meet the cold war situation. "We sent land, air and naval forces to fulfil our obligations to the United Nations in Korea, and quite rightly so. In Malaya we have now made a contribution of orthodox forces to help the people of that country to rid themselves of Communist terrorism and come closer to the day when they can successfully undertake selfgovernment.

While it remains clear that during the cold Avar the Communist policy is to ferment these small perimeter wars we must play our part and equip ourselves with a certain number of orthodox forces of all arms of the services. I have no quarrel with that, but over and above that Ave are preparing, I believe, for a relatively enormous expenditure so that we may play our part in the unfortunate event of the outbreak of a major war in the Pacific. The best way to prepare for that eventuality would be to set up a small, hardhitting, mobile, medium bomber striking force. We must not delude ourselves. At the present time, at any rate, Ave can have no confidence in what I call " passive defence ". It is impossible, so far as I know with the facilities available, to guarantee 100 per cent, effective passive defence from the air attack. Whatever anti-aircraft defences are employed, a proportion of an attacking force will surely get through - probably quite a big proportion. Therefore, remembering the enormous destructive power of one of these atomic weapons, and the concentration ot our industry near centres of population. Ave must agree that it would be very unwise to rely on the interception of an enemy attack. The only real defence to air attack is retaliatory attack against enemy bases. While I do not suggest that Ave should neglect passive defence entirely, or forget the importance of interception, we must make our contribution in the form of a hard-hitting, retaliatory striking air force.

The submarine is quite an effective platform from which to launch guided missiles. It is not unlikely that any naval attack on this country will take the form a submarine attack. To those who visualize an orthodox ground attack on Australia, I direct attention to the enormous task involved. It would, perhaps, be more to the point to say that if an enemy were capable of launching an amphibious attack on the Australian mainland on an invasion scale, it could only mean that our great allies, the United Kingdom and the United States of America, had been defeated in the Pacific war and that the whole war, as far as we were concerned, had already been lost. The contribution to the central strategic reserve of a small force of five, six or seven squadrons of medium bombers of the " V " type would mean that we would be doing something real and effective. I hope that, notwithstanding the importance of sentiment, we would be realistic enough to select an American medium bomber. I refer to a bomber which can carry hydrogen bombs and has an operating range of something like 4,000 miles. If we were to select American aircraft, we would avoid all the confusion and difficulty that we encountered in the last war when we tried to adapt American supplies, equipment and spares to the equipment with which we had been armed before the war began. We could use the American supply lines and their stores and equipment, and thus make a satisfactory contribution to the major effort. It would increase the efficiency of our effort enormously. If that very sketchy appreciation is correct I want to pose this question, " Where do the aircraft carriers, to which we are committed in the Royal Australian Navy, fit into this picture? ". I do not believe that they fit into the picture at all. I think that we are spending our defence money and efforts wrongly in that regard. The protagonists of the carrier will argue that the Navy must always have its own air cover. They will tell me that I have already said that any naval aggression against this country is likely to be carried out by submarines, and that the aircraft carrier is the best defence against submarines. I would accept that, perhaps, under certain conditions and in other parts of the world, but in our strategic and geographical situation I think it is wholly wrong, and I propose to try to examine that proposition.

First of all, there will be a certain amount of surface ship traffic across the Pacific Ocean, and presumably across the Indian Ocean, but the traffic density will necessarily be very low. It will not be comparable with the traffic density of ships in the western approaches during the last war, or at the terminal focal points on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of America. It will be even less in comparison with the last war because of theadvent of air transport across great distances. Very large quantities of supplies, which previously had to be carried by ships in convoy, will in future be carried by air transport, even across the whole breadth of the Pacific, if only in order to save time. So, I do not think it is an erroneous assumption that prompts me to say that the density of ocean traffic in the Pacific in the next war will be sparse, and therefore any suggestion that we will be running merchant ship convoys across the Pacific which could or would require escort cruisers, destroyers and aircraft carriers, is so improbable that it can be ruled out of the realm of possibility. By far the most economical, efficient and safe method of running sparse surface traffic across wide ocean spaces is by evasive routing. No submarine will locate itself indefinitely in the middle of a great ocean on the offchance of accidentally running across a single ship. The incentive, the target, is not sufficiently attractive. Where the submarines will concentrate their efforts, of course, will be at the entrance to our ports, our focal areas, and on our coastwise trade. Not even the strongest protagonist of the aircraft carrier, I think, will argue seriously that in these circumstances carrier-borne aircraft are more efficient than shore-based aircraft. So, if we are to be faced with the problem, of protecting our shipping in our focal areas, within a couple of hundred milesof our shore bases,, and along our coasts, then it is perfectly clear that instead of wasting our money and effort in sendingto sea aircraft carriers which are themselves so vulnerable, we should have thejob done by shore-based aircraft, in conjunction, of course, with small antisubmarine naval craft. In fact, recent exercises in our own country have shown that our shore-based Neptune aircraft are- much more effective in locating and keeping down submarines than are the seaborne aircraft of the Fleet Air Arm. Our carriers are not combat carriers but escort carriers. They are designed and equipped for that purpose. I think [ have said enough to make people think that perhaps there is no requirement for them in the Australian theatre as escorts. What other employment is there for them? It has been suggested by some people that they make excellent platforms for the launching of guided missiles. I do not doubt it, but it is a very expensive mobile platform, and much cheaper ships can do the job just as well, if we decide to go in for that sort of thing.

When I indicate some of the costs that are involved in this carrier programme perhaps people will begin to realize that they are not getting value for money. The carrier of which we are in the course of taking delivery will cost us about £20,000,000. The hull itself costs £15,500,000. It is true that by some reciprocal agreement with the Admiralty the British Government is paying half the cost of the hull, but that does not alter the fact that the hull of this one ship is costing £15,500,000. By the time it is equipped - but not with aircraft - it will cost about £20,000,000. I think that is indisputable. The aircraft component consists of two types of aircraft. The first is the Sea Venom, which cost £96,000 each. That is nearly £100,000, and certainly by the time some of the operational equipment goes into them the cost will be well over £100,000. Indeed, it will be closer to £150,000 each. The anti-submarine Gannet costs £148,000, and by the time it is equipped operationally, with radar and all the modern requirements for anti-submarine search, it will cost, I am sure, in the vicinity of £200,000. I admit that that is a guess, but I think that it is an intelligent guess.

That is not all. These aircraft carriers are very vulnerable, and no naval commander will take them to sea, where there is any possibility of meeting submarines, without a screen. Therefore, because we are committed to these aircraft carriers we are also committed to a screen of destroyers. We have ordered three of the " Daring " class destroyers, which I am told by the Minister will cost us £7,300,000 each; Therefore, for the screen which is to protect this carrier we have to find capital expenditure of £22,000,000. That does not take into account the running costs, the maintenance, the crews' payments, and all the rest of it. Even that is not all. If we run an aircraft carrier we must have a shore base as well. We have established a shore base at Nowra, which up to date has cost us £3,000,000, and which is likely to cost us more. For all this big capital expenditure, which must come out of our limited resources, we get a piece of equipment which in my view, and as I have tried to show, will be of little or no use in any future Australian theatre of war. If the same money and effort were diverted from this carrier programme to producing a group of medium bombers capable of carrying atomic weapons, as a retaliatory striking air force and a contribution to the Pacific central strategic reserve, we would be making a vastly better contribution to the security and defence of Australia.

To recapitulate my arguments, I believe that our defence thinking should be re-orientated roughly on these lines: Our Navy should accept the proposition that the submarine is the major menace. It should accept the proposition that we will not have convoys traversing the ocean, and that evasive routing is a more efficient and effective method. Shore-based aircraft at focal areas off our coast and on our coastwise sealanes are much more efficient than carrier-borne aircraft and, therefore, they should concentrate the whole of their efforts on large numbers of small anti-aircraft ships of the frigate class and similar types and develop co-operation with the shore-based aircraft of the Neptune or its subsequent class.

The Army should be given to understand that it should train to make its necessary contribution of orthodox troops during the cold war period in such places as Korea and Malaya. Attention should then be focussed on the aircraft to produce this hard-hitting, mobile retaliatory striking force of bombers capable of carrying atomic weapons, with a range of 4,000 miles or more; the class of aircraft, preferably to be American, so as to fit in with the obvious logistic set-up that. will occur in the Pacific in the case of a major war. In addition, the Air Force should provide an anti-submarine component of the Air-Navy effort in order to control the submarine menace on our sealines along the coast and on our focal areas. If that were done, I believe that we would be in a much more secure defence position. I believe that we would be helping our allies infinitely more than we are to-day, and I do not believe that the cost would be any more than it is to-day with our carrier programme.

Mr. THOMPSON(Port Adelaide) 1 4.27]. - I desire to speak on the amendment, and I think it would be well for us to realize what that amendment really is, as it has been suggested by many honorable members opposite that the amendment is put forward with a view to giving prominence to Labour's socialist philosophy. The motion for the adoption nf the Address-in-Reply is as follows: -

quote.para: We, the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

speech.para: The honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) has moved, as an amendment, that the following words be added : -

quote.para: And we desire to add that, in the opinion of this House, the Government should at once terminate nil negotiations for the sale or disposal of any of the assets of the Australian Whaling Commission located at Carnarvon, Western Australia.

speech.para: I join issue with any honorable member opposite who suggests, as did the honorable member for Darling Downs (Mr. Swartz) that the purpose of the amendment is to give prominence to Labour's policy of socialization of industry. This is a discussion of what Labour believes to be right compared with what the Government believes to be right. The amendment does not seek to put into effect the socialization policy adopted by the conference of the Labour party in 1921. The Labour party has made it clear time and time again that it would take over an industry from private enterprise only when private enterprise was conducting that industry in a way detrimental to the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: - Is that the true socialist policy, or is it the Blackburn interpretation ?
- It is Labour's present policy.
- It is the Thompson interpretation.

- It is not my interpretation. The Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) has asked whether it is the true socialist policy. He asks whose interpretation 1 am giving. I am merely stating what was intended by the decision arrived at by the conference in 1921. Having once made a decision, the conference has a right to alter it later if it so desires. In this instance, the Government is seeking to dispose of an undertaking that was established by a previous government.. I refer to the whaling station at Carnarvon, in Western Australia. The Government claims to be entitled to do so. I am merely pointing out that the intention of the Labour conference in 1921 was that an industry would be taken over only when private enterprise was exploiting the public.

speech.para: Let us consider the present position. We on this side believe that certain functions can be carried on successfully by a government.

talk.start.para: - Such as banking?

- I believe that we could make a good job of banking, but the people of Australia have decided against the nationalization of the banking system. Until they are prepared to agree to our doing so, we shall not put our banking policy into effect. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) has stated clearly that before attempting the nationalization of an industry, be it banking or anything else, the Labour party will first ask the people to decide whether they want it. In this instance, the Government does not want to go to the people. As recently as the 10th December last, we had an election, but nothing was said during the campaign about the sale of this whaling undertaking. The Minister tells us that the Government had decided some years ago to dispose of the whaling station if it could find a purchaser. That point was. not made an election issue. The people of "Western Australia were not told that the Government, if it was returned to office, would dispose of the whaling station. It is all very well for the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) to say that the people knew about the proposal, that it was made known to the Western Australian Government some two or three years ago. This matter is of such importance to the people of Western Australia that mention should have been made of it if the Government intended to sell the undertaking.

speech.para: Let us now examine the whaling industry as a whole. It must be apparent to all that this is a matter of concern to all nations of the world. We know the feelings that were expressed when the Japanese came down to take whales from the Antarctic. It was feared that if we did not call a halt a whaling industry would not exist in the Antarctic before long. It then became an international question, as between governments, and not as between private people who were simply wanting to make as much as they could out of the whaling industry. When it became an international problem, restrictions were placed on the number of whales to be taken each year. Those restrictions were not determined by a private company. Whaling operations are limited by an international convention in which various governments have participated. When we consider that only a limited number of whales may be taken in. a specified area, we naturally ask what the Government is going to do to ensure that they are taken in a way that will not give an undue advantage to some individuals by allowing them to make a monopoly of the industry and profit from it as they like. In Australia, it was for years almost impossible to get any one to undertake whaling on a scale large enough to be effective. Some years ago I visited the whaling station at the northern end of the South Island of New Zealand. A few whales only are taken there. The Chifley Government found that the whaling industry, in Australia was being whittled away, and saw that, if something was not done, we should eventually be allowed no quota by the International Whaling Commission, because other countries would be taking the lot.

In these circumstances, did private enterprise, of which honorable members opposite talk so much, come into the picture and say, " We shall establish an efficient whaling station to obtain oil and other products from whales ? " It did not. Some private concerns fooled about in a small way, but, in general, the whaling industry was going by the board. The Minister for Trade, who has been handling this matter for the Government, has stated that the Chifley Government established the station merely to ascertain whether whaling could be undertaken profitably.

talk.start.para: - Was it very easy for private companies to obtain capital, and purchase ships and other equipment, at the time of which the honorable member speaks ?
- I admit all the difficulties.
- The honorable member knows very well that private enterprise was unable to enter the industry.

- I point out to the honorable member that the whales were available many years before 1939. Private concerns could have entered the industry many years ago. The fact is that they did not do so, and the Chifley Government decided to establish a whaling station and satisfy itself whether the undertaking would be profitable. If the venture had proved a failure and losses had been incurred, the honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hamilton) and his colleagues, particularly the VicePresident of the Executive Council, if they ran true to form, would now be saying that a socialist government had taken on an enterprise in which it had lost a lot of money. We have heard such statements many times from honorable members opposite, particularly those who hail from Queensland. They have told us of undertakings started in that State by Labour governments, which they claim were failures and had to be closed down. However, they do not talk about the successes. They talk only about the failures.
- Tell us about the successful government enterprises in Queensland.

- I referred to the matter only in passing, and the Chair would not permit me to discuss an industry in Queensland at the moment. I repeat that, had the whaling station at Carnarvon been a failure like other undertakings in Queensland, and a drag on the taxpayers because losses were being made, and had no one been willing to purchase it, honorable members opposite would have condemned the Chifley Government for undertaking an enterprise that showed losses. Had the undertaking proved unprofitable, the Government and its supporters would have abandoned it And cut their losses. The Government and its supporters claim to believe in private enterprise, and they want to hand over to private operators any successful government enterprise, whether it be a whaling station or any other instrumentality, which is of benefit of the people. Any one who acquires the assets of the Australian Whaling Commission will get an undertaking that has been proved to be profitable. I do not know what price the Government could get for it. I am not at the moment concerned with that. However, I do know that, up to the present time, the profits earned have been absorbed almost entirely in the payment of the capital cost of the venture. It will not be many years before it is fully paid off, and profits after that time would redound to the benefit of the country. Honorable members opposite, on the one hand, condemn the proposals of experts for tax increases, and, on the other, they want to sell an undertaking that earns profits and brings in revenue that would otherwise have to be obtained by taxation.
- We want more enterprises like this one.

- We want a lot more. The Carnarvon whaling enterprise was not developed by the taking over of a successful private undertaking or the nationalization of an industry. The Chifley Government saw that it was necessary to establish a whaling station, and it did so. The present Government now says, in effect, that the Chifley Government was right, because the enterprise is profitable, and, therefore, it wishes to hand it over to private con cerns. That is indicative of the philosophy of Government supporters. In this instance, we have a conflict between two almost directly contrary philosophies, and we must decide which is right. As I have pointed out, honorable members opposite use the example of a failure in government enterprise as much as they can in an attempt to prove that their philosophy is right. However, when an undertaking entered into in accordance with the contrary philosophy is a huge success, we are entitled to say that our philosophy has been proved right.
- The principle is not right.

- The honorable member wishes to talk about principles. I remind him of the metropolitan abattoir at Adelaide, in South Australia. That enterprise is governed by acts of parliament. It is almost wholly a government show, although it is conducted by a semigovernment board. Do we ever hear the primary producers in South Australia saying that the abattoir should not have been established, or complaining about its work? We do not. They accept it gladly. Private enterprise would not establish killing or freezing works in theEyre Peninsula of South Australia. It was left to the government - not a Labour government, but a Liberal government - to do so in accordance with the socialistic philosophy, as honorable members opposite term it. The freezing works opened by the South Australian Government on the Eyre Peninsula has been a huge success. It has done much for the people of the peninsula, and Mr. Playford, the Liberal Premier of South Australia, is almost boastful about it. 1 agree that the works has been of immense benefit. However, if the views of honorable members opposite are correct, it should have been left to private enterprise to establish such works.
- In Victoria, it is left to private enterprise.

- That may be so, but I point out to the honorable member that Liberal supporters in South Australia point to this type of enterprise as an example of the fine record of the South Australian Liberal Government, which has held office for about 22 years. The Australian Labour party in South Australia does not oppose Mr. Playford and the South Australian Government on the question of the public ownership of these undertakings. It supports them. I was a member of the South Australian House of Assembly for many years, and I can say from experience that the only opponents of such enterprises in the South Australian Parliament were members of the Liberal and Country League, as it is termed. In the South Australian upper house, legislation to permit the establishment of these undertakings could not have been passed were it not for the support that Labour members gave to Ministers and, perhaps, several rankandfile Liberal members, to defeat the opposition of other Liberals. Honorable members opposite claim that a Liberal government was responsible. Actually, when much of this legislation was passed, the Labour party had to assist the Government to obtain a majority in the Legislative Council. I have listened to Government supporters speaking about a socialist philosophy and how it is opposed to the Liberal philosophy, but 1. recall how much South Australia, with a Liberal Premier, has been able to do. The coal mine at Leigh Creek is a government undertaking, in competition with privately owned coal mines in New South Wales. I have heard complaints from New South Wales that coal being mined in South Australia is cutting down exports from New South Wales, which is very concerned. The Labour party was not responsible for the relevant legislation, but it was responsible for joining with Mr. Playford and the South Australian Liberal Government in giving effect to it. The philosophy of private enterprise is opposed to any government enterprise at all, yet much of the success of South Australia has been brought about by the adoption by the Playford Government of the philosophy of the Labour party and of planks that we have had in our platform for years. Mr. Playford has given effect to those policies with our support and in face of opposition from members of his own party in the Parliament. I say to honorable members that he could not have succeeded without Labour support.

speech.para: Mr. ACTING DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr. McLeay).- Order! The honorable gentleman's time has expired.

talk.start.para: . - In rising to support my colleague, the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) and urging the rejection of the Opposition's proposed amendment, as an addendum to the proposed Address-in-Reply, that negotiations for the sale of the Australian Whaling Commission's establishment be suspended, I first make this comment: Although I did not listen to the speech that was made by the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard), 1 have carefully read it. After I had read it once I asked this simple question: What on earth was he complaining about, and what was the ground on which he thought the amendment should be supported by this House? Quite frankly, I was compelled, by his own arguments and his own statements, to come to the conclusion that the Opposition is not facing this problem from the point of view of realism, but that, on the contrary, it is looking at the problem from the single point of view of bitterness and frustration. I have not heard one sensible argument put by the Opposition as to why this proposed amendment should be adopted. One gathers the impression, from listening to everything said by honorable members opposite, that they are rancorous about the fact that the Government might be taking action to sell the assets of the Australian Whaling Commission, and they are not worrying about whether such a sale will benefit the Australian people or about what the philosophy behind the Government's action might bp. One might also gather the impression that the assets are to be sold and that one of the Ministers - perhaps the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) or I - might be pocketing the proceeds. The Vice-President of the Executive Council can always speak for himself. I shall speak for the other Ministers. Whatever happens, the assets, or the proceeds from their sale, will bc used for Commonwealth purposes in the normal fashion.

speech.para: If it so happened that there was a sale of the Australian Whaling Commission's establishment, why would it be made? That leads me to ask, first, what the policy of the Government is with regard to the conduct of commercial enterprises.
