Secondly, when the sale does take place, if it does in fact eventuate, will it he for the benefit of the Australian people? This is the. subject we should debate this afternoon rather than engage in bitterness, rancour and all sorts of woolly-headed statements designed as party-political propaganda. May I go back historically to the beginning of this problem? Honorable gentlemen opposite, as well as those on the Government side, will know that this matter was first raised in 1945. In 1948, the question arose as to whether we should have a mother whaling ship or a shore-based whaling station. The government of the day came to the conclusion that in order to develop one of Australia's primary resources, a certain aspect of fishing, it would be advisable to establish a demonstration whaling unit to ascertain whether commercial whaling was in fact practicable on the "Western Australian coast. After having looked rather carefully through the files, I find that some doubt existed, from the breeding grounds off the New Zealand coast, about the way in which the whales might move up the east or west coast of Australia. In the opinion of myself and the Government a correct decision was made, namely, that the Australian Government of the time should come into this fi rid and try to establish that, with adequate capitalization, good /management, and effective equipment, whaling in Australian waters could be made a commercial proposition. I for one should like to . compliment the honorable member for Lalor on the active part that he took during those years in establishing the commission and in ensuring that it was given the necessary capital to enable it to work successfully. No one, least of all my colleague the Minister for Trade, wishes to deprive him of any of the credit due to him for what was attempted and what was achieved by the Labour Government. But, as I have said, the Labour Government went into this venture for a purpose, to see whether it was practicable to exploit commercially the whales off the Western Australian coast.

This Government came into power in 1949, and not long afterwards, in fact in March, 1952, the then Minister for Commerce and Agriculture (Mr. McEwen) stated the policy of the Government with regard to the Australian Whaling Commission. That policy is thoroughly endorsed by every honorable member who sits on the Government side. The policy can be expressed in a question. Does the Government believe in carrying on commercial or industrial undertakings of a kind which can be successfully carried on by private industry? The answer is clearly " No ". This Government does not believe that it is the province of a government to enter into the field of private enterprise and to do those things which an individual can successfully achieve, except when there are exceptional circumstances. This view is adopted for a very good purpose. There is enough work for the Government to do, in terms of the general administration of the great departments of State, and in terms of general policy decisions, without getting into the sphere of commercial and industrial undertakings.

talk.start.para: - The question is not getting in; it is getting out.

- I can see no difference between getting in and getting out. Once the Government has demonstrated the success of the undertaking, let it get out, because it has enough work to do, as one day, in the dim distant future, the honorable member may have a firsthand opportunity of finding out. If he does, he will be the happiest person in the world when he realizes that he does not have too many responsibilities of a commercial kind. Otherwise, he will find pretty quickly that the administration of his department is as bad as I think itwill be in any event. To return to the argument 1 have been putting: This Government believes in individual and private enterprise when it can do the job as successfully as the Government can do it. We think that in present circumstances private enterprise can do the job. Therefore, there is not one good reason why the Government should stay in this field. But my colleague the Minister for Trade, went further. He said, " Of course, we would not wish just to get out and leave the field. If we sell the assets of the commission, two conditions will have to be fulfilled ". There was a strong view that any company carrying on the work of the whaling station should be Australian-owned. I think honorable members who sit behind me will agree that, as the bulk of the whale oil produced is exported, it would be desirable that ownership of the industry should be vested here, so that the Australian community would have the benefit of the sales of oil overseas. That was the first condition. Secondly, the principle was established that, as this industry was of great benefit to the people of Australia, the station should be kept going and that whales should be caught and processed. Those two conditions have been set down as fundamental conditions to be complied with before the Commonwealth will agree to the sale of these assets.

speech.para: I come back to the statement made by the honorable member for Lalor that there was something clandestine or surreptitious about this transaction. I have in my possession a copy of a statement that was issued by the then Minister for Commerce and Agriculture in 1952. The statement is quite clear. It set out the Government's intentions. It set out the Government's philosophy and policy. It stated that, if the Western Australian Government cared to purchase these assets, the Commonwealth would be only too happy to receive proposals from it. So far from the transaction being clandestine or hidden, those with brains to think or with ears to listen know that, since 1952 at least, it has been common knowledge that the Commonwealth is prepared to sell, subject to the conditions that I have just stated. So, since 1952, the doors have been open to applicants. Recently, several applications have been received, and they are now being considered by the departmental officials. But the door has not been shut to the Western Australian Government. Rather belatedly, the Western Australian Government sent a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), asking whether it could submit an offer. In order to give the Western Australian Government a special concession, the Prime Minister said that the date for receiving offers would be extended to the middle of March. That date was set for a very good reason. The whaling season begins on the 1st April, so that if a company takes over these assets, it is desirable that it shall do so by the middle of this month. A special privilege was given to the Western Australian Government and it was given an opportunity to tender, if it wished to do so.

Let me introduce a political note here. I have not been able to find out just what the true position of the Opposition is. I think most honorable members will concede that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) has argued that the assets should be sold, or has agreed that they should be sold, although he wants them to be sold to a particular body - that is, the Western Australian Government. He does not, in fact, object to the sale of the assets by the Commonwealth. He agrees to the sale.

talk.start.para: - He does not.

- I suggest that the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron) look at the record. If the Leader of the Opposition does not agree to the sale, he has expressed himself in rather obscure language. Certainly the view that he does not agree could not be read into his words by any person with a normal appreciation of the English language. There was not a single argument worthy of attention in the speech of the honorable member for Lalor. Bitterness and rancour, yes, but not argument. The honorable member for Lalor urges that the negotiations be suspended and finally cancelled. So we find again the classical division between the various individuals who make up the Labour party. We find the same kind of division that existed on and before the 10th December of last year, when one group of Labour men which sat in one place and another group which sat somewhere else were arguing about where the Labour party stood in national politics. To-day, we find the honorable member for Lalor and the right honorable member for Barton (Dr. Evatt) disagreeing about the sale of the assets of the Australian Whaling Commission. I have mentioned that point in order to introduce a purely political note, and to ask honorable members opposite where they stand.

speech.para: Now I come to the approach of the Western Australian Government. In 1952, that Government knew that it could put in 'an offer if it wished to do so, but it hesitated, or refused to do so, until just recently, when it knew that an election would take place. Now it is treating this problem as a piece of political bait and as a political issue. There we find the answer to the question: What is the Opposition grizzling about? The Opposition is not grizzling in terms of realism or of rational policy. It is grizzling because an election is about to take place in Western Australia, and it hopes to gain a temporary advantage by raising a false issue.

Now I come to the real questions that are involved. There are two questions that should be asked when we are considering this sale. The first of them relates to the policy of the Government, which I personally regard as being of great importance. I have stated it to the House before, and I shall continue to state it during the rest of the time that I am in the Commonwealth Parliament. I do not believe, nOT does the Government believe, that a government agency should take part in normal commercial operations when private individuals can do the job. The second major question is : Will this sale be for the benefit of the Australian people? I think it will, because the commercial value of the enterprise has been demonstrated and, if the assets are sold, adequate value will be received for them. The money received will be used for Commonwealth purposes. I cannot say now that the Government will hypothecate that money for a particular purpose. I have no authority to do that, and I have not put a proposal to the Government. But let me say that in terms of fisheries - one section of the activities of the new Department of Primary Industry - we have immense opportunities for development, and for making a contribution to the solution of the problem of our balance of payments.

I think the facts about whaling are fairly clear. The honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson) did not disguise the fact that there is a limit to the number of whales that may be caught off the Australian coast. A few years ago, the annual catch was limited to 2,000, but later, in order to conserve whales, it was reduced to 1,800. It was thought that there had been a gradual diminishing of the number of whales available. The number was gradually becoming smaller, and it was thought that the reason for that was that too many - I think this is the right term - pregnant whales were being harpooned. So, a decision was made to limit the catch last year to 1,800. However, as a result of certain inquiries that have been made, it has been found that there is a whale breeding ground to the north of New Zealand, and that whales from there pass near Norfolk Island. With the object of catching some of those whales, it has been decided to grant a licence to a Norfolk Island company to catch 150 whales this year. In addition, it i3 thought that the catch on the east and west coasts can be increased by 40 whales. So the total permissible catch this year will be 1,990.

The point I want to make is that the catch is limited. The largest number that can be taken under present conditions is about 2,000. Therefore, we cannot develop the industry to any great extent. I contend that it is not in connexion with whales that the Commonwealth should extend its activities. I believe that the time has come when, instead of worrying about a successful enterprise that cannot be extended, we should think in terms of other commercial enterprises which offer a wealth of opportunities. In tuna fishing, prawn fishing, cultured pearls, pearl shell fishing and in a dozen and one other fishing industries, whether connected with sedentary fish or swimming fish, there are many opportunities for development. There is ample opportunity for people of enterprise and initiative to establish profitable industries for the benefit of this country. Therefore, in considering the second question - whether this sale will help the development of the Australian community - I say there is no reason why the Government should stay in the whaling industry and that the sale could not possibly jeopardize our future prosperity. I add: Let us not stand on the past; rather let us think in terms of what we can do to make this country more profitable and to increase our opportunities to sell overseas as a means of solving our balance of payments problem. You, sir, know that that is a great problem. You know that last year we had an adverse balance on current account of £268,000,000. I think that, by using a little imagination and scientific investigation, we can expand our primary industries, particularly the fishing industry, and that such a contribution would be of benefit to the Australian people. Therefore, I answer the second question in the affirmative.

The sale of this undertaking is in accord with Government policy, which was made known to the people in 1952 and again at two subsequent general elections. Secondly, it may give us - and I hope it does - an opportunity to come to grips with the real problem of the further development of Australian resources. I think that my colleague, the Minister for Trade, has said almost everything that could have been said on this matter, but I hope that I have been able to present the argument in a somewhat different manner. I agree with everything that he has said, and, on the grounds set out by him and by my other colleagues, I urge honorable members to reject the proposed amendment.

Mr. CLYDECAMERON (Hindmarsh; [5.7]. - I wish to use my allotted time to deal with a great injustice that exists in the Public Service. I refer to the salaries that are paid to third division telegraphists and postal clerks employed by the Postmaster-General's Department. During question time to-day, I asked the Postmaster-General to state whether he was willing to make representations to the Public Service Board with a view to persuading it to negotiate with the unions concerned on the question of these salaries. He stated that not only would he not even bother to make such representations to the board, but also that he was not even prepared to allow his own department to discuss the matter with the union.
The history of this case commenced in December, 1951, with the lodging of a claim to the Public Service Arbitrator for increased margins after the Public

Service Board had refused to negotiate on any of the points contained in the claim. When the claim came before the Public Service Arbitrator, the board queried his right to determine the matter and asked that it be heard by the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. Apparently the Arbitrator was impressed by the submissions of the board, and he decided to have the matter listed for the court's consideration. On the 4th May, 1954, fifteen months after the matter first came before the court, the Chief Judge, Sir Raymond Kelly, referred the matter back to the Arbitrator. On the 17th July, 1954, the general secretary of the union and Mr. Albert Monk, of the Australian Council of Trades Unions, waited on the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) in Canberra and placed before him the union's case in relation to the claim. But no results flowed from this interview. After a courteous reception and a display of the Prime Minister's ability to convince the deputation that he was greatly impressed by all they had said, they went away, foolishly believing that something would be done. But, as I have stated, nothing was done.

On the 16th September, 1954, the case once again came before the Public Service Arbitrator in the form of a statutory conference. The board asked for an adjournment, using the excuse that it wanted more time to study the two and a half times formula that the court had applied in the metal trades case. The request was granted. Not until the 16th December, 1954, was the matter again considered by the Arbitrator, and on that occasion the board announced that it was prepared to make an offer to the union. The union accepted the offer on the understanding that this acceptance would not prejudice its right at a later date to press its full claim for the application of the two and a half times formula. As a result of the board's offer, which was implemented by regulation, and which became operative from the 23rd December, 1954, the maximum marginal rate for postal clerks was increased to £290 a year, and for third division telegraphists to £315 a year.

Early in 1955, the union again requested the Arbitrator to apply the two and a half times formula to the marginal rates of these employees, and after a further delay he made an order in which, in general terms, he indicated that he thought the union had made out a case for the application of the formula. However, he did not issue a determination in which he specified particular rates of pay, because he adopted the view that, if the Government intended to appeal against his decision, it would be a waste of time for him to undertake the laborious task of fixing rates of pay and margins for various classifications if they were to be upset on appeal. He said, in effect, " If the Government intends to appeal against my intention to apply the formula, I shall save myself further work by merely making an order indicating that that is my intention ". The board refused to accept the Arbitrator's decision, and it appealed to the full bench of the court against his intention. On technical grounds the court did not uphold the appeal, but referred the matter back to the Arbitrator because he had not specified rates of pay.

The Arbitrator then issued determination No. 23 of 1955 in which, except for postal clerks and third division telegraphists, he specified increases which were in accord with the two and a half times formula. In the case of postal clerks, he fixed a maximum margin of only £305 a year instead of £355, which would have been the maximum margin awarded if he had applied the principles followed by the full bench of the court in the metal trades case. For third division telegraphists, he fixed a margin of only £335 above the basic wage, whereas, if the principles adapted in the metal trades case had been applied, the margin would have been £405. The Public Service Board again refused to accept the umpire's decision, and, with the full connivance of this Government, it sought leave to appeal to the court against the determination. In July, 1955, the full bench of the court granted the board leave to appeal. During August of 1955', shortly after the right to appeal was granted, the board promised the union that in the event of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission reaching agreement with the Professional Radio Employees Institute on the question of marginal rates for Overseas Telecommunications Commission telegraphists, it would negotiate on margins with the postal telegraphists. This was only proper in view of the fact that both the board and the arbitrator had previously fixed the rates for Overseas Telecommunications Commission telegraphists at within £8 or £10 a year of the rates fixed for the Postmaster-General's Department telegraphists. It was only right and proper that the rates of pay of the two groups should continue to be kept together. On the 16th December, 1955, the board once again promised the union that it would re-open negotiations, and this time it said that it would do so as soon as the Full Court delivered judgment on the board's appeal. The court's judgment was given on the very next day, and I might mention incidentally at this stage that it is a strange thing that the court's decision was not given until the 17th December, in view of the fact that, prior to the announcement of the general election date as the 10th December, the court had indicated, in a public statement, that it would give its judgment on the 24th November. But, knowing that the judgment would have serious political effects, or was likely to have serious political effects on the Government, the court, by some strange coincidence, decided it would postpone its judgment on the appeal until after the general elections were over. In its judgment the court, as most of us expected, not only rejected its own metal trades award principles, but also actually further reduced the Arbitrator's rates for postal clerks and telegraphists by another £20 a year, thus depriving postal clerks of a total of £70 a year, counting the £50 a year which the Arbitrator himself had fixed below the Commonwealth formula. The court also deprived the third division telegraphists of £90 a year compared with what they should have received had they been given the full benefit of the metal trades award formula. As a matter of fact, the court's decision actually resulted in a loss of £5 a year on the amount which was fixed for postal clerks by the board itself. So that, to-day, the maximum rate for postal clerks is £5 a year less than the amount which the board itself agreed upon and fixed by regulation on the 23rd December, 1954. The court increased by a solitary £1 a year - the princely sum of 4½d. a week - the amount which the board had fixed by regulation for telegraphists. This was a type of discrimination not suffered by any other group in the Commonwealth Public Service; However, in fairness to the court, I want to say that the court did say that the rates fixed for postal clerks and third division telegraphists might not be just and proper and might need adjustment by the arbitrator. There was a clear implication by the court that it considered that the Government or the board, if it did its duty, should have negotiated with the union in respect of these two particular groups.

The union's experiences with other applications to the Public Service Arbitrator satisfied it that it should do everything possible to avoid the unnecessary delay which had seemed, in the past, to go inevitably hand in hand with applications to the arbitrator. Right through, the union has made every effort to try to conciliate with the board rather than to suffer delay as a result of the tedious and prolonged process of arbitration. After the court's- judgment was made known to the union it again requested the board to resume negotiations. This time it was told that the board- could not meet the union until after Christmas. The inference to be taken from that statement was that at least after Christmas the board would meet the union. So, in January, 1956, the union again asked the board to meet it in conference, and it was then that the board indicated what had been in its mind all the way through because for the first time the board told the union clearly and distinctly that it refused point blank to negotiate on those two particular classifications.

The next development was the decision of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission to increase by £40 a year the salary range of its own telegraphists, and this increase, mark you, was an increase over and above the amounts fixed by the board's regulation, and was granted without prejudice to the Professional Radio Employees Institute claim for further increases so as to get the full benefit of the metal trades award formula. Again, the Third Division Telegraphists and Postal Clerks Union requested the board to negotiate in accordance with its promise in August, 1955 that, in the event of the Overseas- Telecommunications Commission granting an. increase to the technicians employed by it, the board would consult the Third Division Telegraphists and Postal Clerks Union. The union considered that the board should honour this promise, and meet it again in conference. But the board made it clear, for the second time, that it had no intention of meeting the union, in connexion with- this matter. "While refusing even to negotiate on the claims of the telegraphists for an increase of £90 a year, or the claims of the postal clerks for an increase of £70 a year, the chairman of the Commonwealth Public Service Board, Mr. "W. E. Dunk, is at the moment himself accepting an increase of salary of £1,500 a- year, which brings his salary to £5,500, and the two members of the board are accepting an increase of £1,250 in their salaries, which have now been brought to £4,500. If those men, who are so anxious and so willing to take such enormous increases of salary, are now stating that they cannot give a paltry increase of £70 and £90 a year respectively to the two groups to which I am referring, on the ground that the country cannot afford it, surely they ought to set a practical example by paying back to the Government a portion of the increases of salaries, for instance of the extra £1,500 which they have received since the making of the regulation of the 23rd December, 1954.

It costs the Postmaster-General's Department more than £1,000 to train a postal clerk and telegraphist, but this outlay is being wasted as telegraphists are refusing to remain in the jobs for which they have been trained at such expense, because of the low range of salaries paid to them. The refusal of the board to negotiate has caused widespread discontent among clerks and telegraphists, so much so that a stoppage of work is inevitable unless the union's grievances are rectified. For the first time in the history of this Commonwealth we are faced, at this moment, with the first real threat that the country's telegraphic communications will be completely held up.

I wish to quote to the House, for the benefit of every member of this Parliament, the decision of the union reached at meetings throughout the Commonwealth. A Melbourne mass meeting last Tuesday demanded a resumption of negotiations, and now awaits the board's reply to decide its course of action. A mass meeting in Sydney on Monday gave the board one week in which to reply to its demand for a resumption of negotiations. A mass meeting in Perth called on the union to abandon negotiations and arbitration and asked the Australian Council of Trades Unions to lead the union in a policy of collective bargaining and direct action as laid down by the 1955 Australian Council of Trades Unions Congress. The Queensland telegraphists actually carried a resolution to hold a stop-work meeting as a protest on the margins position and the board's attitude on the 23rd December, but were advised to hold their hand. The Tasmanian men have conferred with members of the Government and have been assured by Government senators that they have consulted the PostmasterGeneral. All I can say is that the discussions of Liberal senators with the Postmaster-General did not produce very good results, or were not very convincing, judging by the reply that the PostmasterGeneral gave me at question time to-day. The South Australian men had a mass meeting, which the honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin) and I attended, and at which the union's case was fully explained to us. Even senior postal clerks and instructors have been denied the full benefit of the court's metal trades award principle.

Summed up, the union asks for a maximum salary of £1,023 for Third Division telegraphists in lieu of the present salary of £933 and £973 in lieu of the present maximum salary of £903 for postal clerks. This group of the Commonwealth Public Service has never before had to take direct action to secure wage justice, but the board's continued refusal to meet the union in an effort to conciliate will leave these officers with no alternative but to go on strike. Even the amounts claimed by the union will not restore margins to their 1949 percentage of the basic wage. In addition to their loss in margins, Commonwealth public servants are the only government employees, with the exception of those employed by the Liberal Government of South Australia, who do not get the benefit of quarterly cost of living adjustments. On this aspect alone, each and every Commonwealth public servant is losing £39 a year on his present basic wage. Telegraphists are being paid £129 a year less than they should receive, and postal clerks £109 less. Even if they were content to accept the two-and-a-half times formula as a proper method of fixing margins and the amount which they are behind in the basic wage, they are not prepared to tolerate this injustice any longer, and the responsibility for a complete breakdown in telegraphic communications in Australia will rest fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the Public Service Board, and also on the Government if it fails to take appropriate action to insist on justice being done to this most important section of the Public Service.

This is not an idle threat. These men have reached a point where they are not prepared to tolerate any longer the attitude of the Public Service Board in refusing to meet them in a decent, conciliatory spirit. The Government claims to believe in conciliation, but it has shown absolutely no desire to apply conciliation. A government which tells the workers to accept the decisions of the court, or the umpire's decision, and itself refuses to abide by the decision of the Public Service Arbitrator, is not fit to occupy the treasury bench one minute longer.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to come back to the " wailing wall ", and deal with the amendment to the motion for the Address-in-Reply. At the outset, I congratulate my friend and colleague, the honorable member for Perth (Mr. Chaney), on his contribution to this debate. He has injected a great deal of sound common sense into a debate that has been marked by much woolly thinking, particularly by some honorable members opposite. The honorable member laid his finger accurately on the cause of the argument about the disposal of the Commonwealth "Whaling Commission's assets when he directed attention to the fact that a closely fought election is to take place in Western Australia on the 7th April. I hope to show, briefly, that this discussion is a shameless election stunt on the part of the Western Australian Government, with the connivance and co-operation of honorable members on the opposite side of this House.

speech.para: It is well known that for at least three years the Australian Government has been anxious to dispose of the Australian Whaling Commission's enterprise. The Western Australian Government may plead ignorance of that fact, but it would be astonishing if it could produce convincing proof of that ignorance. It is well known at the Australian Whaling Commission property that the Australian Government has been anxious to dispose of this concern. It is well known also that from time to time offers for the purchase of this undertaking have been received and rejected because they were inadequate. If honorable members opposite, and the Western Australian Labour Government, are so deeply and genuinely concerned about their principles of socialism and the value of the people's assets in this particular part of Australia they would have taken up the matter long before a week or two prior to the Western Australian State elections. It is well known that the Western Australian Minister for Fisheries (Mr. Kelly) spends a great deal of his time - indeed has quite, enjoyable holidays - on the Australian Whaling Commission's property. Consequently, he would be well aware of the exact situation over the past three years. Now that the matter is reaching finality, the Western Australian Government has begun to display some sort of fictitious interest in acquiring this property.

As further proof that this discussion is a blatant election stunt, I refer honorable members to the statements made about the proposed offer to the people of the district to enlist their sympathy in this matter. It has been said that this is a profitable concern, and that if the State Government became the owner it would spend all the profits from it doing all sorts of things for the people of Carnarvon and of the northwest districts generally. Any Western Australian government that is aware of its responsibilities to the north-west of the State would do these things regardless of whether it owned a particular asset in that area.

As an illustration, it has been suggested that if the State Government acquires this whaling station it will immediately build an all-weather, sealed surface road from Geraldton to Carnarvon. That is an amazing proposition. Only yesterday, I asked the right honorable the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden) whether there had been any accumulation of federal aid road funds in the hands of the Western Australian Government. I was amazed to learn that at the 30th June last there was more than £1,000,000 unspent money, obtained from this source, in the hands of the Western Australian Government. This is the Government which now says that if it acquires this asset it will spend some money on the road from Geraldton to Carnarvon. Obviously, such a promise is an attempt to whip the feelings of the people of Carnarvon into a frenzy over this issue. When the proposition is closely examined, it is shown to be completely hollow.

Suppose that the Australian Government does not sell the Whaling Commission's enterprise, or that it does sell it to the Western Australian Government? What difference, in terms of hard cash or prosperity or anything else, will it make to the people of Carnarvon if the station carries on its work as efficiently as possible? The only possible difference that it could make if the Government concerned were to operate it inefficiently and spend money extravagantly over a short term would be to place a little mort money in the pockets of the trades people of Carnarvon and the adjacent area. Over a long term it would mean the loss of a valuable asset in the district. If it were to go into the hands of private enterprise, which spent its money wisely in the Carnarvon area, apart from the tendency to operate more efficiently, over a long term it would be a much better proposition for the people of that area.

All this talk about spending money to develop the area if a State government obtained control of the asset is irrelevant to the issue now before us, as is adequately emphasized by the fact that any State government, with a full recognition of its responsibilities to the north-west of
Western Australia, would not make the expenditure of funds for the development of that area dependent on acquiring one asset in the locality.

Honorable members opposite have based a great deal of their argument on the fact that this is an enterprise which is carried on by a government and which operates at a profit. That seems to be the basic standard by which they judge these things. It is a very interesting proposition. Surely the true standard by which to judge these ventures is whether they can operate at a profit comparable with the profit and under the conditions under which private enterprise would operate.

talk.start.para: - How does the honorable member know ?

- How do I know that private enterprise could carry on more efficiently? Let us examine a few figures. The Nor- West Whaling Company, which has operated almost contemporaneously with the Australian Whaling Commission which has the same quota of whales, and which operates under the same regulations, started off with a share capital of £150,000. The Australian Whaling Commission had a capital expenditure of £1,300,000, nearly ten times as much as the capital of the Nor-West Whaling Company. The profits of the Nor-West Whaling Company and the profits of the Australian Whaling Commission have been comparable over the years, but the Nor-West Whaling Company has paid considerable sums in taxation to the Commonwealth, as is shown in the following table : -

speech.para: Those amounts relate to company tax alone. In addition, it has paid to its shareholders a 20 per cent, dividend in each year of its operation, and the revenue which the Commonwealth would derive from these dividends in the hands of shareholders would be a considerable sum.

Admittedly, the Australian Whaling Commission has made high profits but it has not had to pay taxation. If we were to deduct from those profits the sum which the Government would have received by way of taxation if the enterprise had been in the hands of private industry, we can see immediately that the profit to the Commonwealth and to the people of Australia would be considerably reduced. When we consider that the whole of that capital asset is tied up and cannot be used for the benefit of the people of Australia in other directions, we immediately see the wisdom of untying that money, and putting this venture into the hands of private enterprise, which would operate it on an efficient basis. The money derived from the sale of the enterprise could then be used for the functions of the Government, that is, to assist in developing other industries. There is no doubt whatever that an immense field exists for the expenditure of money in research and development by the Government in the north-we3t of Western Australia and, indeed, in the whole of Western Australia. Only recently, I had to approach the Minister in charge of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Mr. Casey) to ask him if, by some means, he -could provide assistance for research into the sperm whaling possibilities in the southern seas. A small whaling company, the Cheynes Beach Whaling Company, has carried on at Albany, and has spent many thousands of pounds in trying to explore the possibility of developing an industry based on the sperm whale in conjunction with its normal activities in producing whale oil from humpback whales. The sperm whale is an entirely different type of mammal from the humpback whale. It produces a different type of oil, and an export market to the value of hundreds of thousands of pounds a year would be offering if the potentialities were adequately exploited.

One great difficulty of the Government is that funds are limited for this purpose. The Minister for Primary Production (Mr. McMahon) made reference to the possibility of developing prawn fishing in the north-west. This is a type of fish which is at the other end of the scale, as it were, from the whale, but it exists in large quantities off the northwest coast of Western Australia, and there is a strong possibility of its being profitably exploited. The assertions by honorable members opposite that the Government, by selling the whaling station, will deprive the people of Australia of an asset are baseless. Let us take that argument to its logical conclusion. We assume that a government enterprise can operate at a profit and we do not make any comparison with the profit rates of private enterprise in similar circumstances. Then we could arrive at the amazing proposition that all industry that could operate profitably, no matter at how small a profit, ought to be in the hands of the Government. The fact that private enterprise might carry on at a larger profit, or more efficiently, would not be justification for private enterprise being allowed to carry on. I ask honorable members opposite if that is not the logical conclusion of the proposition which the honorable member for Wills (.Mr. Bryant), for example, submitted to the House. If that is so, what sort of standard of living would the people enjoy with the Government making a slight profit, temporarily, when private industry could make a much greater profit and operate more efficiently on world markets at lower cost and give an improved standard of living to the people ? Therein lies the complete answer to the woollyheaded socialist doctrines that we have heard uttered by so many honorable members opposite in the course of this debate.

This enterprise, in particular, is one in which no government, even a socialist government, should be engaged because it involves a high degree of risk. Those members who like to consider themselves shareholders in the venture because it happens to be carried on by the Government, do not realize the high degree of risk that does exist in this whaling industry; and I venture to suggest that, as shareholders, they receive very little benefit from it. The honorable member for Perth (Mr. Chaney) drew attention to the fact that Australia supplies a minute percentage of the world supply of whale oil, and is very much at the mercy of world prices and of the large operators on world markets. The price of whale oil has fluctuated during the last few years from £125 a ton down to £50 a ton. From that point of view alone, it is a highly hazardous undertaking.

There is an even worse factor which the honorable member for Perth did not mention, and that is the fact that the whales themselves may no longer be there. The Government, through its research organization and through its investigations and exploratory work, tries to regulate the quota of whales so that the stock may remain constant. Of course, the Government cannot read the mind of a whale. Whales are gregarious mammals which travel in herds along certain; routes. At some stage, very often, something occurs to upset their set habits, and it has been the experience, off the coast of America, that for no known reason, the whales in one season will not follow their previous migratory habits. They have disappeared, and the whole enterprise has gone overnight.

The honorable member for Perth also drew attention to the great hazards resulting from climatic conditions in the northwest, such as the damage that can be wrought by cyclones in that area. The whole of the Whaling Commission's fleet could be destroyed, the whole of its buildings could be blown down, and the whole of its capital assets destroyed overnight. The honorable member for Leichhardt, who is interjecting, does not seem to agree with me, but that happened to the Norwegian station which existed in the north-west some years ago. There is the additional market risk of competition with the by-products from the whaling industry. All these things, added up, do not make it a safe and certain enterprise for a government to risk the taxpayers' money in. Surely, it is more logical to allow private enterprise to ensure against those risks and to apply the asset value of that whaling enterprise to the development of other areas in the north-west or other parts of Western Australia.

There is one further point I wish to mention briefly. A very grave doubt has arisen in my mind as to the constitutional position of the Australian Government in the ownership of this whaling station. The Commonwealth Constitution gives to the Government power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to fisheries in Australian waters beyond territorial limits. If one examines that provision carefully, one will see that that is an express territorial jurisdiction. It gives to the Commonwealth power to make laws with respect to a place or places - fisheries - but not to carry on the function of actively engaging in the industry which affects those fisheries. If the matter were challenged in the High Court I have very grave doubts whether the Commonwealth Whaling Commission would be able to survive. Therefore, at this time when capital is plentiful, surely it is desirable that the Australian Government should realize on this asset to the best advantage instead of waiting, at the mercy of some unscrupulous firm, which might, at a suitable time, challenge the position. In that event the Government would possibly run the risk of losing its asset for a mere song. For those reasons I think that the Australian Government is doing a wise thing in taking this step at this stage.

The very blatant election stunting in which the Government of Western Australia is engaged on this issue is something which should deceive no one in that State. For years the Western Australian Government has known of the possibility of acquiring this asset, and if it really wished to do all the good things for the north-west of Western Australia which it has professed it wished to do but which, for years, it has ignored, it should have acquired it long ago. Now, its promise to spend large sums of money in that area if it can acquire this asset is simply an attempt to whip the people of Western Australia into some sort of excitement or of fear that if this station passes into the hands of private enterprise, the people of Carnarvon will lose something. Nothing could be further from the truth if there is a government in Western Australia which is fully alive to its responsibilities to all sections of the community.

talk.start.para: .- At the outset I would like to congratulate those of my colleagues who entered the Parliament after the last election and who have made such splendid contributions to the debates so far this session.

speech.para: With other honorable members, I feel that they will be a great asset to the Labour party and, I hope, in the very near future, to a Federal Labour government.

talk.start.para: - It is wishful thinking.
- Perhaps it is not. I felt very sorry for the GovernorGeneral when, in opening Parliament, he had to read such an address.
- That has already been said.

- I say it again because, from watching the GovernorGeneral closely as I sat in the Senate chamber, I came to the conclusion that he did not relish his task. Many of the things that he had to say will be found, almost word for word, in previous addresses, and no man of any standing would appreciate that.

speech.para: In his opening remarks His Excellency made special reference to the events that will take place on the 1st July, and the consequences of these for the Senate and the House of Representatives. His Excellency indicated that the Government proposed to call a conference of members from both sides of the Parliament to see whether something could be done to avert the difficulties that would confront the Parliament and the country if this situation continued. The Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) announced after the 1954 election that such a committee would be set up. He failed to carry out the promise that he gave to the people and to the Parliament on that occasion and now sees that his failure to do so will place grave obstacles in his way after the 1st July. I am in complete accord with the proposal to call an all-party conference because I have always felt that when a government is elected by the Australian people it has a right to govern and that no other chamber should be able to upset its legislation. It is a most important issue and one that we must face. If it is agreed that a referendum should be held [ hope that the Australian people will be asked to vote also on the question of the abolition of the Senate.

talk.start.para: - The Labour party had an opportunity to do that when it was in office, but it was not game to do it.

- To say that my party had an opportunity to do something that it now asks the Government to do is sheer humbug. "When Labour was in office it had a war on its hands. From 1945 until it left office, it had to take in hand the work of rehabilitating the nation and returning to civilian life more than 1,000,000 Australians. I remind Government supporters that the parties to which they belong have been in power for most of the 50 odd years since federation. However, that is not of real importance. Is it broadminded to argue that something that is now needed should have been done by a previous government? I suggest that it is not. The situation to-day is completely different. Shortly there will be almost a deadlock in the Senate. Are not responsible Government supporters - if there are any who may be termed responsible - in favour of an elected government having the right to govern ? The Governor-General said -

quote.para: Government expenditure itself must hi: sedulously watched and, wherever possible, pruned. 1 have tried to work out just what is the cost to the Australian taxpayer of the continued existence of the other chamber, which, after all is said and done, is only a party House. Honorable members have seen, on the last night of a session, this House adjourned for half an hour while ten or twelve bills which it has discussed for weeks have been passed by the Senate. Obviously, they cannot have received any consideration. They have simply been Government measures and have been passed quickly with the aid of Government supporters in that House. "What is all this costing the Australian taxpayer? I would estimate that it is costing him at least £500,000 annually. It may be very much more, and if the Government wishes to prune expenditure, here is an opportunity for it to do so. T believe that the Australian elector would he ready and willing to abolish the Senate.

talk.start.para: - Are the senators ready and willing to do so?

- This is not a party matter. I am speaking as one who has been a member of the House of Representatives for about fourteen years. I have always maintained that the Senate has outlived its usefulness. That being so, we should not burden the Australian taxpayer with its upkeep any longer.

speech.para: I would like to mention another way in which the Government could prune expenditure if it wished. I refer to the existence of a one-man party in the Senate. I am not making this a party issue. If a member of the Country party or of the Liberal party broke away from his colleagues and became the sole member of a new party in another chamber I should feel just as strongly on the matter as I do in the present instance. Is it sane that one man should be accepted by tho Parliament as a party? If it meant no more than giving him a party name it might be all right, but it does not end there. If it did I would not mind even ten or twelve honorable members doing the same thing, but the recognition of a party involves the extension of certain privileges which cost the taxpayer thousands of pounds. I understand that the privileges granted to this one-man party include the use of a Commonwealth motor car, the services of a secretary and typist, a room in the Senate quarters of this building and a room in the Commonwealth Parliament offices in the State that he represents. I say in all sincerity that I am not attacking the individual who gets these things; I am attacking the system under which the Australian taxpayer is called upon to carry all these burdens because one man has been recognized as a party in this Parliament. The whole thing could become farcical.

I now ask the members of the Government to tell us whether, if by any chance a Communist had been elected to the Senate at the last general election, as was quite possible, it would have accepted that one Communist as a political party in the Parliament. "Would the Government have given him all the privileges to which the Leader of a party is entitled? I ask that question quite sincerely; but 1 receive no answer from the ranks of the Government. I now ask that question again of the Minister for Territories (Mr. Hasluck), who is at present at the table. Again I receive no reply. Why will not the Government answer that question? I have heard it said that the reason for the peculiar situation that has arisen in which a particular person has been accepted as the Leader of a party and has received all the privileges of a leader, although he has no party, is that it suits the Government. Now, I have some regard for the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), and if by any chance the Government has taken this action to gain some petty party political advantage against the Opposition, then it is no wonder that the general situation throughout Australia is becoming desperate. Once again I ask the Government to answer my question, and I shall put the question again. If a Communist had been elected to this Parliament at the last general election held on the 10th December, would he have been acknowledged as a party, and would he have received all the privileges accorded to the leader of a party?

talk.start.para: - Would he have been entitled to them?
- Certainly, if they are already made available to a one-man party in the Parliament.
- Although he may owe allegiance to a foreign power?

- The honorable member who interjected should know that the Communist party is a legal organization. That is not merely my belief about the Communist party. The Australian electors declared at a referendum that the Communist party is a legal organization. All that I am asking the Government is whether it would accept a single Communist as a party, and as the leader of a party, if he were elected to this Parliament. I hope that it would not.

speech.para: In the present great era of prosperity, when we hear on all sides that the country has never been more prosperous, my mind goes back to another period in our history. In 1926, about eight years after World War I. concluded, this country was going through a period of prosperity similar to that which the Government so often claims is widespread to-day. Yet, in 1929 and 1930 our economic situation was completely changed. I warn honorable members that the economic pattern and the actions of the Government in the economic field today, are similar to the economic pattern and governmental actions in 1926.

After World War I. wheat was required all over the world, and consequently we were able to sell wheat and other primary products in all the world's markets. Moreover, we were able to get good prices for our exported primary goods. Over the last few years our economic pattern has been similar to that. This Government assumed office in 1949 and it has been in office during a period of the most bountiful seasons that we have ever had. We have produced an abundance of wheat, wool and other primary products, and prices have never been higher. All those goods have been required throughout the world up to the present time, but the situation is now slowly changing. If we had said to the people of Australia in 1926 that in 1930 more than 800,000 people out of a population of about 7,000,000 would be on the dole, the people would not have believed us. Yet 800,000 Australians, many of them wearing the badges of ex-servicemen from World War I, were looking for employment in 1930.

In 1926 people thought that such a situation was not possible, but it happened. Then from 1930 almost to the outbreak of World War II. we carried an army of unemployed. For long periods many Australians were on the dole, and many were suffering from malnutrition. Yet throughout that period wheat was rotting in the stacks throughout Australia. Some honorable members might smile at that statement. Perhaps, they did not see the sufferings of the people in those days. I greatly fear that the same situation will again occur in Australia because to-day the economic pattern is similar to the pattern of those days.

At present we see the Government consulting experts, just as the Government did in the 1930's. It appears that the Government is not governing the country ; it is leaving that to the experts. Surely, it is a reflection on the grand men in the public service who have served this country for many years and who are most competent officers, for this Government to call in outsiders to tell it how to run the country. Some of the advisers, whoever they may be, bankers, big businessmen-

talk.start.para: - Or dentists.

- Yes, dentists are very important people in the community - or dentists, or boneheads. The Minister for Social Services (Mr. Roberton) has again given us a glimpse of the stupid approach that this Government adopts towards important matters. So, the financial advisers are brought in, and one of their suggestions is that the supply of money for hire-purchase must be reduced by the financial organizations which undertake that sort of business. They must reduce the supply of money that is required for the purchase of refrigerators, washing machines, radios and other things. No one will ever convince me that a refrigerator is a luxury item, or that every housewife is not entitled to an automatic electric washing machine. I think that those appliances should be installed in a home in the same way as are cooking stoves, or water and sewerage services. But the Government, however, continues to follow its short-sighted policy, and we see the same pattern developing as we saw in former years. If we restrict these industries that produce refrigerators, washing machines and other things that are essential in the homes of to-day, and if we say, " We shall impose restrictions on finance for the purchase of these products on hire purchase agreements what will happen to the industries that produce the refrigerators and other items that are being purchased under hire purchase agreements - and purchased in that way because the workers cannot afford to pay cash for them?
- Where are these industries? Who are the firms making these articles?
- Are there no Australian firms making refrigerators? Are there no Australian firms, employing thousand of Australian workers, making automatic washing machines?
- Tell us who they are.

- The honorable member should know that. I shall mention only a couple of them. These are the firms that make Coldstream and Kelvinator products. It is fantastic that the members of this Government do not appear to know these firms. I do not think they know how many people it would be possible to put out of work by following the Government's policy of reducing finance for the purchase of goods on hire purchase agreements.

speech.para: I sincerely regret that the pattern that we saw in the recession after World War I. appears to be being woven again today. Because of the incompetence of this Government from 1949 to the present time we can now see prospects of another recession in Australia.

talk.start.para: - Nonsense!

- The honorable member says, " Nonsense 1 " I heard the same expression used after World War I. when any one predicted the dire consequences of government mismanagement. I warn the Australian people and this Government that, while honorable members opposite may content themselves by saying " nonsense ", the writing is on the wall. Although the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Holt) said recently that very many employees are required to fill vacant jobs, there is an army of unemployed growing in this country.
- That is rubbish!

- It is all very well for the right honorable gentleman to say " Rubbish ! " I invite him to look round Australia to-day and to examine some of our industries. What is to become of the miners who have been sacked on the coalfields of New South Wales? There are some hundreds of them already. When we direct attention to these things, the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) merely says, "Rubbish ! " There is an army of unemployed growing in this country. I hope that the day is not far distant when the Australian people will realize once and for all that the only party that can govern this country in the interests of Australia and the Australian people is the party which comprises the present Opposition, the Australian Labour party.

.- The speech just delivered by the honorable member for Adelaide (Mr. Chambers) is one that the people of Australia have been listening to during election campaigns since 1949. In that year every one who was associated with the campaign heard all the Labour candidates stumping around the country and saying, " There will be a depression if the Menzies Government is returned". In 1951, no depression had occurred, but there was another election campaign, and again the apostles of gloom in the Labour party stumped around the country and said, " There will be a depression if the Menzies Government is returned". In 1953, there was a Senate election, and again the Labour candidates said, " There will be a depression if the Menzies Government is returned ". But there was no depression. In 1954, again they stumped around the countryside and made the same prediction. We heard it again in 1955. Still, they continue with their prediction, and the people of Australia are sick and tired of hearing it, because they have complete confidence in the economic policy that is being pursued, and will continue to be pursued, by this Government, which has given this country the greatest period of prosperity it has ever known. So much for the contribution to this debate of the honorable member for Adelaide.

speech.para: I should like to join with the other members who paid tribute to the quality of the speeches made by new members on both sides of the House. They have been of an excellent standard, and I believe that every one of those members will be an asset to this Parliament. I was particularly interested in the speech delivered by the honorable member for Hughes (Mr. L. R. Johnson). He took, as the basis of his contribution to the debate, the subject of housing, and he repeated what we are so used to hearing, that the poor State governments have been starved by the Menzies Government for funds and so have not been able to do the job that they would like to do in the field of housing. We know that the State governments have used this as the excuse for their own ineptitude and their own failings. If anybody doubts that, I hope that to-night I shall be able to convince them that the States have failed to shoulder their own responsibilities. In order to do so, I have only to trace the course of one project which was carried out under the terms of the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement. We know that, in 1945. a socialist government introduced socialist legislation, which was known as the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement legislation, which led to the State governments becoming great landlords, owning the houses and demanding rental from the people based on a formula which was concocted by the Labour Premiers and the Labour Minister and Prime Minister of the day. That formula demanded a certain amount as rental, based on the capital cost of the home. The prime consideration in assessing the rent was the capital cost of the home. That is an important factor to consider. Under the terms of that agreement, the Commonwealth was required to find the money to finance the States in carrying out these housing projects. There was not enough money available on the loan market to supply the States, and so the Commonwealth, through this Menzies Government, forwent any share of the loan moneys. Not only did it do that, but it supplemented the money that it gave to the States from its own revenue. That money has not always been honestly used by the States. They have been completely irresponsible in their use of it. I make that statement, and in order to prove its accuracy, I shall deal with the Zillmere estate in Queensland.

talk.start.para: - What, again*

- Yes. Honorable members will recall that this matter was raised some time ago, but there have been considerable developments since then. It will be recalled that, in 1950, this Government introduced the States' Grants (Imported Houses) Bill. That legislation was supplementary to the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement. The bill, which became an act, provided that the Australian Government was to assist the States by granting them a subsidy payment of £300 on every house that was imported and erected. I wish to read portion of section 3 of the act, which states - " Costs in relation to imported houses, means the sum of the costs incurred or to be incurred in obtaining, transporting, importing and erecting the houses.

speech.para: I put emphasis on the words " erecting the homes " because that is particularly relevant to what I have to say. With the introduction of that measure, the

Queensland Government arranged to purchase a total of 8S6 pre-cut houses from France. Those houses were to be erected at Zillmere. In 1952, in this House, the matter of the irresponsible attitude of the Queensland Government's administration oi' this scheme was raised, and a report was obtained by officers of the Commonwealth who were sent to Queensland to carry out the investigation. The report that was submitted to this Parliament by those officers included these words -

quote.para: There is justifiable doubt that the Commonwealth Government is getting a satisfactory result from its advances under the CommonwealthState Housing Agreement and its subsidy payments under the States Grants (Imported Houses) Act 1950.

speech.para: Honorable members will recall that the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) made a statement on the matter in this House. Subsequently, more officers from the Commonwealth experimental building station were sent to Queensland to carry out an investigation. Again their report was submitted to the Parliament, and again we learned that there had been a most serious challenge to the responsibility of the Queensland Government in carrying out its obligations to the nation, because it was reported that there was great doubt whether the Australian Government was getting an adequate return for the money invested in this housing project.

We move from there to the date on which the Queensland Minister for Housing found that he was coming under fire from this Parliament and made a statement that, because Queensland was a sovereign State, it would refuse to allow any further investigation of the Zillmere project to be carried out until the project was completed. Towards the end of 1955, a report was received in Canberra that the project was completed. It was then time for the Australian Government to send officers to Queensland to carry out their final inspection, and that was done.

The inspection was carried out against this background: On the 30th June, 1952, the Queensland Government had received a subsidy payment of £300 a house on no fewer than 850 houses because it had furnished to the Australian Government a statement that those houses had been shipped to Australia. Nobody denied that they had, but the Queensland Auditor-General submitted an audit certificate stating that the houses had been shipped from France on ships which ha named. He also gave the date of arrival of those ships in Brisbane.

The responsible Commonwealth Minister at that time wrote to Queensland, notwithstanding the fact that the subsidy payment had been made on 850 houses, and asked that the Queensland Auditor-General certify that the houses had been erected in Australia. No reply was received for five months. The fact is that some of those houses, if they arrived in Australia, have disappeared, and nobody knows where they are to-day. I am not referring to all the houses. I wish to correct any impression honorable members may have that I am talking about all of the 886 houses. I do not suggest that all have disappeared, but a very substantial number has disappeared, and cannot be found.

On the 7th August, 1955, the Queensland Minister for Housing, in a broadcast and in a press statement, admitted himself that 812 houses of French origin were involved in this matter of subsidy payments to the States under the States Grants (Imported Houses) Act. When the allegations were made that all of those houses could not be found in Queensland, the Commonwealth officers who went to Queensland made a specific check of a great number of the houses there and the report, as is evident in th° statement made by the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) yesterday, showed that a substantial number of the houses built there are constructed entirely of Australian materials. Some of the houses contain 80 to 90 per cent, of Australian materials, and others have substantial proportions of Australian material. That suggests that somewhere and some time after the houses were shipped from France, a substantial number disappeared, and the Queensland Government had substituted in their place Australian houses. It then claimed from the Commonwealth the subsidy on those houses.

talk.start.para: - A fraud?
- An honorable member has suggested that this was a fraud.
- Another conspiracy.

- The honorable member for East Sydney claims that this is a conspiracy to defraud. It could be such a conspiracy. A physical examination will show that the houses about which I am speaking are not to be found at Zillmere. When the Queensland Minister for Housing was challenged on this matter, Le replied that the houses were shipped from France and that the AuditorGeneral's certificate proved that they were. He further stated that an officer employed by his department in France to supervise the shipping of the houses saw that the houses were shipped, and certificates have been furnished to prove that they were shipped to Australia. But the Minister does not claim that he has the houses to-day. In fact, according to the statement made by the Minister for National Development in this Government, the Queensland Government denied that proof of the erection or possession of the houses is relevant to the payment of the subsidy. The Queensland Government is now insisting that, nothwithstanding the fact that the houses have disappeared, it is entitled to the full subsidy of £300 for each house on the ground that they were shipped from France. Does that suggest that there has been responsibility in the handling of this matter? I suggest that it does not.
- Did the houses arrive in Queensland ?

- That is a question that the honorable member might direct to the Queensland Minister for Housing. I would be pleased to receive an answer from him showing that the houses were, or were not, in Queensland, but it is his responsibility to say where they are.

speech.para: Throughout the construction of this housing project, it must be remembered that the Queensland Government notified the Australian Government on only a few occasions that it was short of materials, and asked for permits to substitute Australian building materials. I have the list showing the occasions on which that happened. This shows the dates on which approval for the substitution was given. On the 19th February, 1952, the Queensland Government asked for permission from the Commonwealth, and received it, to substitute Australian for French materials insofar as the steps, sills, plates and bearers were concerned. On the 5th December, 1952, permission was given to the Queensland Government, at its request, to substitute for French material Australian asbestos cement to the quantity of 875 sheets. This had been damaged by fire. On the 4th March, 1953, permission was given to replace the weather board on the exteriors of fourteen houses with imported asbestos cement and that approval also was given, but when an inspection was carried out, not only were those substitutes found but throughout the area, there was such an immense number of substitutes that it is impossible at this stage, without a complete and thorough examination of the project, to say exactly what materials have been substituted. An inspection that has been carried out indicates that substitution has taken place to a very substantial degree.

This leads to two points. First, has the money that was provided under the terms of the States Grants (Imported Houses) Act - that is, the £300 subsidy - been paid on imported houses which have been erected in the country ? If there are only about 800 instead of 886 imported houses at Zillmere, then I cannot see that the Queensland Government is entitled to claim subsidy payment on 886 houses, as it has done. When challenged on this, the Queensland Minister and his commissioner admit that all the houses are not of French origin, that a number of them are of Australian origin, but they still claim that the Queensland Government is entitled to the subsidy on the ground that the houses were shipped from France. If they have tried to obtain a subsidy until now, when the Commonwealth inspection has revealed that the substitutes were carried out, knowing full well, as they must have, that under the act they were not entitled to it, is that honest, or is that fraud, or an attempt to defraud the Commonwealth Government of money? Is it an attempt by the Queensland Government to demand money to which it was not entitled and to conceal from the Commonwealth the fact that some of those houses have disappeared ?

Let us move from there to the second point that is involved. The subsidy payments might involve a matter of only tens of thousands of pounds, but what of the houses that are missing? If there were only 40 houses missing - I know beyond doubt there are more than 40 houses missing - and the average cost of those houses is £2,500, then we can say that there is £100,000 of the taxayers' money which cannot be accounted for by the Queensland Government, the Queensland Treasurer, the Queensland Minister for Housing or the Queensland Commissioner for Housing, the people who are charged with the responsibility of handling these funds. The loss of 40 houses would mean the loss of £100,000. But it is more than that. It is, without any doubt, vast sums more than that. Forty houses at least! But I am prepared to suggest that the number involved would be almost double that figure.

I suggest that, in addition to the absence of the houses - and the absence of the number suggested means the disappearance of £200,000 of the taxpayers' money - there are a great number of other items which should have been imported and installed in the houses when they were erected. Prime cost items and hardware, which were supposed to come in with the houses either did not arrive, or were never used and disappeared after they arrived - that is, if they did come to the country - because substitutions in these fields occurred in regard to some items in every house on the project. That being so, let us suggest as a minimum that the amount of taxpayers' money which cannot be accounted for by the Queensland Government might be £250,000.

talk.start.para: - The figure is rising.

- Yes. What is the position? Tens of thousands of pounds have been claimed by the Queensland Government from the Commonwealth under the States Grant (Imported Houses) Act, to which the Queensland Government was not entitled, and hundreds of thousands of pounds of the taxpayers' money made available under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has disappeared. When the Queensland Minister for Housing has been asked to answer these questions, he has deliberately avoided giving any answer. He has tried to cover up with a smoke screen of excuses and other suggestions and, whilst not denying that the houses are not there, he suggests that the Commonwealth Government still has a. responsibility to find the money because the houses were shipped. When any government is so irresponsible in the handling of the taxpayers' money that hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of materials disappear, it is fair for people to ask whether that Government has been completely honest in its administration. We do not know where the houses are. Perhaps a mistake was made, and they were never shipped from France, even though the Queensland Minister for Housing swears time and time again that they were. Perhaps they did land in Australia. If they did, then the taxpayers of Australia are entitled to know where those houses have gone. They are entitled to know whether the houses have been sold. They are entitled to know whether the houses have just disappeared, in smoke. They are entitled to ask the Minister to explain, and we, as the Commonwealth Government, have a responsibility to demand from the Queensland Government a complete answer to these questions, because the sum of money which is involved is so vast. The evidence is so substantial. In addition to the statutory declaration which is in the hands of the Leader of the Liberal party in Queensland, we have the results of the inquiries made, and the physical inspection carried out by the officers of the Commonwealth, who included an architect from the Department of National Development and an architect from the Department of Works in Queensland. Those two independent individuals who carried out this inspection furnished a report and substantiated the claims that have been made in this statutory declaration. The evidence is such that it is beyond dispute that a great number of these houses cannot be accounted for by the Queensland Government.

speech.para: I regard this matter as being so serious that I believe there is a responsibility on this Government, because it accepted responsibility under the terms of the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement for finding the money and handing it to the States tq be expended. This

Government kas a responsibility to demand, or take legal action to make absolutely certain that the people of this country are acquainted with what has happened to that building material. 1 believe that this Government has to take action on both counts. It has a responsibility to take steps to obtain repayment of the money which the Queensland Government has obtained and to which it is not entitled. It must also take action either by way of judicial inquiry, or some other means, .to ensure that all the facts are revealed, so that the people of Queensland may be able to judge whether they have a government which is responsible, whether they have a government which is irresponsible, or whether they have a government which is downright dishonest. These things can be determined only by a judicial inquiry, and since Queensland will be faced with a State election at a date which has not yet been announced, I suggest that there is a responsibility on the Premier of Queensland to ensure that the date of that election is not announced, and that the election is not held until such time as a satisfactory answer to all these questions has been given to the people, and the people themselves are satisfied as to the integrity of the Government concerned.

Hr. GEORGE LAWSON (Brisbane) |S.48|. - I am pleased to have the opportunity of following the honorable member for Lilley (Mr. Wight). His tirade of abuse and of charges and countercharges against the Queensland Government, and against the. Queensland Minister for Housing in particular, are no more than one would expect from him, because he has admitted that the Queensland Government is facing an election. The charges made by him to-night are prompted by nothing more nor less than political motives in the hope of damaging the Queensland Labour Government.

This is nothing new. We have had it from the honorable member for Lilley for a number of years. We are sick and tired of it. Unfortunately, I am not in a position to refute the charges and counter-charges he has made here to-night, although I was always in a position to do so during previous debates. The honorable member for Lilley mentioned that the Leader of the Liberal party in

Queensland has already taken this matter up. Of course he has ! I inform the honorable member through you, Mr. Speaker, that the Queensland Minister for Housing has issued a writ against Mr. Morris, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in that State.

talk.start.para: - What for?
