- The honorable member for Petrie (Mr. Hulme) asks, "What for?" He knows what for, as he has made charges similar to those made by the honorable member for Lilley here tonight. However, I shall make no further comment on this matter at the moment, because I am quite sure that the Queensland Minister for Housing, and the Premier of Queensland will deal with those charges in their own way.

speech.para: I turn now to the Governor-General's Speech, and to my mind it was similar to other speeches that have been prepared bv this Government and read by His Excellency. In my opinion, the Speech contained nothing of importance bearing on the serious plight in which this Government has landed Australia's economy. Indeed, I regard it as one of the most futile opening speeches that have ever been delivered in this Parliament.

At this stage, I desire to add my quota of congratulations to those which have been already extended to the new members on both sides of the House upon their speeches, not only for their excellence of construction, but also for the manner in which they were presented. I consider that, by and large, the speeches of our new members were equal, if not superior, to all other maiden speeches that I have heard delivered in this House during my lengthy Parliamentary career. Without a doubt, our new members are a valuable acquisition by the Parliament.
His Excellency stated in the second paragraph of his Speech -

quote.para: My advisers believe that the relations between the two Houses should be reviewed . . . They will, therefore, propose the setting up of an all-party committee of both Houses to investigate the constitutional problems which may be referred to it. One of these problems is that of the Senate and its powers and the procedure to be followed in the event of a dispute between the two Houses.

speech.para: Is other Words, the Government intends to appoint, an all-party committee to deal with the position that exists in the Senate. It is true, as the honorable member for Adelaide (Mr. Chambers) has said, that the position in that chamber is most unsatisfactory from the Government's point of view. I am one of those persons who have always believed that the people's House is the House of Representatives, because the people decide by their election of honorable members which political party or coalition of parties shall govern the country for the ensuing three years.

If the Government experiences any difficulty in having its legislation passed by the Senate during the life of this Parliament, a certain amount of blame will rest on the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) himself, because his efforts during the general election campaign assisted a member of the splinter party to gain election to the third Senate vacancy in Victoria. I well remember reading in the press - and I feel sure that other honorable members not only read in the press but also heard over the air - that the Prime Minister, from a number of platforms, had praised the alleged anti-Communist party; and he stated that he admired its attitude in fighting for what he termed a principle. I do not think that the right honorable gentleman had any sympathy with that party at all, but that he praised it because he knew that the AntiCommunist Labour party's second preferences would be given to Liberal and Country party candidates. The Prime Minister was reported to have stated that he was sure that the Liberal and Country parties would gain a majority in every State. Little did the right honorable gentleman think at the time that if the Liberal and Australian Country parties were returned to office, the Government would be faced with a not altogether hostile Senate, but a Senate in which members of the Anti-Communist Labour party would have great power.

talk.start.para: - The Prime Minister must have had a big influence on the electors.

- He had sufficient influence to be able to persuade many electors on that score. However, T am pleased to have an opportunity to state the opinions that I have held for a long time in relation to the Senate. The framers of the Constitution endeavoured to ensure that the Senate would be a States' house, but except at the beginning, it has never been anything like a States' house or a people's house. Immediately after the first Senate election was held, that chamber became a party house, and it has remained a party house ever since. We know what has happened over a long period of years. I contend that when this people elect a government with an overwhelming majority in the House of Representatives, that government should be able to pass, and give effect to, its legislation without being hampered or hindered by another place. When a deadlock occurred between this House and the Senate in 1951, I would have liked to see the Government take the matter further and do what the honorable member foi1 Adelaide has said he would have liked it to do, instead of obtaining a double dissolution. I well remember the events that occurred in this Parliament in 1929. When supporters of the BrucePage Government, which had been in office for about six years and held a majority in both Houses, fell out and engaged in a dispute on the floor of the House, that Government was defeated by some of its own supporters, and was forced to the country on a single dissolution. Subsequently, the Scullin Government was returned to office with almost as big a majority as the present, Menzies Government enjoys. What did that Government find? It found that Australia was on the verge of bankruptcy, financially and economically. When the Scullin Government inquired into Australia's financial position a week or two after it took office, it found that the overseas trade balance was below the danger level, and that there was not suffic]ent money in the Commonwealth Treasury to pay public servants their current fortnight's salary and age and invalid pensioners their current fortnight's pension. It, introduced legislation to overcome these difficulties, but what happened ? The anti-Labour majority in the Senate rejected practically every measure that was introduced by the Scullin Government. The same sort of thing has happened since. especially since the present method of voting at Senate elections was introduced. In 1951, when Labour had a majority in the Senate and the Menzies Government had a majority in this House, certain legislation was delayed, and a double dissolution was obtained in. an attempt to remedy the position. As time goes on, matters get worse. As I stated earlier, I believe the time for something to he done is long overdue. However, in the last paragraph at page 1 of the printed copy of the .GovernorGeneral's Speech, we find this sentence, referring to the Government -

quote.para: They are of opinion that should agreement he reached by the suggested committee-

speech.para: That is the committee that the Government proposes to appoint - the electors may be more disposed to vote for any constitutional amendment which would subsequently be submitted to the electors by referendum.

I sincerely hope that no such palliative referendum will ever -be submitted to the people by this Government, because I believe the Senate is nothing more nor less than an obstructionist, futile and obsolete -House, and a financial 'burden on the community. I say that bearing in mind that I have some very 'fine colleagues in that, House. But when it comes to a question of .principle, I forget individuals. I view this matter from the viewpoint of ;the interests of the people and Australia as a whole. .Government supporters, by way of interjection, :have asked why the 'Labour Government did not abolish, or attempt to abolish, the Senate. Those questions have been very ably answered by the honorable member for Adelaide. Government supporters have asked also what was the attitude of the Australian Labour party to the abolition of the Senate. I want to tell honorable members opposite that every Labour member of the Senate has signed a pledge which clearly indicates that Labour believes in the abolition of the Senate.

talk.start.para: - But they left it at home in 1949 when they increased the size of the Senate.

- Notwithstanding the observations of the honorable member for Canning, I venture to say that, if a vote on the question were taken, every Labour member of the Senate would vote for its abolition. I personally am very keen to see it abolished.
- It would have to be a secret ballot.

- I do not care what sort of ballot might be adopted. We have only to look at the example of our sister dominion of New Zealand, where a Liberal government abolished the upper house. The present Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr. Holland, at a function in Canberra only the other day, stated that he did not regret the attitude ,he had adopted in supporting the abolition of the upper house. The Senate is no different from the erstwhile upper house in New Zealand and the upper houses in the State Parliaments. Last Thursday afternoon, the honorable member for Griffith (Mr. .Coutts) stated that I had voted in support. qf a proposal to abolish the former Queensland Legislative Council. I make no apology for my action. When I had the opportunity to voice my opinion and to vote for the abolition of a State upper house, I willingly, did so. Nothing gave me greater pleasure than my part .in voting for the abolition of a .useless upper house in Queensland. I consider that the upper house in every State is useless.
- The honorable member was a member of the house that it was proposed to abolish.

- I was. I maintain that the Senate also is a useless chamber. The remarkable thing is that no .non-Labour .government in. Queensland has ever proposed, either in the course of its administration or in an election policy speech, the restoration of the Queensland Legislative Council. -The Queensland Parliament has worked admirably with a single house, and no one has ever questioned that.
-(Hon.Archie Cameron). - Order! The honorable gentleman's. time has expired.

.- In speaking in support of the motion for the adoption of the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech, I am honoured to be. associated with the expression of loyalty to our most gracious Sovereign .Queen Elizabeth the Second.

speech.para: As a new member of the House, I, like many others of the newly elected members, am deeply conscious of the trust that has been placed .in all of us and of the responsibility that is our privilege. 1 take this opportunity to thank the electors of Phillip for the confidence they have placed in me, and to assure them that I am at all times at their service as their representative.

As I passed through King's Hall to take my seat in the Parliament for the first time, many great Australians, immortalized by painter or sculptor, looked down upon me. I, in turn, look to them with the thought that their revered memory is preserved in paint -and canvas, marble and bronze, and in the many deeds that have contributed so much to the great democracy in which we live - deeds that are an example to all Australians as the heirs to the nation that these men helped to build. But to us in this Parliament especially, they present an ideal of service to our country which must be . a continuing inspiration to all of us who come after them. We have had many great nation-builders in the past, and, when the history of more recent times is written, it will be seen that none is more entitled to the gratitude of all sections of the Australian people than is our present Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies). The people of Australia once again declared their faith and trust in him by the magnificent vote of confidence in the Government and in his leadership last December. The history of Australia, by comparison with that of other countries, is a brief one, but none the less interesting and inspiring. I should like to see the history of our great country :i good deal more publicized, and a greater emphasis placed upon the deeds and achievements obtained in such a short space of time, as it is a history of which we can all be proud. The Australian people have never failed to answer any call that has been made upon them, and now that we are taking an increasingly important part in world affairs, the role of the average Australian, the man in the street, is more important than ever before. The worker on a weekly wage, the man on a fixed salary, the small business man, the grocer on the corner, of the street, the small manufacturer pr producer, the young man or woman who wishes to own a home, are all in turn being harassed by the control on credit liquidity and the effect of continuing import restrictions. Their burden is an ever-increasing one. These people are deeply concerned, not only with their immediate future, but .also with their children's future and that of the nation. They are the people who will play the main part in overcoming the problems which confront any government. It is 'through them that the Government's policy will be successfully implemented. These problems, of which we are all aware, will be the more easily surmounted if the importance of every individual Australian's part is fully .recognized. If the people understand the policies of governments and why any particular legislation is needed, I believe that they will cooperate with the governments for the benefit of the nation. I urge the Government to take the people into its confidence and prior to, where possible, or at the time of enactment of legislation, explain in plain and simple language why the legislation is necessary, and the benefits to be expected from it. I believe that by so doing the Government will not only maintain the confidence of the people but also give them a greater real interest in the nation's affairs and help to develop a truly national spirit in Australia.

An awakening of the cause of Australian nationalism would be of immense benefit to our country in every one of our national problems and activities. I have sufficient confidence in the Australian people to believe that they will not be found wanting in their readiness to assist the Government, and I believe that people are entitled to an explanation, and not only the implementation, of legislation. Since 1949 the Government has pursued a prudent economic policy, which has brought to our country a prosperity greater than any ever previously enjoyed here. It is the duty of governments, not only to preserve and defend this prosperity, but also, if possible, to improve it. Prosperity is not without its problems. We are confronted with labour shortages in almost every industry and with high costs and scarcity of materials in many industries. Our rapidly increasing population, our natural expansion as a young and vigorous country, the necessity to forge ahead with national projects such as the SnowyMountains scheme and the Australian Aluminium Production Commission's works at Bell Bay, and our provision for defence, have all contributed to these difficulties. But who would deny that our defences and development ;.re most necessary? Obviously, a balance between the supply of and the demand for our resources must be achieved, and the Government's intention to preserve this balance was made clear in the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General.

Our overseas funds are low. Our wheat industry is faced with a surplus and with keen competition from Canada, the United States, and the Argentine. These three countries and Australia combined hold a two-years supply of wheat for world demand. Our wool payments have fallen in comparison with those of recent years. These are matters for very grave concern. The Government's policy in the past has been directed towards conserving our overseas funds, and this policy will be continued. But, in addition, the decision to establish a Ministry of Trade and a Ministry of Primary Industry, and the plan to introduce an export credit insurance scheme, are positive steps towards rectifying our balance of payments position. We must increase production and reduce costs, and this is not to be achieved simply by calling for a greater effort on the part of either employer or employee. All sections of the community must work together for greater efficiency in management and production. I am sure that we can achieve our aims if thu Australian people work together in the. consciousness that they are taking part, as members of a team, in a national effort to maintain and increase a prosperity to be shared by all.

Our arbitration system is interwoven with industrial relations, and it seems imperative as a means of promoting production and peace in industry that some, streamlining of the procedure now operating is necessary, so as to provide a speedier channel whereby employees and employers may more readily negotiate. These matters, while of the utmost importance, can and will be solved by means which are in our own hands. We can and will surmount our economic difficulties, but unless we have a vigorous and adequate defence programme the benefits so accruing could well be of no avail. Our country must not be an easy prey for those who look upon us from outside our shores with envy, or for those within the country who owe allegiance to foreign powers. In Asia there is a huge problem -a man-power potential more than sufficient to annihilate us, or races most of whose members are uneducated, who are in many cases impoverished and in indigent circumstances. These are the prerequisites for successful infiltration by communism. A programme of indoctrination and intimidation is now in force - the stirring up of racial hatreds, the anti-British campaigns by Communist agents, the dissemination of the idea that the Asian races are under-privileged by reason of European colonization. In Indonesia there is strong agitation for the right to Dutch New Guinea. In Singapore schools English is a secondary language, and the students are being taught to look upon red China, nol Malaya, as their motherland. The Mao plan envisages that by 1960 China's military, economic and industrial strength will be such that it will be able to "liberate" Indo-China, Thailand and Burma. Thereafter, the "liberation " of Indonesia is to be completed. If this is achieved, an arc of Communist-controlled countries will be formed around the Malay Peninsula. The pattern is clear, and if the Western nations, including Australia, do not combine to play their part vigorously, we could be engulfed in the all-too-rapid Communist drive toward* us. This pattern, and the nearness of those countries, is a problem which has to be faced. It is a matter that concerns every Australian. Years ago, we were taught at school that in our isolation we were safe, but with the advent of modern times and modern science, that security has gone.

Those of us who have spoken to new Australians, people who have brought from many lands the culture of older nations and who will, in the future, play an ever-increasing part in our community, know full well the terrifying experiences, and the lack of principle and tolerance, that follow when authority is thrust upon a people by Communist aggression. To avoid this happening in our nation, we must prepare for all eventualities. We must make it perfectly clear that, while it is our earnest desire to live in peace, we shall not countenance intimidation from any quarter. We must reaffirm our intention to adhere to our immigration policy, which, from the very beginning, has been designed to preserve our cultural and political heritage, our democratic way of life and our high living standards. In other words, I believe that the Australian people will not tolerate any policy which will allow the infiltration into this country of people who are not prepared to preserve the high standards of civilization, now the cherished tradition of our people.

During the last few years, we have heard and read a great deal about Communist aggression, and the need for defence. It has become commonplace, and the average person tends to regard such talk as a figment of the minds of politicians. The cunningly devised cold war, and the continual reiteration by Communist leaders that they want peace, have had, in some places, the desired effect of cultivating increasing complacency amongst people of the democracies. Nothing could be more disastrous. If our nation is to be more readily defended, it, is necessary to awaken in Australia a more vigorous nationalism, a more acute awareness of the threats to our democratic way of life. It could well be that a different trend of thought would then emerge in our country; an eagerness to preserve our cherished freedom from within by keeping our economic position strong, and by assisting the Government in its request for efficiency in management, greater production, and restraint in spending, together with an eagerness to defend Australia from the threat of Communist aggression, from within and also from without.

We cherish our heritage, our country and our democracy. We should be willing to face more readily the responsibility of supporting further defence and economic measures if we were taken into the confidence of the Government and asked to participate in and become an integral part of any future defence scheme. Our economic position is linked inevitably with our defence problems. They go hand in hand. A call to the nation in the words of Alexander Pope may well be made: "Act well your part, there all the honour lies ".

talk.start.para: . - I take this opportunity to thank the electors of Stirling for having elected me to represent that new electoral division. While I am in this chamber, I hope to do my best in their interests and, by doing so, also to further the interests of the Australian people generally. It is because I am concerned about the interests of the people of the devision of Stirling, and of the Commonwealth generally, that I strongly oppose the decision of this Government to dispose of the assets of the Australian Whaling Commission at Carnarvon. I oppose that proposal because the whaling venture is a profitable one, and I contend that those profits could be utilized in the interests of the people, and not handed over to a private concern. As a matter of fact, it was only as a result of the probings of members of the Opposition in this House that the intention of the Government to sell this Government-owned enterprise was finally revealed.

- It is of no use honorable members opposite saying that this is not the case. They should remember that, only this week, when a question was asked about this matter the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) did not then say that the whaling venture was to be sold. Questions had to be put to him on several occasions before he finally admitted that that was so. Then, he had the audacity to say that certain interested parties had been consulted.
- lt was known three years ago.

- Similar moves -may have been made three years ago. It was in 1952, or approximately three years ago, that the Minister told the Government of Western Australia that he intended to sell the venture. That was a Liberal Government, which the Minister knew would not be interested, because the political beliefs of that Government were similar to those of the present Australian

speech.para: Government on the subject of government enterprises. But when there is a Labour government in- office in Western Australia, the Minister does not bother to include that government amongst the interested parties. It is left out of the picture altogether.

The fact is, of course, that the Labour Government, of Western Australia is interested in purchasing these assets, and when it heard the rumours that were floating round in regard to the matter, as a result of pressure that had been brought to bear on the Australian Government, mainly by honorable members on this side of the House, the Premier of Western Australia made some inquiries. The Minister for Trade admitted that it was only last week that he received a letter from the Premier of Western Australia inquiring about the matter and asking the Minister would the Australian Government give the Western Australian Government until the 31st March, so that the State Government could go into the matter with a view to securing an option to purchase. The Minister for Trade said that the Australian Government would not give the Western Australian Government until 31st March, but would give it until the 15th March - a mere sixteen days - in order to allow the Western Australian Government to go into the proposal.

The position, of course, is that the Australian Government does not intend to dispose of the assets to the Western Australian Government. This Government knows already to whom it is going to dispose of the venture. It is to be disposed of to the Nor-West Whaling Company Limited. The very monopoly that the honorable member for Perth (Mr. Chaney) was concerned about, in his remarks earlier to-day, is about to take place. When that occurs, NorWest Whaling Company Limited will control the whole of the whaling operations in Western Australia. Instead of its quota of whales being 500, as it is now, ultimately it will be 1,000 whales, because it will take over the quota of the Australian Whaling Commission as well. Consequently, the profits of £200,000 per annum, which rightly belong to the people, will go into private enterprise.

If the. Labour Government of Western Australia could obtain control of this venture, it would, use those profits in the interests of the people of. Australia. As a matter of. fact, the Premier of Western Australia, Mr. Hawke, has already indicated that his Government would De prepared to use those profits to do something for the people of the north-west, such as extricating the banana planters from some of their water difficulties, or sealing the road from Carnarvon to Northampton, a 230 mile stretch of road along which may be seen piles of tyres and tubes, indicating how rough, it is and what a horror stretch it is. Work of that kind would be of advantage not only to the people of the north-west, but also to the people of Western Australia generally. This matter has been ventilated fairly thoroughly in the House and I do not want to dwell on it at any length.

During the remainder of my time, 1 prefer to deal with the Speech made by the Governor-General at the opening of the Parliament, a Speech prepared for His Excellency by the Government. It did- not contain very much meat into which one could get one's teeth, but certain features of it require some comment. The most important portion of it, as far as I could see, was that which dealt with the economic difficulties of Australia. True, it only glossed over them. It did not offer any remedy for our economic ills. It mentioned them and then passed over them. In order to analyse the situation that has developed in Australia during the last few months, we should look back on the events that led up to it. If ever a government should stand condemned for destroying the Australian economy in the interests of big financial institutions, this Government should stand condemned. There is no question about that. The actions of the present Government parties, not only since they have been in power, but also before they took up the reins of office in 1949, have conformed to a plain pattern. Honorable members opposite who are without bias in these matters will agree that during the war years the Australian economy was more stable than that of any other country. Australia was the envy of every other country in the world then. That was the position also during the immediate post-war years.

In 1948, the National Security Regulations ceased to apply. As Commonwealth prices control depended upon those regulations, it was necessary for the government of the day to take a referendum of the people, seeking an amendment of the Constitution to enable the Commonwealth to continue to control prices. The present Government parties misled the people and urged them to record " No " votes. The people were sick of controls, as was only natural after many years of controls. They looked for something better, so the referendum was defeated. As a result, the administration of prices control reverted to the States, but, because of divided authority, the control was not so efficient as the unified control exercised by the Commonwealth. Finally, prices control became almost useless, although it retained some value. That was the first disaster that befell the Australian economy.

The second disaster occurred when the Chifley Government was defeated in 1949, because from then onwards inflation in Australia began to run riot. There were lulls now and again, but, generally speaking, there was a headlong rush towards inflation. If any honorable member wants proof of that statement, let him look at the way in which prices have increased during the years that this Government has been in office. A strong criticism of the Government's administration was contained in the "World Economic Report of 1952-53, which analysed the price increases that had occurred in Europe, the United States of America and Australia. It was pointed out in the report that, between 1950 and 1953 - the first three years of office of this Government - prices in Europe and America rose by an average of 15.6 per cent., compared with an average rise in Australia over the same period of 48 per cent.

I tried to get some figures to enable me "to make a similar comparison at a later period, but unfortunately I could not do so. However, I have been able to get some figures which show how prices have risen in Australia and in other Englishspeaking countries. They are contained in a letter from the Acting Commonwealth Statistician, dated the 24th February. The information supplied to me by the Acting Commonwealth Statistician assumes a base figure of 100 at the December quarter of 194-9. In the December quarter of 1955, the figure for Australia was 166, showing that prices here had risen by 66 per cent, during that period. By the September quarter of 1955, prices in the United States of America had increased by 14 per cent., and in Canada by 16 per cent. Those were the latest figures available in respect of these two countries. By the December quarter of 1955, prices in the United Kingdom had increased by 37 per cent., and in New Zealand by 41 per cent. Those figures show how inflation has run riot in Australia as a result of the mismanagement and maladministration of the country by this Government.

For whose benefit were prices control and other controls thrown overboard? They were thrown overboard for the benefit of big business interests generally, because big business wanted to make profits which it could not make while an effective system of prices control was in operation. It did not matter to honorable gentlemen opposite that the value of margins was decreasing steadily, that basic wage increases were lagging three months behind price increases and that social services benefits were constantly deteriorating in value. Not only did the Government parties commit that act of treachery to Australia, but also they suggested to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court that the basic wage be pegged. They applauded the decision of the court by which the basic wage was pegged, although it meant that the workers would be in a worse position than previously. The quarterly adjustments made previously had lagged three months behind price increases, but the workers had received the benefit of some increases, whereas, after the decision of the court to peg the basic wage, they received no increases at all. As a result, the value of the basic wage has been steadily decreasing. It is true that in some States controlled by Labour governments automatic adjustments of the basic wage have been re-introduced, in some States by the action of the Government and in others by the action of a State industrial tribunal.

Then we reached the stage when margins came up for review. What happened then? First, there was a great deal of opposition to the restoration of the value of margins. Finally, the two and a half times the 1937 margins formula was applied, hut even that did not raise the value of margins to the 1948 level. The reference to that matter in His Excellency's Speech was not as clear or as correct as it could be. His Excellency said -

quote.para: The industrial tribunals have granted very substantial increase in all marginal rates of pay. while competition for labour has raised pay still further.

speech.para: There has been a substantial increase of some margins - only of some, though - hut margins certainly have not been raised to the level to which they should be raised in order to give workers the same purchasing power as they had in 1948, under a Labour government. Who reaps the benefit of that? Big business again. Employers do not have to pay higher wages to their employees, and consequently they can make very big profits. While all this has been going on, profits have been increasing. In order to see that that is so, one has only to look at the financial journals or at the financial pages of any newspaper.

When thieves fall out, we often get bits of information that we do not get at other times. Honorable members will remember that recently Waltons-Sears Limited tried to get a controlling interest in Cox Brothers (Australia) Limited. It sent a circular letter to all shareholders in Cox Brothers. Incidentally, the letter that I have in my hand was not addressed to me. The letter from Waltons-Sears Limited to the shareholders of Cox Brothers, the 15th December, 1955, contained the following passage: -

quote.para: The average percentage of net profit to ordinary capital after deduction of preference dividends fin- the past 0 years is 23.37%.

speech.para: That referred to Waltons-Sears Limited -

quote.para: This compares with the average percentage of 12.77% earned for the same period by Cox Brothers.

speech.para: Cox Brothers, not to be outdone, also sent a circular letter to their shareholders, dated the 19th December, 1955. In a paragraph headed " Brief answer to Waltons-Sears letter dated 15th December 1955 " the following statement appears : -

quote.para: The audited figures published by Cox Brothersshow that the net profit to ordinary capital on retailing was, in 1955, 14.3%, and in 1954, 18.6%.

speech.para: It is only when arguments of that kind occur between organizations that we get anything like a true picture of the profits that companies are making at present. That example, of course, is only one of many.

Following the wage freeze to which I have referred, what did this Government do? It allowed prices to rise without restriction. As a matter of fact, it encouraged an increase of prices by removing subsidies from some commodities. So we find that a new method of reducing wages has been adopted. In the past, the Government was not as shrewd as it is to-day. It used to reduce wages by 5 per cent, or 10 per cent., but now it freezes wages and raises prices by 5 per cent, or 10 per cent, and achieves the same result. What effect has that policy had on the Australian economy? It has had the effect that we are being outpriced by our overseas competitors.

Who has to take the blame for that state of affairs? According to the Government and the big business interests, the worker must take the blame. It is said that he is getting too much money in his pay envelope, that there is overfull employment, and that he is not working as hard as he should be working. The truth is that the Australian worker is as good as, and even better than, workers in other countries. Given adequate power, efficient management and uptodate machinery, he can produce as much as any other worker. My authority for that statement is National Development of March, 1954, a publication issued by the Department of National Development. It contains this statement -

quote.para: Moreover, in recent years, productivity in Australian factories has increased substantially. The increase in output per man-year which has taken place compares favorably with the challenging standard set by the United States.

speech.para: I ask honorable members to note the following further statement : -

quote.para: In the best equipped and best managed factories, the current level of productivity of Australian workers and factories is good by «ny standard.

speech.para: When people are criticizing the workers, they should remember those facts, and remember that the Australian worker, if given efficient management, adequate power, and up-to-date machinery, can compete with other workers. I say to supporters of the Government and the people whom they represent: Do not blame the workers, but place the blame where it belongs. It does not belong to the Australian Labour party or to the workers.

One would have thought that, following the 1952 crisis, the Government would have prepared some plan to meet future crises, but it has not any plan at all. An editorial in Muster of the 4th October, 1955, which is the official organ of the Graziers Association of New South Wales, refers to the stop-and-go economic policy of this Government and concludes with the following statement: -

quote.para: The Government, alerted by the events of 1952, should have had time to think and plan ahead to meet a similar situation in a more adequate fashion. The nation hae every right to expect that the repetition, in 1955, of the same state of affairs should produce suggestions to safeguard the future - plans more satisfactory than the purely expedient measures put forward up to date.

speech.para: It will be noted that journals which do not support the views of the Australian Labour party are critical of this Government for its mismanagement of Australia's affairs. The situation has been brought to a head by the huge surpluses that are accumulating throughout the world. The United States of America has in storage surpluses worth £A.3,000,000,000. The American Government is paying guaranteed prices to the farmers, and it is at its wit's end to know how to dispose of those surpluses. The Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) is critical of that country because it is disposing of its foodstuffs in a manner that does not suit him. Such large surpluses have a tendency to depress world prices, and a situation has arisen which is similar to that which the late Mr. Ben. Chifley had in mind when he said that 75 per cent. of the last depression could have been avoided by sane economic controls, lt will be remembered that he built up Australia's overseas balance to £S36,000,000. The Treasury Information Bulletin published in January shows that for the six months ended December, 1955, there was a further reduction of £5S,000,000 in our overseas balance and that it is now well b low £300,000,000. Our economy is poised like a house of cards; only one card needs to move and the structure will collapse.

The unfortunate aspect of the matter is that the Government has brought forward no means of solving the problem. It is just allowing things to drift. The only method that it will adopt eventually will be the old tory method of allowing the worker to carry the burden. Some business interests are openly saying that there should be some unemployment. Of course, there is nothing new about that suggestion. That method has been usedmany times in the past, and those persons who have applied it have always reaped huge benefits. That form of economic savagery, which will eventually be introduced by this Government, is contrary to the Australian way of life and must be resisted by every right-thinking member of this House. As a matter of fact, at a by-election in 1945, the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) stated that there should be a pool of unemployed in order to discipline the workers. He said that quite openly. Although he has since denied that statement, it is recorded in the Wheatgrower of the 24th April, 1946, and can be read by anybody who is sufficiently interested to look at it. It was this Government that appointed the notorious Professor Hytten to the Commonwealth Bank Board. Professor Hytten said that there should be a pool of unemployed of from 6 per cent, to 8 per cent. That is the direction in which we are heading at the present time. Has the Commonwealth not reduced its works programme by 10 per cent.? Although it has not reduced its financial assistance to the States, there is no doubt that, as soon as the forthcoming State elections are over, financial assistance to the States will be reduced and they will be forced to curtail their public works programmes and to dismiss some workers. Families that have deposited a few pounds in the savings banks or who have invested money in Commonwealth bonds, as many of them have been doing, will be forced to drain off their meagre savings.

We want a healthy economy based on a consumer purchasing power that only a fully employed labour force and decent wages can provide. Some men are unemployed now, and many others in employment are -not as sure of a steady job as they were a little while ago. An article in the Financial Times of the 9th February, 1956, indicates that jobs are becoming scarce. The latest figures published by the Commonwealth Statistician show that fewer houses will be built in 1956. As a result, less furniture and fewer household goods will be purchased. Consequently, unless something is done to give the community greater purchasing power, the dangerous situation with which we are now confronted may develop into a fullscale depression. The only way of avoiding a depression is to formulate a public works programme. The blueprint should be prepared now, so that when unemployment comes the slack can be taken up.

talk.start.para: .- Undoubtedly one of the greatest problems that exercises the minds of responsible citizens, and has done so in recent years, is juvenile delinquency. As you know, Mr. Acting Deputy Speaker, this subject was extensively traversed by the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Cleaver), but I consider the need to deal with this problem to be of such paramount importance that it cannot be too strongly emphasized.

speech.para: In discussing the problem with some of my colleagues, I found that their immediate reaction was that juvenile delinquency was not a matter for this Parliament, but for the governments of the States. I do not subscribe to that view, and for that reason I propose to make my speech to-night along certain lines. First, I shall endeavour to prove that this Commonwealth Parliament; - and I use the word " Parliament " advisedly, because I believe a subject of this nature should be well above mere party considerations - should accept at least some measure of responsibility in the matter of juvenile delinquency. Secondly, I shall endeavour to make a few concrete suggestions as to means whereby this Parliament could do something positive towards combating thisscourge. Some of those suggestions may be novel, some may be provocative, but I shall offer them in the hope that they may provoke some discussion, from which something concrete may emerge that will be of definite benefit to the community.

A few weeks .ago I -attended a meeting convened by a municipal council, part of whose area falls with in the electorate of Henty, which I represent. Those honorable members who know Melbourne, and who know the electorate of Henty, know that the majority of homes in that electorate are modern, spacious and well kept, and, therefore, it is reasonable to assume that there would be little or no juvenile delinquency in my electorate. But that is not so. Figures produced by the police at one of the police stations in this municipality showed that in the previous two and a half months there had been 25 arrests, only, four of them being persons over the age of nineteen years. I think that honorable members will agree that those figures disclose a very shocking state of affairs.

I believe that the problem of juvenile delinquency should interest this Commonwealth Parliament, for two reasons. The first is on the grounds of pure economics - pounds, shilling and pence. We have been told that the recent waterfront strike cost the wharf labourers and the shipowners more than £6,000,000 in wages and profits, and that its cost to the community cannot be accurately calculated. We are frequently reminded of our adverse trade balance and, quite rightly, of the steps that we must take to correct it. But I maintain that those matters pale into insignificance beside the colossal waste caused by vandalism and juvenile delinquency, and beside the cost of maintaining great numbers of persons in gaol. Added to these is the cost of maintaining the government departments responsible for the administration of the police forces, the courts and the gaols of this country. The number of man-hours lost <to this country by the- incarceration of. large numbers of persons in gaols far exceeds the number lost by any strike. At the end of 1949 it was costing the Australian community £10,000,000 a year to administer the departments associated with the courts, police forces and gaols. At that time, there were 4,000 persons in gaol in Australia. Those figures are the latest at my disposal, but it is reasonable to. assume, on the basis of previous years, and taking present costs into consideration, that to-day there would be nearer 5,000 persons in gaol and the cost of administering the departments concerned with the machinery of justice would be substantially higher than it was in 1949. I believe, therefore, that if this Parliament would tackle the problem with vigour and in the right way, many of those persons now in gaol would become, law-abiding taxpayers who would help to contribute to meeting- the cost occasioned, to the nation, by the scourge of juvenile delinquency.

It is ridiculous- to contend we cannot afford to use a few million, pound's annually to deal with this matter. I say that we cannot afford: to do nothing about it. Recent research by childrens' courts in Victoria show that two of the major causes of juvenile delinquency are loss of, or lack of, parental control, and the shortage of adequate clubs suitable for adolescents. In many instances loss of parental control is due to the loss of one or other of the parents. When the missing parent is the father the position, is more serious. I believe that, at this particular stage of history - and- this observation applies all over the world, and not only to Australia - the loss of many of those fathers i3 due to the recent war. I do not say that the war can be blamed for all cases of lack of parental control, but it can be blamed for many of them. and if this Parliament accepts responsibility for repatriation services, the provision of war service homes, war pensions and widows pensions then, I submit, it should be equally willing to accept its moral responsibility to the children who lost their fathers in the last war.. Certainly a nation which can spend more than £1,000,000 a day on fighting a war - and I believe that if the war were still going om we would still be finding the money to fight it - can. afford s few million pounds a year to fight juvenile delinquency.

This brings me to some of the suggestions for dealing with the problem that I wish to make in the hope that it will be alleviated. I believe that this Parliament should call an immediate conference, on a federal level, of all interested parties, including State governments, churches, the Boy Scout movement, the Young Men's Christian Association, and' so on. I think that some suitable agreement could be arranged through interested municipal councils, State governments and other bodies whereby the necessary number of youth centres could be provided, on the basis that the municipal councils would provide the land, the Commonwealth would- provide the buildings, and the. various State governments would provide the equipment and the cost of maintenance. I do not know what it would cost to build a suitable building for a youth club, but l think an adequate structure of that kind would cost between £10,000 and £15,000. Certainly any money which is expended by the Government in this direction would be returned many times over in social value. It would be really an investment and not an expenditure. A sum of £1,000,000 expended in this direction would build 60 or so of such clubs and youth centres, which would be designed to direct the energies of our young' people into the right channels.

The very tenor of life these days is taking children away from the environment of the home. They are finding their entertainments outside the home. They are congregating in crowds on street corners and in milk bars. In cases where the milk-bar proprietors are- decent people that is, perhaps, not a very serious matter; but instances- have been brought to notice- of young people having become contaminated by coming into contact with persons of undesirable character. In every one of those packs or groups of young people on the streets there is a potential leader, and it is absolutely essential that the influence of that leader should, he for good, and not for evil, because of the effect it has on his weaker brethren.

I believe that too much responsibility for combating juvenile delinquency has been placed on churches and welfare institutions. Those bodies are doing a wonderful job, but they are hamstrung by lack of finance. I have two suggestions to make whereby I think the Government could assist the churches and other organizations in tackling this problem, with great benefit to the community. Many people who are regular churchgoers feel that the maximum amount they can contribute to the collection is 2s., because there is no medium of currency between the florin and the 10s. note. Many church leaders believe that the issue of a 5s. note would be of material benefit by providing an intermediate amount of contribution between 2s. and 10s. I believe that the issue of such a note would also fulfil a very useful purpose in the community generally, and I urge the Government to consider it seriously. Another way in which the churches could be helped would be to exempt from income tax regular contributions by way of collections. I do not mean that any taxpayer should be able loosely to say that he had contributed so much to his church and was, therefore, entitled to an increased exemption. A growing number of churches are working to a fixed plan of pledges through an envelope system, and if my suggestion were adopted, I believe they would be prepared to co-operate with the Government by issuing monthly or quarterly receipts for regular contributions made in that way. Any money or benefit the churches derived from this scheme would help them fight the problem of juvenile delinquency.

I do not subscribe to the colloquially termed practice of " passing the buck ". It is easy for honorable members to argue that these matters are of no concern to this Parliament, and that the responsibility rightly rests with the State Governments. The State governments are just as entitled to lay the blame at the door of the churches, and those institutions, in turn, could place it right back where it belongs, on the parents and the community. But let us, as a government, face the position as it really is, and do something about it. Statistics recently produced in Victoria show that in. children's courts during the five years upto 1953 juvenile delinquency increased, by 50 per cent. In Australia, its greatest incidence is between the ages of 16- and 22. It has been calculated that 1.6- in every thousand of our population in that age group is a criminal. I am convinced that a large percentage of them have missed the love and guidance of a father due to the war. Youth is no problem if children can be guided and' moulded, but the streets are not theproper place for them to obtain their experience. If we do not mould and guideour youth correctly they will soon befound in the courts, and ultimately in our gaols or mental institutions. Honorable members who read the press should need no proof of that fact. Fairly recently, in two of the industrial suburbsof Melbourne it was estimated that 75 per cent, of the crimes committed were by children between the ages of eight and" seventeen. One highly organized gangperpetrated a series of shop breakings and the eldest member of it was found to beeight years old. This is not a fairy story. That case was reported in the MelbourneSunNews Pictorial on the 4th March, last year. In last week's press a report appeared of two boys of twelve and thirteen years of age respectively who, in. Melbourne, stole a number of cars to thevalue of £35,000.

These facts all emphasize the need foryouth clubs. If the Government does not form them, these young people will form their own and use them as places to plan crime and other acts of delinquency.. That has happened in the United States of America, and it is a fact that the police are afraid to go intothese clubs unarmed, and then only in twos or threes. This Government makes grants to the National FitnessCouncil and to one or two other organizations, but generally speaking it does little - towards helping our youth. The general public applauded the recent decision of" this Government to assist in financing homes for the aged on a £l-for-£l basis,, and it should be just as enthusiastic to dosomething similar for the youth of thecommunity. It is equally important tolook after both ends of life.

Another important factor in the matter of child delinquency is the lack or inadequacy of housing. Honorable members on this side believe in home-ownership, and are proud of what the Government is doing to help people purchase their own homes through the CommonwealthState Housing Agreement; but nothing that is done is so perfect that it cannot be bettered, and I have a suggestion to offer which I hope will at least start discussion and may lead to some practical result. Many young couples, wishing to own their own homes, are under great strain to find the necessary deposit, and when they have their homes they are able to furnish them in only a meagre way. They are placed under a further difficulty to meet the repayments over a period of -30 or 30 years.

This Government pays a bonus on the birth of a child, and also provides child endowment until the child reaches the age of sixteen years. I suggest that when the first child in a family reaches the age ot one year, a sum of £100 should be credited to a housing account for the parents. When the second child reaches the age of one year, a further £150 should bp placed to the credit of that housing account. When the third child reaches ils first birthday, a sum of £250 should ho credited and for the fourth and each subsequent child, £300. The result would bc that when the fourth child had his first birthday, a sum of £800 would have beep wiped off the cost of the home. Surely that is little enough to pay for four of the very best type of immigrants it is possible to obtain, and certainly much le.ss than the cost of bringing four migrants from abroad under the present immigration scheme. Let it be clearly understood that my suggestion would only supplement the present immigration policy, and would not in any way prevent other migrants from coming to Australia. It would help to populate the country, something that is greatly needed, and would give some incentive and assistance lc, young couples to purchase their own homes. The amounts I have suggested Ave only tentative, and may be deemed insufficient and in need of revision, but if such a scheme were adopted it would lip a step in the right direction. The suggestion is not that this money be paid in cash, but that it should be credited to an account to assist in home ownership and so encourage persons to be better citizens.

I wish to sum up my remarks by relating a parable. I recently heard a story about a man who fell into a hole in the road which was too deep for him to climb out of without assistance. Three men passed him. The first commiserated with him on being in the hole, the second told him what a fool he was to be in that predicament, and the third helped him out. Let us not be like the first man and hold up our hands in pious horror at juvenile delinquency. Neither let us' be like the second man, and say that the responsibility belongs to the States and the churches, and fail to recognize that we have a problem or try to absolve ourselves from the blame. Let us be like the third man and give a helping hand. Irrespective of what has happened in the past, or of whose fault it may be, let us make sure that in the future no finger can be pointed at this Parliament because of its lack of vision or charity. I am not trying to preach a sermon, but I arn pleading for the youth who are the future citizens of this country so that they may be given their just rights and privileges. This Parliament has accepted a responsibility to look after the aged. Let us extend that responsibility to the youth of the community as well, and as a nation and a parliament, give a lead to the world by recognizing our responsibility and showing that we are prepared to do something positive to make many young Australians better members of society.

speech.para: There are very laudable sentiments expressed in the article, but all the information contained in the article that reflects on me, all the information that reflects on my secretary, and all 'the information that reflects on my stenographer, is entirely and absolutely untrue. And yet this paper says that they were in the room of the honorable member for Brisbane and that he evicted them. My secretary does not know the honorable member and does not know his room. My stenographer has never seen the gentleman. He, in turn, has never seen my stenographer, although it would be to the everlasting good of his soul if he had. talk.start.para: .- I wish to raise a very important matter which actually becomes more important when we consider what has happened to-day. It comes into my office every month, unwelcome, unheralded and mostly remains unopened, despite the fact that I have written to its management and said, "Do not send your rag to my office any more ". debate.para: All sorts of rumours have been circulating in the intervening years until we on this side of the House have come to the conclusion that it will be only a matter of weeks before this Government, again after secret negotiations, will suddenly make a public pronouncement that a corporation has been formed to take over the Commonwealth ships. Honorable members first learn about these things from reports in the press. Just as was done in the case of the whaling industry, the transaction in connexion with the Commonwealth ships will be decided while the Parliament is in recess, and we shall merely be required to listen to the Minister's explanation of what has been done. The Colonial Oil Refineries Limited went that way, and so did Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia) Limited. The whaling station at Carnarvon will be disposed of in similar circumstances; and the next thing will be the Commonwealth shipping line, in spite of the fact that the Australian people do not want these ships to be sold.

In Tasmania, there is a farmers' organization with about 8,000 members called the Tasmanian Farmers Federation. I desire to quote a few extracts from the leading article of the federation's weekly paper of the 19th January, 1956. It is headed " Commonwealth ships ", and it reads -

It U also disturbing for the reason that the sale of this large interest in a vital national asset is to he made to a private interstate chipping monopoly which, if reports are true, is itself controlled by overseas shipping interests.

I can now advise the House that I hare received an interim report and have been told that the committee will deal more fully in a later report with matters 'which are referred to. The second aspect to which I wish to refer is that late to-day I received a report from the chairman of the Stevedoring Industry Board on a number of stoppages which have occurred since the date on which a general resumption of waterfront work was to have taken place. It appears that even in the relatively short time since the 15th February, when the resumption was to have taken place, there have been stoppages in nine ports of the Commonwealth. I base that statement on what is alleged to have been said by one of the federal councillors in addressing a. meeting in Melbourne. Mr. E. Bull was reported as having said: -

quote.para: Everything we can do to embarrass the shipowners and the Government without damage to ourselves, we will do.

I would have thought that common sense would by now have indicated to them that whatever damage may be done to the shipowners and the stevedoring companies. - and it may not be as much as is sometimes believed, because experience has shown that they are able by adjusting freight rates to cover these losses - the real blow is struck at their fellow citizens, and in particular their fellow unionists. Not one Australian household escapes the damaging effects of these interruptions to the shipping and commerce of this country.

I believe that we, as a parliament, will have to consider what is presented in this report and decide upon suitable action. When we do that we shall have to keep in mind not only the interests of the federation, the shipowners and the stevedoring companies, but also the state of the Australian economy and the burden that is placed upon it by a blatantly inefficient waterfront operation such as we have witnessed in the last few years.

speech.para: While the Minister was speaking I obtained the impression that running through his statement was a threat to the waterside workers, and to anybody who happens to sympathize with them. In addition to that, he has explicitly, as well as implicitly, thrown the whole responsibility for trouble on the waterfront on to the Waterside Workers Federation. By his own action in calling a conference of shipowners and waterside workers' representatives and representatives of the Australian Council of Trades Unions in this Parliament House a short time ago, he, according to the press, told the shipowners of what he thought was their share of responsibility for what had happened on the waterfront.

Workers do not go on strike for the fun of it. Every waterside worker lost at least £132 in the recent strike. I suggest that the waterside workers had a just cause and a good case. They had been in and out of arbitration courts and conferences for a couple of years, but had received no satisfaction. Moreover, since work has been resumed on the waterfront neither the shipowners, nor the court, nor any other party has brought the matter into court so that the men could get the marginal increase which everybody expects them to get - the amount to be decided, of course, by the court, but without any alteration in the conditions under which they have been working. The parties were prepared to have the matter discussed by the court at a certain time, but now that the men have gone back to work the Government says that it is satisfied now that work has been, resumed, and is completely indifferent to the claims of the waterside workers. That will not get peace in the industry.

talk.start.para: - The court has been sitting regularly in this matter.

speech.para: Mr. -CALWELL.- It has not yet produced any result, and the waterside workers themselves have not been encouraged to go to the court with any claim. After all, it is their claim that should be considered, and not the counterclaim of the shipowners. Every member of the Opposition wants peace on the waterfront, but we can have peace there only if we have it with justice. Nothing is properly settled unless it is rightly settled. The Government can say what it likes about Communist control on the waterfront and the activities of certain people in promoting lightning strikes and the rest, but the great body of the waterfront workers are not Communists and would not strike or engage .in activities about which the Minister has complained unless they felt a deep sense of injustice.

Thousands of men have left the waterfront since the strike began, and they will not go back, because the conditions prevailing there are not as good as the conditions in other industries. Decasualization is an objective yet to be achieved; and it was a Labour government that set up the Australian Stevedoring Industry Commission to help improve conditions on the waterfront. If this Government did half as much as the Chifley Government did to promote peace, there would be real peace on the waterfront. It is up to the Government, instead of issuing threats and telling the waterside workers what it intends to do with them at a later stage, to take positive action so that further trouble on the waterfront will be avoided. Petrol tax in common with other taxes on commodities has been used for general revenue purposes for many years, ft was not until 1920 that any portion of the petrol tax proceeds was set aside for road purposes. Since 1920 the following amounts have been collected and distributed - Period 1926-55 - Collections f 351, 000,000, Distributions £161,000.000. In addition to the above distributions, an amount of £4,300,000 has been allocated since 1947-48 to strategic roads and roads of access to Commonwealth properties. On two occasions since first assuming office, the present Government has increased the allocations from petrol tax for roads. As a result, the proportion of total collections allocated for road3 from Customs and Excise on petrol has increased from about 45 per cent, in 1949-50 to 73 per cent, at the present time.
